name: Presidente
text: . I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 19 December 2019.

name: Presidente. –
text: On behalf of Parliament and personally, I would like to express my deepest condolences to the families and friends of the victims of the tragic crash of the Ukrainian plane, which was shot down shortly after taking off from the Iranian capital Tehran on Wednesday, killing all 176 passengers and crew on board. We trust that a thorough, thorough and transparent investigation will bring justice to the victims. I invite you to observe a minute's silence in their memory. (Parliament was standing and observing a minute's silence)

name: Rasa Juknevičienė (PPE).
text: – January 13, 1991 was essentially the last of the baltic countries to prolong the battles of the Second World War. Belatedly, because it was almost fifty years since the Ribentropo-Molotov Pact, but it was won.  Thank you, Mr President, for having adopted the unseeded, which many of my colleagues have become entangled in today. Today, on January 13th, we are already celebrating not only as a day of tragic loss, although people who defended freedom were then killed or injured under the dense tracks. Today is a day of victory for us, paving the way for the European Union and NATO. Finally, the Second World War ended two years later – the first of ninety-three September, when the USSR army was brought out of Lithuania. This unscmied symbol of respect and remembrance for all the victims of Soviet communism, from the Baltic, Poland to Romania, Bulgaria, Albania, as well as the millions of people killed in Russia itself, is a sign of respect and remembrance. Today is a good opportunity for me to thank all my colleagues who voted in favour of an important resolution on the action of the Russian Federation against the investigators and judges of the January 13 case in November. The solidarity you have expressed is a very important European value.

name: Presidente. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome, I hope that the holidays have been good for everyone.

name: Presidente. –
text: The final draft agenda as set by the Conference of Presidents pursuant to Rule 157 of the Rules of Procedure was distributed at its meeting on Thursday 9 January 2020. The following amendments have been tabled. Following consultations with the political groups, I would like to submit to the House the following proposal to amend the final draft agenda for Thursday: the title of the debate on 'Burundi, in particular the case of detained journalists' is replaced by 'Burundi, in particular freedom of expression'. (Parliament agreed to the request) On Monday, the GROUP of the European People's Party called for the title of the Commission statement on 'Cross-border organised crime and its impact on free movement' to be changed to 'Cross-border organised crime and its impact on free movement – The case of Malmö and Copenhagen'.

name: Tomas Tobé
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Sweden has serious problems with violence connected to organised crime, and the city of Malmö is particularly affected. Bombings and shootings are now part of everyday life in Malmö. Last year, the Danish Government introduced border controls against Sweden to protect Danish citizens from Swedish gang members. This is a unique decision. No other government in Europe has so clearly pointed out gang members in a neighbouring country as the reason to have border controls. The PPE believes that the escalating violence in Malmö and Copenhagen should be mentioned in the title of the debate on cross-border crime, and we ask for a roll call vote on this matter. The fact that the S&D Group doesn’t want the problems in Malmö to be mentioned in the title is deeply regrettable. Let’s take the chance in this Parliament and change this today. We have serious problems to handle and it’s important for Sweden, Denmark and Europe. (Applause)

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Mr President, what I find regrettable is that we are trying to use this shift, which makes it possible to change the agenda, so that, for the third time in a row, we can try to win a vote which has already been lost twice. And I say this because the Group of the European People's Party has twice tried to move this issue to the Conference of Presidents and the other groups have clearly told them what our position is. If necessary, we reiterate it again. We believe it is important to talk about the dangers of organized crime, but without the need to criminalize a particular issue and attack a particular city, in this case. Therefore, continue to insist. This political group is still going to have the same position.

name: Presidente. –
text: The ID group called for the title of the Commission statement on "Devastating forest fires in Australia and other extreme weather events due to climate change" to be changed to "Devastating forest fires in Australia – Activation of the RescEU program."

name: Joëlle Mélin
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of the nightmarish news of a continent that is burning, where thousands of animals, insects and plants have gone up in smoke in a few weeks and where human lives are seriously threatened, we have a collective duty to react. This reaction can be based on the European culture of solidarity, especially with this great friendly country that is Australia. The architecture and modalities of the rescEU programme, even if it is theoretically reserved for the Member States, allow it. The idea is to send exceptional logistical and operational capabilities to this continent to fight the flames. Therefore, I ask you to support, ladies and gentlemen, this change in title for our statement to the Commission on these devastating fires in Australia.

name: Petros Kokkalis (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, unfortunately the nightmare that is happening in Australia does not happen by itself, it happens because of climate change. Therefore, we disagree with removing the title. However, we do believe that we have a moral responsibility to use rescEU all over the world in all possible means. So we would not object to the rescEU part being a part of the title, but we would object to removing the reference to climate change from the title.

name: Presidente. –
text: The Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left has called for the addition of statements by the Council and the Commission on the excessive use of force by law enforcement during peaceful protests and demonstrations, as the second point of the afternoon. The debate should end with a resolution to be voted on Thursday.

name: Anne-Sophie Pelletier
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, a year ago in this European Parliament a resolution was passed against police violence in the European Union. We are seeing protesters all over Europe today who are being abused and abused by the police, and I am thinking particularly of the citizens of Greece, Belgium, Romania, Poland, France and so many others. Despite the condemnations of the United Nations, NGOs, Amnesty International, the European Court of Human Rights or the Defender of Human Rights, I would like to remind you of an image we saw this week: a young girl who is raped and shoved by the police or the firing of bullets at close range .A. Our GUE group and the insoumise delegation France are therefore calling for a debate and a resolution on the ban on LBDs, de-encirclement grenades and ventral veneers, which are banned in some countries. The use of force, I would remind you, must be proportionate and that is why, ladies and gentlemen, since we are going to talk about texts on fundamental freedoms this week, I would remind you that the right to protest is a fundamental freedom that the European Union must guarantee.

name: Beata Kempa (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear Lady, I would like to thank you for your I would like to say that you have used the name of my country: Poland. In Poland, demonstrations take place peacefully and are not suppressed by the police, but protected. On the other hand, as regards the rule of law in France, we are in agreement, but we have our proposal and I hope that the President will allow me to present it on behalf of the ECC Group in due course. It is also a matter of changing the agenda on Wednesday.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Mr President, would it be possible to ask for a separate vote? Because the proposal, as we understand it, is debate with resolution. We would be in a willingness to make the debate, but not that there was a resolution. So, if possible, we asked to separate the vote, and we would support the debate.

name: Presidente. –
text: The ECR Group has asked for a Commission statement on 'the rule of law in France, in particular recent cases of violence against protesting lawyers' to be added as a second point. The debate will end with a resolution to be voted on Thursday.

name: Beata Kempa
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In view of the use of force against defenceless lawyers and lawyers in the Paris courthouse and the earlier violent pacification of protesting people, the so-called yellow vests, On behalf of the ECR Group, I request a debate with the adoption of a resolution on the rule of law in France. I would remind you that the right to express and express one's views is the foundation of the European Union, enshrined in particular in Article 12 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which guarantees everyone the right to free and peaceful assembly. Power in France, by using force against its own citizens and lawyers, breaks the above principles, which are also referred to by the Treaty on European Union and the Treaty of Lisbon. Let us therefore check whether the same rules and the same law apply to large EU countries such as France, where, I recall, protests are not suppressed. Is the principle of equality respected? I request a roll-call vote so that everyone can speak publicly about whether they support physical attacks on defenceless lawyers in France.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the devastating forest fires in Australia and other extreme weather events due to climate change (2020/2504(RSP)).

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I think I’ll wait a second until it calms down a little bit.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, despite the dramatic and, I would even say, tragic events we are going to discuss in a minute, this is the first time we have seen each other after the Christmas break, and therefore I would like to wish all of you, the citizens you represent and the whole European Union, all the best for the New Year and happiness in 2020. We know that it will be a very challenging year and therefore I very much appreciate that you have already put as the first item on the plenary agenda this urgent debate on the devastating bush fires in Australia. As you know, my Commissioner colleagues are now coming to Strasbourg from Luxembourg, where they have been pledging the oath to their office at the European Court of Justice, and therefore it would be my pleasure and my honour to represent the European Commission in the afternoon’s plenary debates with you. As you very well know – and as Australia has confirmed – these fires which we are going to debate are unprecedented. They have devastated local communities, they have led to the tragic loss of homes and they have taken the lives of people and, possibly, of over a billion animals, many of which are completely unique in the world. Beyond the immediate destruction of forest, land, lives, animals and ecosystems, these wildfires jeopardise health and livelihoods in other places as well. Canberra experienced peak air pollution levels that were 20 times above the hazardous threshold, to give just one example. First and foremost, we send our support and solidarity to Australia. The European Union stands ready to help the Australian people. Yesterday, my colleague Commissioner Lenarčič reached out and spoke to the Australian Minister Littleproud and he reiterated the Union’s readiness to assist Australia in this moment of crisis. He also informed the Minister of the possibility for, in particular, firefighters to be deployed at short notice under the Union Civil Protection Mechanism. The Minister appreciated the support and readiness of the Union to help, but he reiterated that at this stage they don’t require additional assistance. The science is loud and clear. Climate change will increase the frequency of extreme weather events and these events will continue to affect us, and with more and more consequences and higher and higher intensity. Do we need more proof that the prevention of climate change and environmental destruction, adaptation and disaster risk prevention, are absolutely necessary, and that we need to mitigate the effects of climate change together in Europe, in Australia and in the rest of the world? We have discussed many times in recent months the importance of EU leadership on global climate action. The effective implementation of the Paris Agreement and increasing global ambition is a key priority under the European Green Deal. The European Union will use all the tools at our disposal to tackle the global climate challenge. Our bilateral engagement with partner countries is crucial, in particular with the G20 economies that are responsible for three-quarters of global emissions. We value our long-standing partnership with Australia and are working to strengthen it through the establishment of the Dialogue on Climate Action under the Framework Agreement. The Commission thanks the Parliament for tabling this urgent debate and for seeing the climate urgency in these tragic events and especially in these circumstances, where we need to highlight the need to take global action. This is yet another proof of Europe’s ambition to take leadership against climate change, and on this the Commission will always remain on your side.

name: Hildegard Bentele
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, thank you very much for your report. Let me make two comments on this: firstly, on the occasion of the commission's relaunch, on the occasion of the launch of the Green Deal and following the World Climate Conference in Madrid, the EU must add the climate and environmental dimension to its foreign policy more clearly than it has done so far. We do not just need summit and conference diplomacy, we need constant publicity for compliance with the Paris climate targets and the content of the Green Deal. Future EU climate diplomacy must be strengthened in terms of personnel and, above all, clearly assigned to institutions and competences, so that we can quickly bring difficult partners such as Australia on board in the future. On the other hand, we must remember that the way in which fires are fought has been called into question. The Australian firefighting system is one of the best in the world and has yet been overwhelmed by the novel fire dynamics. We have to deal with living with the fire or leaving certain areas uninhabited in the future. In 2018, 100 people were killed in forest fires in Greece. Australian vegetation is found in many parts of the world, and a new hot summer may come here in Europe. Therefore, representatives of the Council and the Commission, please take up both the new challenge of preventing and adapting to firestorms and strengthening European climate diplomacy.

name: Miriam Dalli
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, many might think that what is happening in Australia is happening in a faraway continent with no impact here in Europe, but nothing can be further from the truth. The wildfires in Australia are increasing the CO2 levels in our atmosphere and creating toxic airspaces. The smoke created by these wildfires is orbiting the entire planet. Fires in New South Wales and Queensland alone emitted a combined 306 million tonnes of carbon dioxide and they are generating enough heat to create unique weather systems, including cyclonic fire tornados.  The 7.3 million hectares of land that have been destroyed cover an area that exceeds the size of the Netherlands and Belgium combined. Over one billion animals – twice the amount of EU citizens – have perished. And this is, yes, a biodiversity crisis. Australia is home to truly unique species, including 200 types of mammals that do not exist anywhere else in the world.  In the face of this destruction, complacency should have no place, and the EU needs to remain a leader in fighting climate change when these things happen. Because we saw an unperturbed government in Brazil when the Amazon was on fire, and we are seeing an Australian Government that for the past months has been hesitating to link these fires to climate change. We saw some Members of this House today trying to do the same. It is even planning to use a carbon accounting loophole to fulfil its Paris Agreement commitments and this is not acceptable. As we discuss here, the Australian wildfires are still raging, and are projected to do so for at least another month. Ultimately we are speaking about climate change. We are in this together. That’s why we urge the Australian Government to recognise climate change, phase out its dependency on the fossil fuel industry, and honour the Paris Agreement now, before it’s too late.

name: Ulrike Müller
text: Mr President, i.e. the Renew Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her On behalf of the Delegation for Relations with Australia and New Zealand, I would first of all like to express our sincere condolences to the victims of the Australian bushfires. We stand in full solidarity with the Australian people at this extremely difficult time in the face of heavy loss of life, loss of private property, farm animals, wildlife and nature and the damage to the economy. Our thoughts are with the families and friends of the victims and injured, and our heartfelt thanks also go to the firefighters and volunteers. Of course, the first question is the causes of these catastrophic fires. The climate in Australia is generally hot and dry. Bushfires are an integral part of Australia's ecology and allow the re-growth of certain species and plants. However, it is not clear that climate change is also causing drier and hotter summers in Australia, and thus also affects the length of the bushfire season. What consequences are we going to draw? On the one hand, we need to check whether the EU civil protection mechanism has grown disasters of this magnitude. This concerns both operations within the EU and our ability to provide assistance in third countries in such exceptional situations. Of course, Australia must also stick to its climate targets, and I expect these targets to be met, partly because of the great potential for renewable energy. Prime Minister Morrison said this in the press yesterday. The European Parliament delegation will travel to Australia as early as February to find out about the impact of the fires and progress on climate change. We will have an open debate with The MPs and the government. And now I want to say that we are primarily offering our support to our Australian friends at this difficult moment and helping them to overcome the enormous challenges.

name: Pär Holmgren
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Australia is currently experiencing the warmest summer it has had – the start was also the driest. The average temperature for the month of December was just over 4 degrees above normal for that country – quite an extreme 1.7 degrees above the previous record in December, and this old record was broken only last year.  This is exactly what climate scientists have warned about; a warmer climate naturally leads to an increased risk of heat waves, but also an increased risk of drought, and thus also an increased risk of forest fires. With the totally inadequate climate policy that we are currently pursuing in the EU, the US, China and Australia in particular, we are heading for 3-4 degree warming by the end of the century. And this summer will then be considered an ordinary summer.  Is this what we want to contribute from Europe? We have to do much, much more – now. Not in 2030. Not in 2050, but now, this year.

name: Sylvia Limmer
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her What bothers me most about the discussion is the sensational satisfaction of left-green climate neurotics about the terrible fires in Australia according to the motto: Here is finally the proof of man-made climate change. Shame on you, and please do so vigorously. Without sounding cynical, devastating fires have repeatedly developed from the fires that belong to the continent's ecosystem: 1851, 1939, 1983, 1974, 1975, for example, were such years. And the issue of drought? In fact, there is a tendency towards higher annual rainfall, as can be guessed here in this descriptive statistic of the last 120 years, even if 2019 was particularly low." The reasons for the fires? In addition to arson, it was in particular the perverse policy of green environmentalists that prevented the state programs for the targeted burning of dead wood. This has massively increased the so-called fire load. Even small bushfires can develop disastrously. Incidentally, these facts do not make the suffering of those affected any more bearable, nor do they make the drama in the animal world any more bearable.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! The situation in Australia is indeed extremely serious. Fires are digesting almost the entire continent. They have been wreaking great havoc for many weeks to the detriment of Australian wildlife and biodiversity, threatening the lives of humans and animals. We are, of course, all deeply concerned about the development of the situation, the drought that has been going on for so long and the high temperatures that, of course, are conducive to these fires.  But let's not forget that fires on the Australian continent are not a new phenomenon. They happen almost every year. Astonishingly, when I listen to our discussion, it is this concern of the European Parliament about climate change. Because if we look at the european Parliament's actions, how much does it care about the climate, when once a month it moves entirely to Strasbourg for four days, thus generating CO2 and an annual cost of EUR 110 billion? So I appeal for actions, not words.

name: Petros Kokkalis
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, (I would like to say to Vice-President Šefčovič that) the fires in Australia are unprecedented, yes, but they’re not unexpected. In 2008, the Garnaut report on climate change commissioned by the Australian Government projected that fire seasons would be longer, fires would be more intense and their effect would increase over time, becoming fully observable in 2020. Our own science from the GRC of 2018 says exactly the same: longer seasons, larger areas, bigger fires. Especially in the south of Europe, even in the best case scenario of a 2 degree warming, the projections for the future are near apocalyptic.  What did the current neoliberal climate-denying Australian Government do besides blocking agreement in COP25? They reduced the budget of New South Wales for firefighting by 75% and that for rescue by 34%. Mr Vice-President, we must not do like the Australians. We must do as our own scientists and our own children demand. We must invest and innovate in fire adaptation and civic rotation and we must make our rescEU and EFIS capabilities a global leader as part of the external Green New Deal. (Applause)

name: Eleonora Evi (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the fires that have devastated Australia since September have had a dramatic toll, we have talked about it and we are seeing it: twenty-five people have died, more than 10 million hectares of land have been destroyed, more than a billion animals have been killed. The capital Canberra, with its 500 000 inhabitants, recorded the worst air quality in the world and the fumes even reached Chile and Argentina. It is an unacceptable budget and it is yet another piece in addition to the ever-increasing list of extreme weather events that are caused by climate change. Yet the dramatic images of the fires are not enough for the Australian Prime Minister, who not only responded belatedly to the fires but also stated that his conservative government will not strengthen policies to combat climate change. Australia was also one of the countries, along with Brazil, which most hampered negotiations in Madrid last COP 25. The Commission is currently negotiating a free trade treaty with Australia. What action does it intend to take to ensure that sustainability objectives and environmental protection standards are included in the sustainable development chapter? Does it intend to support these objectives through sanctions in the event of non-compliance?

name: Michal Wiezik (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the problem in Australia is not the fire itself, it has long been part of Australian nature. Bush, forests and Australian unique species are adapted to it. The problem is the large scale of fires allowed by two extremely warm and dry years. The average summer temperature was four degrees higher than normal. When asked: Welcome to the future. In the near future, this scenario will be common, fires will be repeated, their range, intensity and frequency will increase. If we do not start effectively reducing carbon emissions and allow nature to adapt to changing conditions to the maximum extent possible, Australia will be a terrible example of the failure of an economic model incompatible with life on our planet. The remedy must be a global initiative consistently transformed into national policies. Let us be under no illusion that this does not concern us, that Australia is too distant and exotic. Unfortunately, this smallest continent will not be left alone.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – Madam President, massive wildfires have been raging through the country in recent months. Since last September, 28 people have died and thousands have lost their homes. Firefighters are risking their own lives to keep people safe. Our sympathy is with the Australian people in these difficult times. Not rain, but ash is falling from the skies of Australia. We all know that these extreme bush fires cannot be viewed separately from climate change. This is not a casual emergency – this is a climate emergency, stemming from a climate crisis. Now the question is whether these catastrophic fires will bring some sanity to Australian climate politics. The Conservative government, led by Prime Minister Morrison, has done nothing to meet its climate commitments. During the UN climate talks in Madrid, ‘ScoMo’ sided with Brazil and Saudi Arabia to derail global action on cutting emissions. How can a Prime Minister make fear of the costs of climate action more terrifying than the actual results of climate change themselves? Of course, this is not only an Australian problem. It is related to one of the biggest global challenges of our time, in which we all bear responsibility. The devastating Australian fires underline the magnitude of the effects of inaction at the recent COP 25 Climate Conference. This only makes it more important for us, as the EU, to lead and set a standard for the rest of the world. But the European Green Deal is not and cannot be only about Europe – climate diplomacy must become an integral part of our external policy and a fundamental pillar of our soft power around the globe. There is no time to waste anymore. Leading by example we must bring all of our partners with us for common, bold political action on the climate crisis.

name: Stéphane Bijoux (Renew).
text: Madam President, do you hear this cry, even 17,000 kilometres from Australia? Do we hear the pain of the families of the human victims and the suffering of the victims who have lost absolutely everything? Do we hear the cries of a billion charred animals? It is a deafening cry, it is an upsetting SOS that sounds like a global cry of alarm and that is the way to hear the Australian drama which, despite itself, demonstrates that we are right to build a European green pact. As you know, 300,000 European citizens live two hours from Sydney, New Caledonia: they are - and we are, therefore - the first neighbours and witnesses of the disaster. Today, in Europe, we must mobilize in the name of solidarity, of course, but the reality is that we need an obligation of collective intelligence and political mobilization. While we have just declaring a climate emergency, how can we fail to understand that if we do not accelerate our fight against climate change, the Australian disaster will be our global tragedy tomorrow. How can we fail to understand the need to combat climate sceptics all over the world, including here, because the consequences of ecological tragedies have no borders: from Australia to Chile, a toxic cloud has just crossed the world's largest ocean, an ocean rich in biodiversity. I would like to point out that 80% of Europe's biodiversity comes from overseas: it is with this legitimacy that I reaffirm the need for concrete actions to protect the environment and future generations, and it is with this assumed optimism that I declare that the European Green Pact must be based on overseas solutions.

name: Anna Cavazzini (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The fires in Australia are a nightmare, and you sit there all the time wondering: what can we do, what can we do as Europeans? What is clear is that our solidarity is in Australia, but expressions of solidarity are not enough. We need to look very closely at how our economic relations with Australia are fuelling the climate. After all, even Premier Morrison now recognises that there is a link between the climate crisis and the fires. Example number 1: The EU intends to conclude a free trade agreement with Australia later this year. This agreement will lead to rising emissions, as even an official analysis by the Commission says. For example, because the increasing production of meat is claiming more and more pasture land and because we are sending meat and other products around the globe. Example number 2: We all know we need to get out of coal as quickly as possible, and yet Australia is planning one of the largest coal mines in the world with Adani – along with European companies like Siemens. Australia is on fire, and Siemens' treaty with Adani is more important than the Paris climate agreement. Both examples show that we finally need a climate change in EU trade and foreign trade policy.

name: Annika Bruna (ID).
text: Madam President, the dramatic fires in Australia have already resulted in the deaths of 28 people, the destruction of an area of forest equivalent to Ireland and the atrocious death of more than a billion animals. The forest will take 250 years to return to its original state and the losses in terms of biodiversity and CO2 capture are irremediable. If the influence of climate change is irrefutable, let us remember that the free trade you are advocating is one of the main causes. In addition, 183 arsonists were arrested in Australia, some linked to Islamic fundamentalism, Daesh inciting in its propaganda the burning of forests. In Both Australia and Europe, these criminal arsonists must be punished in an exemplary manner. European firefighters and experts were sent to Australia but too late. Let us help Australia and fight future tragedies by strengthening its rescEU and its firefighting capacity in Europe, but also by organising an inter-state force capable of deploying against major fires outside the Union.

name: Anne-Sophie Pelletier (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, we are talking about the biggest fire ever: 28 deaths, 80,000 square kilometres gone up in smoke, millions displaced people, more than a billion animals that have died. And some still feel that there is no climate change! The ecological disaster that is taking place in Australia must alert us collectively: it foreshadows those we will have to face. Let us be clear, however, those responsible are neither bad luck nor the combination of circumstances: it is these climate sceptics who continue to support the lucrative and polluting coal industry, those who prefer growth to the environment, those who organize scarcity by funding water, our common good. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, while Australia is suffocating, the country is burning, its government is selling water to the vultures of pension funds. This statement, ladies and gentlemen, does not obscure the Commission's arrangements and yours. Fellow MEPs, when it comes to establishing international free trade treaties that promote an anti-ecological model, when on Monday you vote on the ecological emergency and on Tuesday you open the doors to polluting lobbies, then stop your double talk of this ecological emergency. The liberal system you idolize is the source of ongoing and future climate disasters and your blind belief in the market will never save you.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to point out that, as soon as the news of the tragic fires in Australia spread, news immediately spread of the arrests of about two hundred arsonists who would have caused these fires, in this way weakening, or even denying, the correlation between fires and global warming. But the problem here is not so much to establish the causes of these fires, the fires, but rather to establish the causes of the spread of fires: how can we not see, or not observe, that this phenomenon of simultaneous even on a global scale is evident? How can you not consider that there were 50 degrees centigrade when the whole thing happened? Ironically, it all happens in a country that is the world's largest exporter of coal and is the one that has been most spent against climate agreements. Ironically, it all happens at a temperature increase of about one and a half degrees, one and a half degrees! So let's start figuring out what can happen to us.

name: Agnès Evren (PPE).
text: Madam President, 2020 was supposed to be the year of biodiversity, but the fires that have ravaged Australia remind us of the urgency to act. More than a billion animals have perished under the flames, some of which are listed as endangered. If the images of koalas or kangaroos in distress have upset the world, they are only the visible and mediated part of a global phenomenon, of which man is the main culprit: the unprecedented erosion of the biodiversity of our planet. Turning a blind eye to this fateful trajectory is suicidal. Food, oxygen, energy, medicine, raw materials, climate regulation, the services that our planet provides us are simply vital. Despite this, we are unable to preserve it. Of Aichi's goals, how many have been met? How many of the European commitments have been kept? Let's wake up to reverse the trend. Both the European Commission and the Member States need to make a stronger commitment to the next biodiversity strategy for 2030. Let us be leaders in this field now so that COP 15 is a real success that can lead to binding, measurable and enforceable goals. It is not too late but let us act.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The new decade began with the terrible news about the fire-ravaged parts of Australia. Large fires, the same size as the whole of Stockholm County or some European countries. And we, we are used to seeing our planet as Tellus where we can live together, animals and humans. But we saw an Australia that looked more like a sun. Fire means so much to us humans. It can be both light and dark. But in this time of climate threat, it is definitely darkness: the lives of people and animals that are extinguished and property destroyed.  When we discussed before the end of the year whether we should see a climate emergency, then this is exactly what we intended. That is why it was so important to adopt a climate emergency. Paradoxically, given the time we live in, the world ended the last decade by failing to adopt ambitious rules at the Madrid climate summit. It is very difficult, in the age of forest fires, to understand those politicians, political parties and those countries that do not want to contribute to an ambitious climate policy.  This is precisely what young people are trying to say to us here in the European Parliament: be responsible now, respect the Paris Agreement. This morning I was talking to a 7-year-old who is close to me, namely my seven-year-old, about the fires in Australia, and he said, "Isn't this what the exhaust gases of cars contribute to?" "Yes," I said. "That's it." "But then we should stop driving with them." That was the natural response of a child. But I have to say that the children's calls should be taken seriously. We need to be much more ambitious in climate policy.

name: Nils Torvalds (Renew).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for A word about the special of the Australian eucalyptus forest. We have known for a long time that this is a biodiversity that has lived a very separate life and where the whole food chain is actually based on eucalyptus-like trees. That is, biodiversity originates in the food chain created by the eucalypmese. It is on it that the mammals live, it is on it that the birds live, it is on it that the reptiles live and the insects and so on.  But what's so special about this eucalyptus forest? When the temperature rises to over 40 degrees, the oil also penetrates the leaves of the forest, and it simply becomes an explosive fire. This has been known from Australian forest fires for many years. But what does the Australian government do? Five per cent of energy in Australia is produced with renewable energy. Everything else is fossil.

name: Ville Niinistö (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the horrible scenes from Australia have shown that climate change and biodiversity loss go hand in hand. The scale of the damage is unprecedented. We are speaking about hundreds of thousands of animals and a lot of the nature of Australia, which is a unique biodiversity ecosystem in itself, having been destroyed. The scale of this damage is something that we also need to reflect on – that we are not prepared to adapt, and be prepared for the damage that climate change is going to inflict on us in Europe as well. We need to be better prepared to address forest fires in Europe, we need to increase our climate ambition, and we have to make sure that countries like Australia do their part as well. In this situation, I think it’s important that from the European side we show solidarity to the Australian people and put particular emphasis on addressing the biodiversity loss in Australia – there the government of Australia needs our help, but when it comes to the climate policies, they need a very urgent push.

name: Teuvo Hakkarainen (ID).
text: – Mr President, the core issue is what is causing the fire. Australia's wildfires are not caused by alleged climate change. There, like all over the world, there are large wildfires every year in dry spells. Does anyone claim that climate change has raised the temperature so that it spontaneously starts fires? You hear such crazy arguments.  In fact, the fires are started by a person intentionally or accidentally or by lightning. A large number of people have been arrested in Australia for deliberately starting fires. This climate hysteria today justifies everything possible and impossible. For many declarants of hysteria, it has developed into a serious obsession and fanatical religion.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, the whole world has been shocked by the bushfires in Australia. More than 10 million hectares of forest have now burned down. More than one billion animals such as koalas, kangaroos, wallabies and cockatoos had no chance in the immense sea of flames. This is an unmitigation a catastrophe for people, animals and the environment. How many more catastrophes do we have to go through before the rudder is drastically reversed?  Over the past century, it has become one and a half degrees warmer in Australia. We must do everything we can to turn the tide, starting with the livestock industry. Due to deforestation and CO2 emissions, the meat industry is contributing on a large scale to the climate crisis – the biodiversity crisis, but especially the climate crisis – which is making these fires even worse. We are all responsible for the survival of our planet. Knife and fork are our main weapons to combat climate change and help animals. That's why we need to eat less meat and dairy.  I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Rupert Lowe (NI).
text: – Madam President, I am sure everybody in this House joins me in sending prayers and best wishes to the Australian people as they deal with this national catastrophe. It’s disappointing that climate change has been blamed as the primary cause of these devastating bushfires by both our Parliament and other so—called climate experts. The cult of climate change marches on with no definitive evidence to support or deny the factual accuracy of their assertions. Logic suggests that climate change has little to do with this natural catastrophe. Higher human population density, resulting in more discarded cigarettes, sparks from electric transmission lines, campfires and, worst of all, arson are more likely causes of the problem. Traditional Aboriginal managed burning at the right time of year has been shunned or banned without any understanding of the consequences. This Parliament needs to urgently address its own excessive, avoidable carbon footprint by rationalising the waste associated with running three Parliament buildings in different geographic locations. We must end the culture of ‘do as I say, not as I do’, and be judged by what our hands are doing, not by what our mouth is saying. Anything less smacks of do-gooding hypocrisy. (Applause from certain quarters) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Petros Kokkalis (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, colleague Lowe. A very interesting approach towards the high population density and the higher concentration of cigarette butts that might be producing these fires. What is your opinion on the continuing unprecedented heat extremes which produce evermore lower moisture, which creates the ground for larger and larger fires, despite all the cigarette butts?

name: Rupert Lowe (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – It has in my view nothing to do as you say with dryness or heat. At the end of the day, we’ve had bushfires in Australia – or they’ve had them – tragically, many, many times over many, many centuries. The biggest fires happened in 1974-75. That was after probably the highest precipitation Australia had had for a long time, which propagated a vast amount of undergrowth and then the bush fires happened. This is why, if you ignore the Aboriginal traditions of backburning at specific times of year when it’s safe to do so, you end up with the problem they have now.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Australia offers us a real picture of destruction. Large areas affected by fire, drought and heat the most destructive in history. Air pollution in Canberra was measured 25 times higher than the permissible limits. A billion animals that died as a result of fires, that's really a picture of destruction, a picture of an inferno. I would like to express my solidarity, of course, with the Australian people, both the dead, the bereaved and those who have lost their homes. But at the same time, I want to hold the Australian government accountable. The Australian government is doing nothing to contribute to reducing carbon in the atmosphere. At the same time, it must be said that it is fully dependent on fossil fuels. Australia exports large reserves of its coal. We call the Australian government to account, come make the planet healthier with us.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: Mr President, contrary to what some extreme voices in this House claim, it is indisputably clear that global warming and climate change are having an incredible effect on forest fires, which do indeed occur every year but are now becoming real humanitarian and natural disasters. It is therefore unlikely to be important for us in the European Union to take responsibility with the new Green Deal and move towards a fully carbon-free economy and society. But we can't do it alone. We need partners in that.  We are in the process of negotiating a trade agreement with Australia. Surely it would be crazy for words if we didn't use the power we have to get Australia on the right side of history? It cannot be, it is impossible that those who want to become partners in our trade policy and gain access to our European market would not be partners in the fight against climate change. This means, of course, that future trade agreements – including the agreement with Australia – must include the Paris agreement and be able to be enforced, and, moreover, that the content of trade policy will in future be aimed at, for example, abandoning fossil fuels entirely. And as far as Australia is concerned, let's start with the coal.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171(8) of the Rules))

name: Marek Paweł Balt (S&D)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, I would like to ask you: do you not think that the European Union has a bit of a split self, because on the one hand we are reducing production by imposing green certificates and high costs on our steel mills, on companies and we demand that they reduce CO2 emissions (and well!), but on the other hand, last year we imported 10 million tonnes of steel from Brazil. We import coal into the European Union from Australia, from Russia, which is also causing an increase in the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere, pulling products from countries that do not reduce CO2 emissions. I would like you to respond to that.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. Ladies and gentlemen, this is just the point I want to make when it comes to trade policy. There is no point in ensuring that we become climate neutral only in Europe, in our own market, and at the same time let in products from all over the world that emit enormously and do not have the same levels of ambition as the levels we impose on our own industry. That is why I believe that trade policy really needs to be used to make climate policy a real one, and that we must ensure that we become climate neutral at the same time but can also continue to protect our own industry.

name: Marie Toussaint (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after the Amazon, Australia is now burning. 10 billion hectares of land were ravaged by flames, 28 people died there and more than a billion animals died. While scientists have established an indisputable link between climate and these unprecedented mega-fires, Scott Morrison's Conservative government continues to downplay the threat of global warming. He should act like a fireman, he's acting like an arsonist. Because coal accounts for 70% of the country's exports, it continues to defend these fossil industries that cause climate runaways. Our modes of production and consumption, by not respecting the rights of nature, endanger natural commons and life on the planet. Persisting in the path of denial and inaction is criminal. It's time to stop the catastrophe: let's really punish environmental crimes. It is time to review our economic treaty, our economic rules, our free trade treaties, to think of a post-growth economy based on respect for global limits. The planet burns, let's not wait for the last fire to light up and for the last tree to go out and finally act.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ID).
text: Madam President, I have defined the immediate consequences of the Australian fires in my initial request for a change of debate. I would like to add to this the idea of the dramatic consequences in the medium and long term, which will obviously be a loss of biomass which will lead to further droughts and deep water stress in a country where water is already a scarce commodity. While this phenomenon is obviously very much linked to this particularly hot summer in Australia, it obviously needs concrete and above all rapid and immediate answers. That was the purpose of the change in the title of our debate that I made at the beginning of the session. Of course, for reasons of political bigotry, Parliament refused my proposal to open and operate the rescEU programme to help Australians and was content, and I have just heard for quite some time, to make big statements about climate change but not to do anything concrete.

name: Robert Rowland (NI).
text: – Madam President, the tragic and horrific bushfires in Australia have once again been hijacked by the extreme eco—evangelists, who ascribe every natural disaster to anthropogenic climate change. This lazy, convenient narrative grossly oversimplifies bushfires, whose causes are as complex as their occurrence is predictable.  In reality, the proximate causes are other man-made factors, like human ignition and Byzantine government regulations made under pressure from the green zealots, such as the failure to perform prescribed burns, controlled felling and the removal of invasive grasses that act as fuel. The climate fearmongers dishonestly claim that Australia has experienced steadily worse droughts. This is nonsense. The data shows that the 1920s and 1930s experienced worse droughts and heat. So, yet again, I feel compelled to dispel the myth that this is caused by man-made global warming. In reality, the policies of a misguided green ideology are the real culprits and we have made what would normally be big fires into hellish conflagrations. So stop using this devastating tragedy to promote your extreme, overtly political environmental agenda of radical change to our economic system that won’t budge the global thermostat.  (Applause from certain quarters) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Bogdan Rzońca (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. "I am very interested in the reasons for the fires. Of course, I understand that one of them is climate change and global warming. But I have also heard that the law in Australia has changed a lot, namely under the new Fire Act, a significant part of the powers of fire and fire have been taken over by local authorities. In these local authorities, on the other hand, the Greens are starting to play a huge role and are already playing a huge role, which does not allow them to interfere in forest management at all. Do you confirm this information?

name: Robert Rowland (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – My honourable friend is quite right. In fact, I did some research last week which showed that the environmental lobby had prevented exactly what my colleague said: away from the local autonomous regions dictating how policy should be mandated and towards the federal level, and then being hamstrung by the environmental lobby again, which prevents what I would call moderate fires and felling, which have actually been eliminated because they believe it causes too much CO2. What happens then, of course, is that you get these massive conflagrations with vast amounts of CO2 as a result. So it’s imperative that we get what in this Chamber we used to call ‘subsidiarity’ – the ability of local authorities to actually run their own regions. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Lídia Pereira (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen of Europe, the violence with which the fires have broken out on Australia can only leave us with a feeling of horror and dismay. To the dozens of human losses, which we regret, add to the losses of wildlife and biodiversity. There are thousands of destroyed houses and an endless burned area. The terror and tragedy that Australians experience awaken sparks feelings of desolation and solidarity. Unfortunately, in Portugal, we are well known about this problem and have also suffered large human and wildlife losses in recent years. Extreme weather phenomena are increasing in frequency and their destruction is irreparable. Politics is asking for action. Here in Europe, we are moving forward in the fight against climate change. We have assumed the ambition of a carbon-neutral continent. The first in the world! The fires that have ravaged Australia, California, Portugal, are warnings we cannot ignore. Young Europeans realize the urgency of respecting the planet. We need all countries, all parliaments, all citizens committed to this change. Our total solidarity with the Australian people.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D).
text: Madam President, this is not the first time Australia has been hit by fires. But the ongoing drought and high temperatures, which reached record levels in December, significantly exacerbated the situation. Twenty-eight people have died and rare species of fauna are at risk of extinction. An area larger than Belgium and Denmark together has become ash. It is remarkably absurd, of course, that the countries with the greatest fires — Australia, Brazil, the United States — in front of Mr Trump and fellow members here today, who believe that climate change has no anthropogenic causes, do not want the Paris Agreement to be implemented. Indeed, the way of thinking reminds you of those who hunted Galileo centuries ago.  What are we supposed to do? We must fight for the Paris Agreement to be implemented and, at the same time, the necessary money must be found so that the European Civil Protection Mechanism (rescEU), for which I am rapporteur of the European Parliament, is ready in 2021 so that it can cope with the consequences of climate change both in Europe and in the third world.

name: Saskia Bricmont (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, in 1987, the Australian rock band Midnight Oil was a worldwide success with its song "Beds are burning", a denunciation of ecological disasters and a call to pull itself together urgently. The lyrics, in connection with the sad news that concerns us today, come back to me "How can we dance when our earth is turning? How do we sleep while our beds are burning?". Thirty years later, the dramatic situation in Australia foreshadows what the world will be like if the Paris Agreement is not strictly respected. What role for Europe beyond solidarity? This year, Europe is expected to conclude a free trade agreement with Australia. So now is the time to make the chapter of sustainable development binding on both sides. Let us not forget that while Australia has ratified the Paris Agreement, several generations of climate-sceptic political leaders have supported the mining sector, the engine of the economy, but also and above all, responsible for the destruction of biodiversity, the denial of aboriginal rights and which has placed Australia among the countries with the highest CO2 emissions per capita.  This is therefore the time for the Commission and Commissioner Hogan in the ongoing trade negotiations to do what is announced in the Green Pact for Europe and to implement ambitious climate and environmental diplomacy through its trade policy as well.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Madam President, Vice-President Šefčovič, if one looks for three terms to describe the causes of the tragedy in Australia, one could talk about 'inaction', 'overexploitation' and 'cynicism'. In Australia, in December 2018, annual greenhouse gas emissions increased by 558 million tonnes equivalent to carbon dioxide. Australia insists on denying climate change in practice, which is why its electricity generation comes from 60% of coal. There are people, including here in the European Parliament, who deny the existence of climate change; Tragedy in Australia can be a catalyst in our external relations as a European Union. As pioneers in tackling climate change we must broaden and support the alliance of the willing (countries, regions and industries) working to implement the Paris Agreement. The Green Agreement may be our new tool but also our heavy economic weapon. It's time to act in the name of the many. Preventing another tragedy and giving prospect of new growth, with new sustainable jobs that will support the sustainability of the planet.

name: Pernille Weiss (PPE).
text: Madam President! It's the greatest that overcomes itself. Right now we are concerned about the severe forest fires in Australia, and a few months ago it was the Amazon in Brazil. Before long, we will have to deal with either droughts or floods in Europe, which are putting a strain on our agriculture, and all the while the Greenland ice sheet has melted at a worrying rate.  There is indeed enough to worry about, but as politicians we are therefore elected to act on concerns, solve problems and produce results. But it requires us, as politicians, to overcome our propensity to talk up the problems and spread even more anxiety. This is, of course, about us being able to create fast calories in the media. I know, but it just makes the road to the results a lot longer.  Instead of showing the citizens of Europe, especially the younger generations, that we politicians can actually work together and that we are being factually, proactively, responsibly and results-oriented in the face of the climate challenge. That is certainly the approach that the EPP Group has in this House, and I hope it is an approach that several groups in this House share with us.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, together with thousands of citizens, I feel a certain helplessness when I see the loss of life and destruction of nature, animals. However, I certainly see it rationally, it is a consequence of climate change, now I am turning to my colleagues on the left, because extreme heat and extreme drought are not the result of green ideology. If it were just the result of a green ideology, we'd be able to handle it. But because it's the result of climate change, which is causing extreme climate change and causing extreme temperatures, that's why these fires are forming here. Citizens are asking what we're going to do about it. I thank Commissioner Šefčovič for the Commission's offer of support to the Australian Government, because, of course, citizens contribute financially to various collections, but they ask how the European Union can help and, if necessary, the EU will also help. But our response is the green deal measures, and I believe they will help.

name: Nicolás González Casares (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I deeply regret what has happened in Australia, the devastating situation, which gives us one more lesson on climate change. It must be thought that Australia has issued more CO2 fires with these fires than the UK in a whole year. We must draw lessons. We are about to launch the European Green Pact, which also entails a forestry strategy. Let us not import the Australian forest into our European territory. In Portugal, in Greece, in Galicia there are eucalyptus monoculture plantations that are also mimicking that forest that is burning in Australia. Let's not make climate change easy. When temperature conditions above 30 degrees occur, less than 30% humidity and winds of more than 30 kilometers per hour, the forest is more possible. Therefore, we must draw lessons from what happened in Australia so that it does not happen in Europe. And let's put in place realistic prevention strategies in the face of this looming climate change.

name: Ondřej Knotek (Renew).
text: – Madam President, we all have in mind pictures of wildfires in Australia, thirsty koalas asking cyclists for water, and thousands of citizens ending up on the beaches. I would like to express my support for the Australian Government, the firefighters for their extraordinary work, and the Australian citizens at this difficult time. Therefore, let me encourage our institutions and Member States to be open to help Australia through any financial, human, or material resources to tackle this dramatic situation. For that reason, I welcome the offer made by the President of the European Council to provide any assistance, and by several Member States to send firefighters. I would also like to emphasise the work done by the European Space Agency and its Copernicus Emergency Management Service mapping, which provided great assistance to Australian firefighters with the monitoring of bushfires.

name: Ellie Chowns (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, it’s indeed somehow very fitting that this first debate in this Parliament in the new year 2020 is on climate change because this must be the year that the world, as a whole, finally bites the bullet on climate action. With current policies we are on track for over three degrees of warming, and the tragic fires in Australia offer a foretaste of the human and ecological disasters that result. As MEPs across the political spectrum have acknowledged, there’s overwhelming evidence that climate change makes these types of events more frequent and more severe. Not only are the fires themselves tragic, it’s also tragic that there are still influential politicians in Australia with their heads in the sand – or in the coal mine – denying this link. To those in Australia who are fighting the fires and their human and ecological impact, we stand with you in solidarity and in mourning. To those in Australia who are fighting to make their leaders recognise and act on the climate emergency, we stand with you in solidarity and hope. And to those Europeans who want to sweep the climate under the carpet while pursuing free-trade agreements, I say simply, think again.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I think what’s happening in Australia is certainly a disaster, but there is nothing natural about it. I think we have to acknowledge the fact that the devastating bushfires raging across Australia are directly connected with the lack of action and the climate denial of the Australian Conservative Government. The best advice and the best support we can give Australian citizens is to acknowledge that point. It’s not an accident when Australia remains supportive of coal, it’s not an accident when federal and state governments continue to subvent financially the coal industry when they’re the largest exporter of liquefied natural gas, and it should be a wake—up call to the rest of us. An effective climate policy is a disruptive policy. It’s one that requires changes and one that should not be taken at the behest of industrial lobbyists.

name: Λευτέρης Νικολάου-Αλαβάνος (NI).
text: Madam President, invoking climate change as the cause of the fires that have claimed the lives of dozens of people and caused incalculable environmental disasters in Australia conceals the fact that today science and technology are capable of limiting, preventing and suppressing the consequences of natural phenomena. Any changes in the climate cannot be an excuse. On the contrary, they should entail even more political responsibilities for governments that not only do not take the necessary measures but, conversely, weaken civil protection and firefighting. Australia is facing this disaster without comprehensive planning, with few staff, 80% of whom are volunteer firefighters, with means borrowed from other countries. A similar design is envisaged by the European Civil Protection Mechanism (rescEU) for the Member States of the European Union. Cuts based on the unacceptable cost-benefit criterion, which are not limited to Australia, are a direction for the European Union and its governments. Let the people not come to terms with natural disasters, with the whole of the unpopular policy. Popular anger must become an organized struggle to make the environment and the land a popular property, to take measures to protect and protect the people.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I offer my deepest condolences to all those affected by the fire in Australia. There is great damage done and certainly these fires are caused by extreme weather conditions. We know that this is not just happening in Australia, it is happening in America, it is also happening in Europe. A colleague recalled fires in Portugal, Sweden. It is therefore important that we strive to calm climate change and, on the other hand, to ensure well-organised protection and rescue. In Europe, we have faced this problem, and the units that come together in such a case can respond more effectively to these extreme phenomena, whether through fires or through floods and other extremes. It is also important that we do not want to remain isolated in this effort to combat climate change and, for example, to turn off livestock production in Europe and to import beef from Australia and Brazil. That would definitely be the wrong signal.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Madam President, honourable, you say that the European Union is ready to help Australia in this catastrophic fire crisis. It is not enough to wait for the Australian prime minister to ask us for help.  It is clear that Australia is no match for this dynamic. Many people have died, thousands of homes have been burned, more than a third of the animals have died in the affected areas, and a koala is at serious risk.  In Slovenia, the Social Democrats have given the European Commission and the Government an initiative for international solidarity in the fight against fires in Australia. We propose that we offer free civil protection and fire fighting capacity to stem and extinguish fires, and we call on the Commission to draw up an immediate plan of joint activities immediately. Let's not waste time, let's send the Union's firefighters to Australia for help.  We need to mitigate the effects of climate change all over the world, and if we want to be a leader in climate action – we need to change the way we live, manage resources and attitudes towards nature and all living things on this planet, and above all we must take responsibility and increase our shared ambitions.

name: Hilde Vautmans (Renew).
text: Mr President, let us first and foremost express our condolences to Australia, and to all those firefighters who are working day and night to do that job. It's horrible what's going on, and it actually affects all of us, from big to small. My daughter came home this week and said, "Mama, we should adopt a koala like that." In fact, my daughter's struggle is a question for Europe: offer all the help we can offer. Firefighters, satellite imagery, we have to do everything in our power to assist Australia.  And for the critics, it is clear that climate change has something to do with this. So we need to bet more on the Green Deal. We must focus on the Paris climate agreement. We must ensure that the resolution we have adopted here, on the emergency situation, that we are going to take the necessary measures for it. We owe it to Australia, and to everyone in the world.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, climate change does not create bush fires, but it can and does make them drastically worse. Australia is one of the world’s top coal producers and exporters. It is the world’s number one exporter of liquefied natural gas, and its government gives $29 billion in subsidies to the fossil fuel industry on an annual basis, according to the IMF. When Prime Minister Scott Morrison was challenged on his country’s dismal performance in dealing with climate change, he said: ‘we don’t want job-destroying, economy-destroying, economy-wrecking targets and goals’. What he is saying is that the economy is more important than the future of the planet. Europe says that it won’t do trade deals with people who behave poorly and are not interested in keeping the Paris Agreement, and God knows, Australia were abysmal in Madrid. So please, we should do no deals with people if they don’t change their behaviour to meet the goals of the Paris Agreement.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we are indeed facing an unprecedented and perhaps truly most destructive and extensive fire, but this is not the first time. We had the same crisis – or maybe a little smaller – of the Amazon rainforests, before we had huge fires in Siberia. I think it's really like an apocalyptic pre-image of what's ahead of us, and that's why we need to act. It is good that we have the Green Deal, but we must also bring other major powers to our side – both the Americans, china, also Russia, brazil and, finally, Australia. After all, it is a democratic state, we also have trade negotiations with them. We must gain through our diplomacy on our part all allies, and especially all democratic states, but also others, because we contribute only eight to 10% of greenhouse emissions. And with those with whom we can't, we have to use a coercive diplomatic mission, or else they're going to stop us. So I say: it is good that the European Commission will negotiate and also offer assistance, but we will help biodiversity sooner and then we must, above all, put pressure on Australia to change its position on the whole issue.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the sight of the Australian bush burning ferociously has horrified all of us. I was equally horrified in December 2015 when the subtropical storm Desmond caused devastating floods in Cumbria in my North West England constituency. Whilst fire and floods are indeed natural phenomena, the scale of these extreme weather events tells us something we cannot ignore: climate change is real, and it’s affecting populations everywhere. Like many of you, I remember a shocking documentary showing polar bears marooned on melting ice flows. I also remember populist media pundits and right-wing politicians, including UKIP MEPs, denying the existence of global warming. With UKIP transformed into the Brexit Party, and their members now joining the Conservatives, we should all worry about the UK Government’s commitment to the environment. And can I suggest colleagues check out the campaign group DeSmog, whose excellent research about the powerful climate-sceptic networks influencing the Tory party exposes Boris Johnson’s personal links with rich and wealthy climate science-denying individuals and organisations?

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to show my appreciation for this important debate, even though this first plenary debate after the end-of-year break has been very dramatic. But I really do appreciate the wealth of information and all the aspects you covered in this discussion. As I said at the beginning, I believe that, after this debate, we can say that we as Europeans clearly send our support and our solidarity to Australia. As highlighted by Madam Šojdrová, it’s very important that this message is also spread across Europe, namely that we are ready to help, especially any country in such dramatic distress. At the same time, many of you highlighted the fact that what’s happening in Australia is just the consequence of global climate change, that this situation was caused by us humans, and that we need a global effort to take care of it. The interventions by Ms Bentele, Ms Dalli and Mr Bijoux appealed to us in the Commission – but also to our global partners – to make sure that we do this collectively and that we will have that consistent and strong global effort. We need to make sure that the Paris Agreement is implemented globally by all the key powers, as Mr Hajšel said, and to look for ways in which we can make that important transition in Europe socially fair so that we can demonstrate to other parts of the world that this is possible: that you can grow, that you can cut CO2 emissions and that you can do it in a socially fair manner. I think that, if we see that the world is not respecting our pace, we will have to look for new mechanisms – as was suggested in our previous discussions – to make sure that we push other countries in that direction if they do not respond to our efforts. Let’s consider mechanisms like the carbon adjustment mechanism or other measures to make sure that other industries in parts of the world outside Europe will also try to produce as cleanly as we do in the European Union.  I think that this discussion has also just reminded us of the fact that we in Europe have also not been spared the dramas and tragedies brought by climate change. Let’s just look back at some of the dramatic events which honourable Members have reminded us about – the tragic fires in Portugal, Sweden and Greece – and let’s be sure that we will not relent in making sure that our readiness and preparedness gets much better every single year to come. We need to simply make sure that we will improve the existing wildfire and forest management strategy, complement the fire suppression strategies with increased awareness, preparedness and prevention, and combine these short—term measures with long-term adaptations, which is so important, especially for forest management. The EU strategy on adaptation, which was adopted in 2013, was aimed exactly at that: to make sure that we would enhance our preparedness and resilience to the current and future impact on climate change, especially by the climate proofing of key vulnerable sectors such as those that I have already mentioned. All this would come under the new umbrella of the new ambitious strategy, which will be the flagship project of this Commission and, I believe, of this House. This will be the European Green Deal. Mr Knotek referred to the Copernicus Programme and I’m very glad to say that, yes, we are the biggest provider of this data, of the imagery which is very often key for fighting fires from California to Australia. We are, of course, going to develop that further and invest in early warning systems, such as the European Forest Fire Information System, which are critical for managing the crisis, as we are discussing today. We have improved our civil protection capacities, but we know that we need to do more. I would agree with Ms Müller and Mr Kokkalis that we have to permanently look for ways in which we can make it better, make it more fireproof and be properly prepared for all contingencies which might head in our direction in the future. To conclude, I would like to say that the best response we could give to this crisis is to be very focused and very determined in introducing the European Green Deal and demonstrating to other parts of the world that it’s possible to do it. We know how to do it and we are ready to share our experience, and of course in all that we would count on the support of this House – of you, of the European Parliament.

name: Lina Gálvez Muñoz (S&D)
text: in writing. – The magnitude of Australia's fires and their virulence, which has in many cases led to the loss of their control, made relevant a parliamentary debate addressing the devastating effects of climate change and extreme phenomenology and other environmental and international relations issues. We Socialists are aware that climate change is real and that we must continue to fight it. The remoteness of the ocean continent with Europe seemed not to justify this debate for some political groups. However, these fires are making an impact in Europe and the rest of the world. So many toxic gases are being generated, that there is even a risk of other weather events being unleashed. In turn, the debate is another call to meet international climate commitments. It is not acceptable for countries that do not comply with the Paris Agreement or that there are political leaders who deny climate change or ignore its consequences. This is a climate and ecological crisis. It is bleak to see thousands of hectares destroyed by flames and how certain types of mammals that exist only in Australia are at risk of extinction.

name: Sylwia Spurek (S&D)
text: in writing. – Even though fire has been an elemental part of Australia environment, the scope of current blazes is unprecedented. Scientists agree that climate change has contributed to Australia’s emergency. They are also in no doubt that one of the leading causes of global warming is animal agriculture since industrial breeding of animals is responsible for huge CO2 emissions, contamination of water and air. In the face of these events, the EU must urgently revise the planned trade deal with Australia. There are valid concerns that this deal will have negative impacts on climate change. A draft final report for the Trade Sustainability Impact Assessment published on 13 December warns us that greenhouse gasses emissions are expected to increase, as a result of increased production in Australia and in the EU. Such increase will come from the production of meat – mainly beef and sheep meat. This trade deal aims to liberalise current meat tariffs. As a result, Australia will produce more meat further contributing to climate change. The EU wants to be a global leader that sets the environmental agenda. We are now witnessing a real crisis and the EU must bring its trading standards in line with our climate ambitions.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, so we go from one difficult topic to another one, but I believe that this debate is really very timely because the threat of organised crime in the European Union is at record levels.  Organised crime affects the life and safety of European citizens. It affects Europe’s economy and society’s trust in public institutions. The 2017 European Union Serious and Organised Crime Threat Assessment Report stated that more than 5 000 organised crime groups are under investigation in Europe, which is a rise of more than 50% compared to the numbers from 2013. Their profits are estimated at EUR 110 billion per year in the European Union. However, only one percentage point of these profits is confiscated. The challenge is to build a holistic and comprehensive approach with the legislative and operational instruments to tackle the modus operandi of organised crime groups, including one of its key enablers, corruption. At the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) meeting in December 2019, dedicated to the fight against corruption and organised crime, the Members of this House called for a strategy on organised crime and corruption, as European problems call for European solutions. Therefore, I very much welcome the timely organisation of this debate.  In 2008, the EU adopted a legally binding instrument requiring Member States to outlaw participation in a criminal organisation.
