However, by the time it was adopted, some shortcomings had already been identified, such as the lack of harmonisation in the definition of the offence (participation in a criminal organisation), which, in practice, means that a number of Member States do not criminalise the mere participation in a criminal organisation, but require a specific link to a criminal offence. As policymakers, it is our duty to close loopholes in existing legislation. An external study on organised crime, and also on this issue, will be launched very soon.  The approach of ‘following the money’ should be part of any investigation into organised crime. The Directive on Law Enforcement Access to Financial Information entered into force on 1 August last year. Additional measures may be needed to enable law enforcement authorities to carry out effective cross-border investigations. Interconnection as well as access for law enforcement is a key component for investigations into organised crime, and this avenue should be pursued in the future.  Asset recovery offices have been created in all Member States, and the Directive on Freezing and Confiscation of Instrumentalities and Proceeds of Crime, adopted in 2014, harmonises these rules across the European Union.  A new regulation on the mutual recognition of freezing and confiscation orders that will apply as of December 2020 complements the legal framework. However, we need to do more. A confiscation rate of 1% is just much too low. The Commission will therefore present a report on the implementation of the Confiscation Directive to help reflect on the need for stronger provision on enhancing asset tracing, freezing and confiscation.  The Commission has already analysed non-conviction-based confiscation provisions in the Member States in a document presented in the LIBE Committee last September. The Europol 2017 report also highlighted the way corruption enables the crime. The 2019 midterm review showed the considerable increase in top-level organised crime activities in the European Union. It is essential that Member States are well equipped to fight against corruption. The capacity to fight corruption has been identified as one of the key aspects of the new rule of law review cycle to be developed by the Commission in 2020.  The European Labour Authority, mandated to facilitate the free movement of workers across the EU and to support the Commission and Member States in the application and enforcement of European law, will also create synergies and work together with other EU agencies, such as Europol and Eurojust, in the fight against organised crime and trafficking in human beings. The Commission fully supports Europol’s approach to dismantling top—level organised crime groups by removing the key players, the so-called high—value targets. Such an approach fits with a desire to deprive criminals of their illegally gained profits. It is also important for Europol to stress that any high-value targets initiative should be complementary to the EU policy cycle on serious and organised crime.  The fight against illicit drugs will be a priority for the next Commission. According to the latest report by the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction and Europol, we are currently experiencing the worst drug crisis in our history. The volume of cocaine and heroin introduced in the EU is at an all-time high, and in parts of Europe, synthetic drug production is growing. As the current EU drug strategy is ending, the Commission will consider what future action is needed in view of this alarming situation. EMPACT, the EU policy cycle for serious and international organised crime, has changed the way the Member States cooperate and tackle organised crime together. For the period 2018-2021, 10 crime priorities are being jointly addressed. These include cybercrime, drug trafficking, facilitation of illegal immigration, and trafficking in human beings, among others.  The numbers are staggering. In 2018, on trafficking in human beings, more than 1 200 investigations were initiated, with 7 249 suspects reported and 6 057 victims identified. Another example I would refer to is excise fraud, where over EUR 229 million of tax evasion has been prevented. So we see that the challenge is enormous and that this is really a European problem, a European challenge, to which we need to find the answers together. Therefore, I would really like to thank Madam President for tabling this issue for plenary debate. I will be listening very carefully to the views of honourable Members and will come back to you with concrete proposals in the future.

name: Tomas Tobé
text: On the other: – Madam President, Commissioner Šefčovič, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent Violence, linked to organised crime, is a serious problem in Europe, and in my country, Sweden, the situation has escalated. Last year, 40 people were shot dead, we've had 200 blasts. Malmö has been particularly affected, where, for example, a woman was shot dead while carrying her own child in her arms. Blasts and shootings are now so common in Sweden that the Danish government has had to take the decision to introduce border controls against Sweden in order to protect its own citizens.  Now is not the time to deny or reduce the problems we see with gang crime in Sweden. Now is the time to ensure that we can do everything we can, nationally of course, but also at European level, to be able to help increase security in Sweden and to ensure that free movement between Sweden and Denmark can also work forward.  It is tragic to have seen how, in particular, Socialist MEPs in particular have tried to reduce this and were not prepared to discuss it. I think we need to be more humble than that. This is a problem for Sweden, but it is also a problem for the whole region and Europe. I would therefore call on the Commission to make three proposals: to ensure that Europol has more resources, to focus more on Sweden, to stop drugs and weapons. Secondly, give Member States the right to deport criminals at all times, even if they are EU citizens, and to increase the exchange of information between Europe's police authorities. Together we can do more to increase security throughout Europe and in Sweden.

name: Heléne Fritzon
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his Organised crime in Europe and the world has become increasingly complex and cross-border. That is why we need the cross-border solutions. We Social Democrats take this development very seriously. Together in our countries, we will be even better at combating both crime and the causes of crime.  The situation is serious in many of Europe's big cities. Malmö is a city that I know very well, a fantastic city, but also a city that has been hit by violence and shootings. That's the way it is. But we also see that the Swedish Government's efforts are useful. In the latest police statistics, shootings are declining. And it's an important job. The latest attack in Sweden was, in fact, in Mr Tobé's hometown, Stockholm, and that is why it is so important that we focus on all the cities of Europe.  All Member States have a responsibility. Cooperation is needed, just as it is between Sweden and Denmark. Europol needs greater efforts, and greater police cooperation is needed where we can exchange information between our countries. We Social Democrats will always take the fight against organised crime. Our European citizens should be able to live in safety in our big cities.

name: Karin Karlsbro
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his Security is freedom. When you don't feel safe, your existence shrinks. In my country, Sweden, it is with sadness and anger that last year we took part in several horrific murders, linked to growing gang crime – including a mother who, carrying her infant, was shot dead in the open street.  Ensuring the safety and security of people is a key task for each Member State. Crime must be combated, crime is to be prevented. But we have long underestimated how crime, weapons and drugs flow between Member States and across the EU's borders. That's not how we're going to do it. The EU's freedom of movement should increase freedom, not be abused by those who want to destroy. Greater cross-border cooperation is now needed.  Today's police cooperation within the EU, Europol, is far too weak and without operational power. If we are serious about strangling the flow of cross-border crime, europe must have proper muscle. The Liberals therefore want europol to develop into a European FBI, which will be operational and able to make its own efforts when gangs operate across borders. I would like to say that this is urgent and important to the EPP and to the Moderates, who have taken the initiative in this debate. But now it's up to the evidence. If we are to take the debate on gang crime to European level, we must also talk about the solutions at European level. Resources will be required, and new ways of working together will be required. I hope that all the parties here tonight are ready to really step up cooperation against cross-border crime, so that this debate is not just filled with empty words. This is about people's freedom and people's lives.

name: Margrete Auken
text: verts/ALE Group. Madam President! Thank you to the Commissioner for an answer which I think is adequate. I'll look at it from a different angle. The means of action in many countries, including Denmark, has been border controls. Border controls can be useful in some places, but are actually mostly a huge hassle. Now, fortunately, it has been thrashed down between Sweden and Denmark. We do not bother citizens as much as we have done, and that has not helped.  We have introduced border controls against Germany too. In Denmark, we are currently celebrating the jubilation this year that we have reunited North Schleswig with Jutland, and at the same time we are very proud that we have built up good border cooperation between minorities – and the memory of Denmark not putting in border controls. Fortunately, it does not work, or rather: it does not work, it wastes money, it bothers our fellow human beings, it costs a lot. But that has been done. It is as foolish as the boar fence that has been put up down there, which does not help (says the Commission) but which bothers people and which is pure symbolism.  Thank you for making good suggestions.

name: Teuvo Hakkarainen
text: On behalf of the ID Group. – Mr President, freedom of movement is precisely what causes organised crime to operate almost unhindered at will. Europe's external borders only have control over the east, away from leaking borders other than a sieve. When the internal borders are nominal, there is no obstacle to the movement of criminals. Any rogue herd can come at any time and anywhere, even if pretending to be a refugee. What does the European Union say about this? It says, "Welcome to full board, how can we serve you?".  Borders are love and self-defense. A state without borders is not a state. Is it already beginning to believe here that multiculturalism, as it is invading us from Africa and the Middle East, is not a wealth, but a curse and a deadly threat?

name: Charlie Weimers
text: On the other: The ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The Danish Social Democratic Government has introduced border controls with Sweden. They look with concern at Sweden-based militant Islamism and organized crime, after, among other things, a Danish government building was bombed. The Swedish Social Democratic Government cannot even expel terror-branded imams, and is particularly concerned about bad publicity from more than 235 bombings in 2019 alone. Last night in Sweden small it again: a bomb in Stockholm, one in Uppsala.  Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul I want everyone back home in Sweden to know that the focus of the Swedish Social Democrats here today, in the run-up to this debate on cross-border crime, was not that bombings had become as common per capita in Sweden as in the Mexico of the drug cartels, but that Malmö would not be included in the debate headline. A good piece of advice for Social Democrats who are ashamed of what they have done is to go to Copenhagen. Listen to the Danes, learn from them; the Danes whom you have looked down on for so many years and accused of xenophobia. Maybe you can learn something on the coup.  But above all: get migration in order – when even the population register in Sweden has failed, then we know it's bad. Stop pressuring the Crime Prevention Council to correct reports so that they fit your picture of reality. This shall be independent authorities. Stop listening to left-wing criminologists. No more low-impact treatment with car burners. Let the police show the gangs who's in charge. Give customs muscle. Punish gang-related crime mercilessly. Clean up radical imams who hate Sweden, but above all: get rid of the lying Sweden image and start caring about the reality of the Swedish people. If you can't do it, you're going to resign.

name: Martin Edward Daubney (NI).
text: – Madam President, in 1992 European leaders gathered and signed the EU’s birth certificate, the Maastricht Treaty, yet by enshrining freedom of movement into law they unwittingly signed the EU’s death warrant. First, John Major betrayed the British public by denying the public a referendum on Maastricht; then, in 2004, Tony Blair opened the floodgates to 10 new European Union Member States – again, no public permission was sought. Blair was toasted by metropolitan liberals with a taste for cheap nannies and tradesmen, but big businesses devoured cheap labour as millions of low-skilled labourers moved in. Freedom of movement was also music to the ears of organised criminals, human traffickers and terrorists. The seeds of Brexit were sown, opening a fault line which should destroy the European Union. But when Angela Merkel rolled out the red carpet to one million asylum seekers in 2015, and Brussels attempted to bully other nation states into accepting quotas, the British people finally called time. Only last week, Guy Verhofstadt stuck up two fingers to our electorate by demanding freedom of movement must still be a part of the Brexit deal. Why? It’s bye-bye Mr Barnier, auf Wiedersehen Emperor Verhofstadt... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Javier Zarzalejos (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the subject which brings us to debate today is extraordinarily serious, because it is the only known case so far that border controls are reintroduced by an escalation of organized and violent crime. Cross-border crime has only one answer: cross-border cooperation. And when it comes to organized crime and terrorism, borders do not protect sovereignty: borders protect criminals. Europe has to be an area of freedom for its citizens and not mobility for criminals. Let's not kid ourselves. We know the problems and what needs to be done. We need to talk about more effective confiscation of assets, of control of cyberspace, of combating laundering, of access to evidence in judicial proceedings, of harmonisation of legislation, of cooperation in the instruments of detention and surrender, of strengthening European agencies. We have, in short, to put our facts where we put our words.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: Madam President! Commissioner, thank you very much for the introduction here today with a good overview, both with the enormous challenges we have, the increasing challenges we have with organised crime in the European Union, and also with the Commission's suggestions on what needs to be done in the future. Because we need to do more so that our citizens in Europe can be more confident. Organised crime is devastating! We've seen challenges with it. The EPP would like to discuss this. We're not afraid to discuss it. We have seen challenges with it in the north of Europe, and we are also seeing it elsewhere in Europe.  In fact, what I would like to bring forward here today is to show that we can work together on this in a good cross-country way. The Danish Social Democratic Government and the Swedish Social Democratic Government have joined forces to set up a special centre to be the focal point for action against organised crime in the Danish-Swedish region. Because we have challenges, but we can only solve them together. It also means that, at times, border controls are needed, that something else is needed at times, but we need to work together if we are to solve the problem of organised crime. The Swedish and Danish Governments have taken care of this together, and I look forward to looking at the initiatives that the European Commission will also be making in the coming months, so that we can really do something about this in Denmark, in Sweden and in the rest of Europe.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa (Renew).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Eef-Soviet, as you rightly said, in the 21st century, in the European Union, organised crime, corruption crime, white-glove crime, crime against the rule of law is more transnational and, in many cases, more sophisticated. That is why the improvement of instruments of police cooperation and judicial cooperation is so important. You have indicated that harmonization of crime definitions is key, and it is; it can also be key to improving the implementation of judicial cooperation and Euro-orders. Because, otherwise, criminals with higher economic resources are more likely to escape justice, to play with the system, to impunity.  Some of the alleged perpetrators of very serious crimes of corruption against the rule of law, of organized crime in general, play with the gray points of the system, weaving legal frameworks so as not to be tried, manipulating and twisting each rule regarding such police and judicial cooperation to avoid it, trying to have impunity. You said it: we need to be well equipped. Count on us actively to fight all of it. He's got all our support.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – According to some studies, the Respected Chairpers, around 90% of illegal migrants made contact with traffickers on their way to Europe, who then transported them for a certain part of the journey. From day one, it was clear that tolerating illegal migration only strengthens the chains for traffickers, as well as other forms of organised crime such as terrorism and prostitution, drug and human trafficking. It is understandable that desperate people agree to bad and dangerous solutions to get their hands on Europe and a better life. What is not understandable is that Europe looks kindly on the danger to which they put themselves and their families at risk and rewards such behaviour by accepting these people despite blatant violations of the law. This only encourages new illegal migrants and expands business through organised crime. The Union must finally bring order to its immigrant and asylum policy. This is for the benefit of all the inhabitants of the Union, but also of those who are yet to become one. In order to integrate well into our societies, they need to respect our borders, our laws and our way of life.

name: Balázs Hidvéghi (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European What we need to talk about here today is that the number of violent crimes in Malmö and many other Swedish cities has risen in recent years to such a level that citizens live in constant fear. The attempt by the politically correct press and the left-wing elite to shut up or relativise these incidents is disgraceful and shameful. We all know that Sweden has taken in the highest number of immigrants since 2015, and since then the number of violent crimes, bombings, shootings and assaults against women has skyrocketed. It must be said that the admission of immigrants in Sweden has led to disaster and their integration has completely failed. It is outrageous that the Swedish and European left continue to do their utmost to keep these facts heard. The real rule of law problem begins when a state is unable to protect its own citizens, and the press does not report on reality, but becomes a tool of left-wing liberal opinion.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Honourable President! The Schengen area without internal borders, which guarantees every citizen of the Union the right to move and reside freely, is one of the greatest achievements of European integration and is a key element of the Union's identity, embodying cooperation, reconciliation, peace, tolerance, trust and security. But Schengen has been a difficult test for the last four years, with six countries in the area erstyking internal border controls for four years, even though they have no legal basis for them.  Today, we are faced with the question of how to move forward. Are we already witnessing the beginning of the end of Schengen and what to do to bring it back to life? How and when internal controls can in fact be abandoned and whether alternative measures can achieve the same objective. The implementation of internal border controls cannot be a long-term response to the challenges of cross-border organised crime, migration and security. Internal controls are only a short-term solution, they are a postponing of responsibility. We must face the challenges of European migration and asylum policy, secure external borders, the fight against people smugglers, the mitigation of the situation in the crisis areas from which people are fleeing. We also need to strengthen cross-border cooperation between police and judicial authorities, the exchange of information between countries, which is still not effective and, above all, trust. In this spirit, we in the European Parliament have also adopted amendments to the Schengen Code with more transparent rules. At the time of the creation of Schengen, we could not have imagined four years of internal border controls. Let us not let Schengen, as we knew it, lose. All the risks will never be eliminated, of course, even if we restore control at all borders. We have rule reform on the table, but this is blocked by a lack of political will among governments. So who does the status quo really answer to? Therefore, my call again: we urgently need to return to the negotiating table and save Schengen before it is too late.

name: Ramona Strugariu (Renew).
text: – Madam President, we must be honest with several things. The fight against cross-border organised crime can only be achieved through a coordinated approach and cooperation based on mutual trust of the competent national and European authorities.  The reintroduction of border controls into the Schengen area is a solution that does not solve the cause, but only temporarily treats certain symptoms of the problem. Exceptional situations should not become a rule, and in this context Europol and Eurojust must and can play a central role in dealing with the root causes of the problem.  Secondly, the Schengen area is an area of freedom and safety. We can only keep it that way if, on the one hand, the national authorities are doing their job in an exemplary way, but at European level we are also more consistent and applied, including legislation. In the fight against organised crime, the measures now are not enough, as the experts present at the LIBE hearing on 3 December have also noted, and as you have well said, Commissioner.  Last but not least, the place of my country, Romania, is in the Schengen area but it must address the problem of organised crime much more seriously and effectively than it does today. We must not have vulnerabilities that endanger the citizens of the Union by giving satisfaction to those who want to restrict freedom of movement. It must remain a fundamental pillar of the European project.

name: Jörgen Warborn (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Organised crime is now one of Europe's most serious problems, and Sweden has unfortunately become a warning example. The situation in the Malmö region is now so serious that Denmark has introduced border controls with Sweden.  This, of course, affects a lot of people. However, I would like to highlight small business owners, who are often particularly vulnerable to this crime. I have met both farmers and builders who are exposed by the international theft gangs almost every week. This also applies to restaurant owners and shop owners who are subjected to this gang crime.  The gangs must be fought with full force, and I hope that the EU can help, because Sweden's Social Democratic-led government has lost control of this. We need to beef up customs, we need to expand Europol, and we need to ensure that police cooperation is expanded at European level, because freedom of movement should not apply to criminals.

name: Moritz Körner (Renew).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. Criminal law and law enforcement are still too often stuck at the borders within Europe. But organised crime has long since fully recognised the process of European integration. Any act that is not prevented by a lack of police cooperation, a lack of harmonisation in the European area, will allow Europe's enemies to argue against one of Europe's most valuable freedoms, namely freedom of movement in Europe. That is why we pro-Europeans are called upon to be bolder and to finally move forward decisively in police cooperation and the judiciary. We need to get out of the national silos that we have. We need a European FBI against organised crime, and we finally need better cooperation between our security agencies. Above all, however, we must protect one thing, which is the free borders within Europe and freedom of movement, because that is one of the most valuable freedoms on which Europe is built.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Honourable President! Cross-border crime, as we said today, knows no borders. An organised, pan-European approach, good cooperation is therefore needed. The reasons are very different. We have heard here today about corruption, drug trafficking, human trafficking, prostitution. On the other hand, we have a perfectly specific case at the border between Sweden and Denmark, where Denmark has closed its border because of crime, which is often the result of organised groups, also resulting from uncontrolled migrant flows. We need to be serious about it and we need to be really aware of it and we need to recognise and answer every problem that comes up. The policy is to identify the problem in addition to the police, the prosecutor's office, the judiciary, not hide it under the carpet and answer it. Otherwise, people's trust is lost and when politics loses trust in people, other, more extreme processes occur in society. So let us not close our eyes to serious problems and answer them, and we will also find it easier to solve this major problem and have the free movement of people in Europe.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I think it is good that, in the context of the debate on organised crime or the fight against organised crime, we are also discussing specific cases that have taken place in Sweden and Denmark. I even think it is perfectly understandable that the Danish Government has taken this measure, and therefore the temporary introduction or reintroduction of internal border controls within Schengen. At least it's good for calming the situation.  However, in the long term, of course, this is not of much importance, and we, especially here in the European Parliament, as responsible people, politicians and Members, must maintain a positive narrative of Schengen, and at the same time we must also support the European Commission on the points that Mr Šefčovič has appointed in terms of stepping up the fight, including by using Europol, also by giving more funding, while strengthening cooperation between Member States and between their investigative bodies. At the same time, we must also have an understanding of what governments such as the government in Denmark are doing and not use it for our political battle between the different factions.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (Renew).
text: – Madam President, this debate reminds us that security is a priority objective for all, but also that precautions must be taken to avoid being used as an excuse to achieve other objectives. Coordination yes, but with all those who can contribute information, knowledge and resources. Because, in the recent history of organised crime in Europe, we have seen how not to share information, how to marginalize security organisations with skills, knowledge and resources, has created serious problems and cost human lives. That is why this debate must serve to deepen coordination, in the creation of a true European intelligence system. Also, to stimulate the creation and implementation of more effective technologies to combat organized crime. But the journey should not be taken advantage of, as we see some reactionary forces doing here, to criminalise all who come to Europe. This is the most direct path to hate speech and the best way to harm the main objective: for real and effective collaboration to define individual responsibilities and enforce the law.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, in Ireland the problems of organised crime have nothing to do with the free movement of people, it has nothing to do with the migrants, who play a very positive role in our society. Since the banking crisis in 2008-09, we’ve actually seen what we would describe as ‘legalised’ organised crime in our banking sector, and in particular in the bad bank called NAMA that was set up to deal with stressed assets, but sadly the authorities have turned a blind eye to serious malpractice. When it comes to illegal organised crime in Ireland, it is very much built around the drugs industry. Sadly, the war on drugs has failed, just the same as the war on the criminalisation of the purchase of sex in Ireland has failed. For the life for me, I can’t understand why Europe still doesn’t harmonise its approach to the drugs industry, because you are only enriching the criminals, and it isn’t working.

name: Arba Kokalari (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for In recent months in this plenary, we have been debating serious events in several EU Member States, including the criminalisation of sex education in Poland; we have debated the murder of journalists and corruption in Malta. But when we from the Moderates try to take up the serious shootings and bombings that are taking place in Sweden and in Malmö, then the Socialists over there stop it. I cannot interpret this in any other way than to be ashamed and to try to reduce the problem.  I would like to appeal to the European Commission, which is here, that we must invest heavily in increasing security in Europe and in Sweden, because the Government in Sweden has lost control. The police in Sweden need help from Europol and increased police cooperation, and I do not want to wake up another day as I did this morning, when I saw that there had been another serious bombing, this time in my home town of Stockholm, but also in the city next door: Uppsala. The situation has completely escalated and we need help.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course, a subject of interest to all European citizens, and, Commissioner, you have presented us with a situation which concerns me. The fact that we have 5,000 crime groups, that they have increased by 50% since 2013, I wonder, what solution do we have, because Europol - you have informed us now - shows that corruption has also increased, so economic crime, prostitution, drugs, arms trafficking and, ultimately, loss of life, because not only society, but also the economy is affected. We simply have street shootings, shoplifting, bar evacuations, cafes. We need to find solutions and, in addition to presenting us here that you are going to do an analysis and a situation, I believe that we need to have proposals. And yes, I do not agree to personalise the case of Sweden or Denmark, we have an interest in the internal market, for all Member States, to have the correct and rapid transmission of information, to break up these networks that affect people's lives.

name: Antonius Manders (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his contribution. I miss the Presidency of the Council, which is a pity. Europe is based on economic cooperation and freedom. We see very often that people are taking advantage of this freedom, and that includes organised crime.  50PLUS is a party that strongly supports European cooperation. Europe must do good for European citizens, but we are very much affected by organised crime at the moment. So much money is being made that the police in the Member States can no longer adequately combat this phenomenon. I therefore call on the institutions to ensure that criminal law and the fight against organised crime become European powers in the next treaty.  At the moment, when it comes to subsidiarity, it appears that the Member States are no longer able to cope and that too much is being abused by the freedom we have in Europe. That has to stop. Make sure that there is no more money to be made from organized crime through all kinds of clever ideas. I hope that the institutions will come up with these ideas and policies to contain organised crime.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first let me thank you and the honourable Members for this very important debate highlighting the enormous challenge we are facing as Europeans in the face of organised crime and violence, and for reminding all of us how important these topics are for our citizens and how dramatic the situation is becoming. Many of you mentioned very concretely the situation in Malmö in Sweden, in Denmark, and indeed we have seen across the Nordic countries but I would say more generally across Europe, the fact that organised crime is on the rise, that drug supply trafficking has increased, and that we see also these very high numbers of organised crime groups which of course then lead to the increased use of violence. You cited the figures for Sweden and I agree with you that they are staggering. I can assure you that on behalf of the Commission we will be ready to explore all avenues, all possibilities, for how we in the Commission, but especially our specialised agencies like Europol and Eurojust, can be of help to Sweden and other Nordic countries or any country of the European Union which is in need of assistance. Several of you asked what we can do, how we can help, and in my introductory remarks I already reiterated some of the measures we would like to propose. But I think the most important one is to close legal loopholes, to make sure that we do not apply the law differently, that our police officials cooperate more sincerely, more cordially, that we would simply close the borders for criminals and keep them open for our law-abiding citizens. So therefore I really would like to thank Mr Tobé, Ms Fritzon and also Ms Auken for their support and also for the call to explore every possibility for how we can increase the capabilities of Europol and how to motivate our Member States and our police forces for even closer cross-border cooperation. I can assure you that this is one of the top priorities for this Commission, and we will see how this will be reflected in the Commission work programme which I hope we will be coming to present to you before the end of the month. Some of you – Ms Schaldemose, Ms Fajon – also referred to the temporary reintroduction of border controls by Denmark, and here I would just underline that Member States are entitled to temporarily reintroduce border controls at their internal borders if confronted with threats to internal security and public policy. Indeed in the last prolongation of border controls at internal borders Denmark specifically referred to the threats related to the cross-border criminality originating from Sweden. I would just like to inform you that the Commission is analysing its notification, its proportionality and necessity, because we know how Schengen is important for our citizens, how it represents the core and also the symbol of European integration. Therefore, we need to explore all the possibilities – how to prevent the causes which led to this temporary introduction of border controls. To conclude, I really would like to agree with all of you who said that this is indeed a European problem which needs a European solution, and therefore it is absolutely crucial that all of us, all actors, work together in this fight, and here again I would underline how the Commission counts on your continued support in this fight against organised crime.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. Freedom of movement is one of the foundations of Eu ropean Union citizenship, whose core values - the rule of law, democracy, the protection of fundamental rights, freedom of competition - are put at risk by organised crime, which is increasingly taking on transnational dimensions. In recent years, many Member States have seen an increase in violence and tax fraud and money laundering offences linked to organised crime. large quantities of drugs arrive in large European ports on a daily basis. Criminal groups acting at transnational level exploit differences in legislation between national laws, which in fact restrict judicial, investigative and information cooperation between Member States. A common EU strategy to combat organised crime is therefore essential, adapting to the new reality of criminal groups, through modern and effective legislation, based first and foremost on a unified concept of organised crime, which goes beyond the limits of Framework Decision 2008/841/JHA, and which includes the provision of survey instruments in step with the most modern technologies, effective asset law enforcement and stable cooperation with third countries. Only by overcoming regulatory gaps will we be able to protect rights without renouncing the idea of a united Europe.

name: Nicolaus Fest (ID)
text: Writing. For many, freedom of movement is considered one of the EU's great achievements. But it has a price. According to the 2017 European Union Serious and Organised Crime Threat Assessment Report, around 5,000 organised crime groups operate within the EU – an increase of 50% compared to 2013! According to the report by the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction, the EU is also experiencing the worst drug crisis since the EU was founded. And the attacks in Paris, Berlin, and Nice also show how terrorists are using free movement. Drugs, crime and terrorism undermine bourgeois societies. Added to this is the ever-increasing financial power of organised crime. Already, the annual profit from organised crime in the EU is EUR 110 billion! This, too, is changing societies into the negative. The situation in Central American countries is a blueprint for what is also seen in some countries in south-eastern Europe: the takeover of state institutions by financially strong criminal cartels. When Schengen was introduced, the EU promised that freedom of movement would not come at the expense of security. The exact opposite has happened, organised crime and terrorism are growing unhindered! Last week Denmark also reintroduced border controls because of the continuing security situation! The Schengen system has failed. We should finally admit that!

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the statistics on bomb attacks and shootings carried out in Sweden last year have led to the introduction of permanent border controls at one of the most open borders. The threat of illegal migration and terrorism has forced these anti-terrorist measures on the part of Denmark. At this point, the Schengen free travel zone faces a major test after both countries closed their borders in November, while Austria and Germany extended their temporary checks at their internal borders for another six months, the first with Hungary and Slovenia and the second with Austria. A total of six countries have closed their borders. We have seen how many Schengen member states do not deal with migration and security problems at their borders and have been forced to introduce checks on them. In this respect, Bulgaria is an example of the protection of the EU's worst land external border – the one with Turkey, where there is zero migratory pressure and is not yet a member of Schengen, even though it has met all the technical criteria. I call for a swift solution to tackle organised crime at European level so that European citizens can continue to reap the benefits of free travel in Schengen. Thank you!

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on "Single Charger for Mobile Devices" (2019/2983(RSP)).

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, this will be a little bit lighter, but it is also a very important topic for our citizens and I would like to thank you for giving me the opportunity to explain what the Commission is doing on the common charger. But, first, I would like to underline that the Commission has strongly supported the harmonisation of chargers for mobile phones and similar devices. The common charger campaign was an initiative triggered by the Commission back in 2009 and I have to underline that, thanks to the Commission’s efforts, the industry implemented a voluntary approach. The work has only gained in importance since that moment and, in the light of the urgent transition to the circular economy, a sustainable product policy is a priority initiative in the European Green Deal, which has just been adopted by this Commission. To give you a little bit of the background, I would just like us to remind ourselves that, in 2009, we had more than 30 charging solutions. Currently, we have only three main possibilities. The voluntary approach has therefore been very effective in reducing market fragmentation, enhancing consumer convenience and reducing the environmental impact without resorting to regulation. It should also be noted that electronic waste is still one of the fastest growing waste streams, which makes this type of waste prevention particularly important.  The voluntary agreement came to an end in 2014. Since then, the Commission has made every effort to promote renewed voluntary commitment. However, the last mile has not yet been accomplished. Since 2014 – the same year the voluntary agreement was discontinued – the industry introduced two new technologies for chargers onto the market: USB C and wireless. Fast charging capabilities have been implemented in many models too and, in this context of technological changes, we felt that the voluntary approach, actively supported by the European Commission, was the best way of achieving our policy objectives without hampering innovation. In discussions with the industry, we continuously insist on the need to agree on a solution which would fulfil the following objectives satisfactorily: convenience for consumers, the safety and interoperability of chargers, and the reduction of electronic waste.  Regretfully, the memorandum of understanding of March 2018 fell short of our expectations. The industry proposed continuing to allow for a proprietary solution instead of implementing one common charger possibility. Therefore, consumer convenience and the reduction of e—waste was not enhanced. In addition, the scope was limited to smartphones only, failing to capture other portable devices. Against the global backdrop of ever—increasing material use and resource extraction responsible for half of the total CO2 emissions and environmental pressures, we consider this a missed opportunity. Therefore, the Commission has explored other possible options with a study to be published in the next few days.  One of the options is the adoption of the delegated act under the Radio Equipment Directive. At first glance, regulating the common charging interface on its own would, however, not necessarily be an optimal solution. This would mainly consist in the elimination of proprietary connectors, representing around 20% of the market with limited benefits for consumers. For this option to achieve significant reduction in material use, e—waste and greenhouse gas emissions, it would have to be complemented by additional measures, for instance to mandate and/or incentivise the sale of mobile phones without the charger. Therefore, we will look at a combination of policy options, including regulatory and non-regulatory measures, in order to achieve our objectives.  The study also assesses whether it is possible to extend the scope beyond smartphones and thus enhance benefits to both the consumer and the environment, taking into account technical issues such as different power needs. In addition, innovation and interoperability are key elements of any solution. Therefore, any better-performing new charging solution would be welcome as long as it is a common charging solution. Along the same lines, interoperability of wireless technology for charging would have to be ensured, even if this is still an incipient technology. Consumers should definitely be given a central role, in particular if manufacturers are only allowed to sell mobile phones without the charger, which seems to be a promising option from the environmental point of view. This would entail large consumer awareness campaigns and consumers should benefit from any reduction in costs being passed on through lower prices for standalone devices. In the European Green Deal we have committed to support and accelerate the EU’s industry transition to a sustainable model of inclusive growth. We have committed ourselves to mobilise industry for a clean and circular economy, including for a sustainable products policy and durable design of products, also giving priority to reducing and re—using materials before recycling them.  The Commission is therefore committed to present the next steps to make common chargers a reality for all EU citizens, and we will keep you closely informed.

name: Róża Thun und Hohenstein
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that, yes, many of us have been advocating for more than ten years for a solution to this very simple problem. The number of cables and chargers produced and thrown away each year is simply unacceptable. We still need four different cables for smartphones, digital cameras, e-book readers and tablets. Europeans change their smartphones on average every two years, so every second year our citizens are forced to buy new chargers when buying new devices, even if all the chargers still function. Demand grows and with it waste and exploitation of natural resources. We are drowning in an ocean of electronic waste. Around 50 million tonnes of e-waste is generated globally per year with an average of more than 6 kilograms per person. In Europe, it is even 16 kilograms per person, and we cannot continue this way. Commissioner, I agree that the voluntary agreement is not enough. We expect three concrete actions to be undertaken. Firstly, the Commission has to show leadership and stop letting tech giants dictate standards. If digital sovereignty really means something to this new Commission, we expect a proposal to establish a standard of a common charger – wireless or not – within the next six months. Secondly, having the possibility to use the same common charger for multiple devices, the consumer should not be forced to pay additional charges when buying new devices. Thirdly, the Commission should propose quality standards for treating e-waste and help Member States to reach e-waste collection targets. Commissioner, this charger is very small, but the issue is big and very important for the environment and for European citizens.

name: Christel Schaldemose
text: for the S&D Group. Madam President! Commissioner, I praised you in the last speech, but I will not do so this time. It is simply too bad that the European Commission has not succeeded in ensuring that we solve the problem of having a harmonised EU charger that can be used for all phones.  We've been talking about this for years. So now is the time for us to resolve it. Fix it. Get it fixed as soon as possible. If this little problem takes so long, how are we even going to be able to ensure that we make our circular economy work? We need to solve it for the sake of consumers and for the sake of the environment.  I know that you have tried to do this through voluntary schemes, but frankly: voluntary schemes in such a field, it does not work. I think it is time for you to take the spoon in the other hand and make sure that we come up with a binding legislative proposal that ensures that we solve this problem and have a common charger for all mobile phones.

name: Liesje Schreinemacher
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, I am often asked what Europe actually does for us, what Europe means. These are sometimes large, life-size abstract things, such as ensuring our freedom and security, or creating a single market for 500 million people. But sometimes it also lies in something as practical and simple as one uniform charger, the so-called common charger. A single general charger for all mobile phones, cameras and tablets means less cost, less waste and more user convenience for consumers. We no longer need a separate charger for each device, which we then throw away when we buy a new phone from a different brand.  This dossier has been going on for a decade now, so it is high time. Although some manufacturers still claim that you can't compare apples with pears, I don't think this needs to be that complicated. For example, manufacturers have already made great strides and we have gone from 30 different chargers to three different types of chargers over the past decade. That's good, but we're not there yet. It seems that something more is needed than just encouragement. For example, the current legislation is still based on a voluntary basis for manufacturers, whereas now you can see that this is not working enough in the end. In addition, of course, there must also be room for the development of new applications.  I would therefore ask the Commission to come up with a plan for a single universal charger, one charger that is good for consumers, which reduces waste and leaves room for innovation.

name: David Cormand
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, at our Commission hearing in November, we denounced the lack of concrete progress for a common charger. While we were calling for swift action, the Commission has taken refuge behind impact assessments that should have already been published. Since then, it's been radio silence. What's the reason? The study in question has been completed since October and was even presented to a group of experts in December, yet it remains inaccessible to this day.  For the past ten years, the Commission has been relying on the goodwill of the industry, with the lack of results that we know, and lobbies are rubbing their hands. That's enough! It is not acceptable for European citizens that a measure to combat waste, pollution and programmed obsolescence should thus be blocked. That's enough! We call on the Commission to present an adequate delegated act as soon as possible or for a legislative procedure to be restarted. While we pride ourselves on a Europe of the Green Pact, it is time to keep the simple promise made ten years ago, that of a universal charger.

name: Virginie Joron
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the universal charger for phones and tablets, it has been in the pipes of Brussels for ten years. For the citizens watching us, the fact that we are having a debate tonight is incomprehensible. The Brussels Commission was supposed to have settled the matter. I have with me here the statement of your services from 2009: 'The Commission welcomes the commitment of the industry to provide a universal charger for mobile phones'. Finally, congratulations a little too hasty. Indeed, if I want to charge my phone with cables of other brands, this is still not possible. The Commission often interferes with our plates, in our speed limits or in our pension systems, but in cases where it might make itself useful it is useless or even inactive. I'm sorry, but we can't continue to be pressured by Apple, which spends more than two million euros on lobbying a year. In 2010, you could have imposed Nokia plugs, which was by far the world's leading manufacturer of mobile phones. Instead, you have authorized Microsoft to buy back and close these businesses. Give this file to Greta Thunberg or any of our 16 million unemployed, it may go faster.

name: Andżelika Anna Możdżanowska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Ten years of such a trivial subject, but so extremely important for the citizens of the European Union, is a shame for our work, for the work of the European Commission. The universal charger is no longer just about facilitating the daily lives of European Union citizens, but also about the expectations of users and consumers and our shared responsibility to the environment. At the moment, consumers are obliged to purchase a new charger when purchasing each new device. The introduction of a regulation to address this issue introduces convenience for the user, but most importantly it will reduce waste in the form of electronic devices, which are estimated to account for 51 000 tonnes per year in the European Union. The implementation of the common charger requirements requires in-depth analysis, taking into account interoperability as a key to the development of the Digital Single Market, the Circular Economy Strategy, the Energy Union and natural technological change for the benefit of industry and consumers. This solution should also take into account the latest trend of abandoning traditional chargers in favour of wireless chargers, which will significantly reduce the environmental footprint and increase the safety of users, such as drivers and passengers. Today, this means looking at and working with manufacturers of chargers and portable radio equipment.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I know that this one minute is far too short to be able to say something sensible, but please do not leave it to the interpreters, they will not come along any more.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Madam President, Vice-President of the Commission, we all certainly have a place in our housing where there are a significant number of old and no longer needed chargers. It was previous practice that what the producer did, the specific type. This was, of course, very unpleasant for consumers and created unnecessary and unethical pressure on further production. With the great support of the European Parliament, in 2014 the EU agreed that mobile phones made for the European market should have a universal charger. At that time, the Commission was encouraged to put this directive to life as part of a delegated act. However, the Commission is not. The Commission is afraid. I don't know if he's afraid of off Apple, which will upset the US, which will lead to more customs conflicts, or if the Commission is simply afraid to enforce what it has agreed to want and enforce. Yes, the previous Commission had strong tendencies towards spinelessness, but what about the new Commission? Will it also be afraid, or will it promote a clear and understandable, environmentally friendly, sovereign European consumer policy for citizens? I personally hope that it will promote what the EU and, in particular, the European Parliament have been calling for for a long time. Otherwise, we can hand over the governance of Europe directly to multinational corporations. Talk will not help, this act would be very simple, it could prove that we are following our objectives and let us all press the Commission to finally do so.

name: Antonius Manders (PPE).
text: Mr President, it is good that we are talking about the common charger. In 2009, I tabled that amendment in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. In 2009 I proposed this, and in the trialogue, the Council, the Commission and Parliament agreed. Ten years later, there is still no common charger.  It is very good that we stress that it is about waste reduction, but what really disappoints me is that people's dependence on mobile phones is not mentioned. Citizens of Europe will now be dependent on mobile phones for their safety, for their social contacts. It's a shame no one's naming that.  Today I drove from the Netherlands to Strasbourg, and then I drive through the Ardennes and I no longer see public phones. My battery was dead. If I'd been unlucky, I wouldn't have been able to call anyone, and I'd be standing there, hoping someone would come and save me.  Phones are vital for people right now. 50PLUS considers it very important that telephone chargers also become universal and we call on the Commission to impose a common charger for everyone and for everyone to continue using these phones as we do now.

name: Alex Agius Saliba (S&D).
text: – Madam President, having different chargers for mobile phones and devices is, first and foremost, a business that brings millions in profits. Companies today are not only producing different chargers for different versions of their phones, but on top of that, some of them are now shipping their new models with a slower charger and, of course, a second, faster one is available for an additional price. Secondly, this is hugely detrimental to the environment. We have more than 51 000 tons of electronic waste per year coming from chargers. Thirdly, this is extremely inconvenient for people, who either have to pay for a charger they do not need, or if they need one, it is because none of the chargers they have at home fit. Enough is enough. Ten years of inadequate and insufficient self-regulation is evidence that a European universal charger for smartphones is a must. We want to promote European standards, European companies, and the European way of life. Well, this is our opportunity. The Commission is long overdue on this and must act immediately.

name: Dita Charanzová (Renew).
text: – Madam President, the Renew Group supports the use of delegated acts by the Commission towards required common standards for charging ports and device cables. The voluntary approach failed to deliver, and memoranda of understanding are only of value when they are fully implemented by all market players. That said, I believe the best short solution is not, in fact, a common charger itself, but to require new phones and chargers to be sold separately, and not only as a single bundle. While all devices would come with a power cable, consumers would not be forced to buy the charging block, which they may not need or want. This would allow consumers to get a better deal and to cut waste at the same time. So let’s cut waste, but let’s protect in a way to show why we do so.

name: Petra De Sutter (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, who else knows this problem? Over the years, we have all accumulated a bunch of different mobile chargers, and that’s not only because we switched brands. Often newer models of the same brand also came with a different charger. What is the result? More than 51 000 tonnes of so—called e-waste per year, according to the Commission estimates. The environment does not benefit from this. When we forget our charger, only people that have the same mobile phone can help us out so the consumer does not benefit from this either. Only the industry does, some companies more than others, as we all know, because the larger part of the industry is moving towards USB C, but some stubborn pupils in the classroom keep on refusing. We cannot let the interests of private profit overrule the interests of our people and the planet. When what is good for the consumer coincides with what is good for the environment, we need to seize that opportunity. In conclusion, Commissioner, please come forward with a sustainable solution as fast as possible. We have already lost too much time.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, the good thing is that we have a socket that hangs on the wall, where all these different plugs, which Mrs De Sutter has shown, fit in. That's a big advantage. It shows that standardisation in Europe has taken a major step forward for citizens and consumers. With regard to the GSM standard for mobile phones, a uniform standard in Europe ensured that we had much cheaper prices. In other words, standardisation can, unbelievably, actually have a cost impact on citizens, and we should stick to that.  However, I would also like to say to all the Members who are opting for the introduction of a single plug here tomorrow, so to speak: we have a market economy in Europe, and that is why we must be careful when using such methods, because we want to ensure that innovation retains an opportunity. But I believe that, after ten years, all the companies that are still sticking to buying their own separate plug – and the Liberal colleague has pointed out that we have come down from 30 to three, in other words, the European Commission's incentives have had a positive effect – well justify why separate plugs are possible. And there is no longer any excuse for the wireless devices. The Commission must act on this immediately.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: – Dear Chairman, each of us has several chargers at home that we never use. We've already thrown a few of them away, but there's still a new one on the drawers. 51,000 tons of chargers are thrown into the environment every year. The Commission's voluntary measures to standardise chargers have no results. Electronic waste in the European Union continues to grow at five percent a year. It is necessary to introduce the same charger for all small devices. It is estimated that consumers will save more than half a billion euros by 2021. I want to emphasize that standardization of chargers should be just one small step towards more sustainable consumption. As many as 78% of consumers had to replace their mobile phone for reasons that could easily have been solved at the product design stage. I think the Commission has had more than enough time to consider high-quality solutions and charger models. It is time for the new Commission to show that citizens' interests are ahead of those of industry!

name: Maria da Graça Carvalho (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the issue of the common charger is of the utmost importance, not only for the lives of consumers, who are obliged to buy a panoply of chargers for each device, but also for environmental reasons. The current situation produces a huge volume of completely unnecessary electronic waste which is estimated to amount to about 50,000 tonnes of obsolete loaders per year.  The European Parliament has stressed several times in the past the need to develop a common charger. The committee's approach that encouraged voluntary agreements between large producers did not produce satisfactory results. We need political will to solve this problem, which involves binding regulation, with concrete targets and objectives for the entire European internal market.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her When I listened to you, Commissioner, All I could do was shake my head. Because what you told us today, I heard nine years ago, ten years ago, eleven years ago. And what has happened? Nothing. Because, ladies and gentlemen, who claim that we only have three different chargers, I look into the store and see much more. Because it is not just about mobile phones, it is about the tablets, about the small cameras, that is, about a large number of different chargers that we have, but which we should not hang on to, but where we really should have uniformity. We have seen very well that a voluntary commitment by companies is not enough, that is of no use. After eleven or twelve years, we are still waiting for these solutions to come. No, not a commitment, but action, Commissioner! Action is what we need and what we as a Parliament want to put in place at last.

name: Edina Tóth (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. For more than 10 years, the initiative to unify mobile chargers has been on the agenda, which has not produced any results to date. I welcome the fact that we are already debating this very important subject in the first plenary session of the year, which is in the interests of consumers and the environment. I believe that consumers' costs would be reduced if the single charger were to fit not only mobile phones, but also tablets, e-book readers and other portable devices. I also think it is important that consumers are free to decide whether to buy a new charger for the new device. This can only be achieved if the combined sale of the device and the charger ceases at the same time as the introduction of the single charger. Finally, I would like to point out that the new provision would also be beneficial for the environment, as it would also significantly reduce the amount of electrical waste.

name: Pablo Arias Echeverría (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, 51 000 tonnes of electronic waste per year generated by the accumulation of mobile terminal loaders, with their consequent environmental footprint. The absence of a single charger also directly affects European citizens and their free movement. When traveling, they are forced to carry different chargers, which undoubtedly limits their mobility. We call on the Commission to present legislative initiatives that will put an end to the wide range of chargers that currently exist. The European Union , as has already been said here, has been advocating for a single charger for mobile terminals for more than ten years, and we have not yet succeeded. We must simplify, simplify, and we must make life easier for European citizens and businesses. The adoption of a single charger will undoubtedly simplify the work of our SMEs, making it easier for them to comply with more efficient legislation. It will also facilitate the lives of consumers and waste management, allowing more rational use of chargers and reducing their number. If the great priorities of this Commission, of this new Commission, are digitisation and the Green Pact, the single charger represents a unique opportunity to bring the European Union closer to its citizens and demonstrate its usefulness.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the introduction of uniform recharging devices can be another example of how the European Union is helping to improve the life and comfort of our citizens. All of us have certainly encountered the fact that you couldn't charge your device because he didn't have an adapter to fit on it. In the recent past it was even much worse, because it was true that what the manufacturer, or even what model of the product, it is a different kind of charging device. In addition to the obvious discomfort to citizens, this has meant, and still means, thousands of tonnes of unnecessary waste. The vast majority of manufacturers have already shown that they have no problem adapting to the micro USB standard and equip almost all devices with it. However, it is still some strong players who reject this, although there are no obvious technical obstacles. The introduction of uniform recharging devices should be another example of regulation that does not restrict but helps the freedom of movement of citizens, goods and services. Increases safety and saves resources. We therefore need to implement it as soon as possible.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we all agree and the Commission has said so. Up to ninety-five million euros of consumer benefits, a positive environmental impact, but also benefits for both the single market – undisputed – and for the increased competitiveness of our small, medium and large enterprises. Why doesn't it happen? Why have we been like this for ten years? We have suppressed roaming, made and made a number of decisions about job locking, portability, etc., very important. 2020 for these European institutions is a magical year. A lot of things have to happen in 2020 for us to effectively give an answer to what we have promised. We're going to make the unique charger a reality in this 2020.  Let it happen. The Commission has the European Parliament.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I have seven requests for the spontaneous speeches and I would like to take them all in the interests of a lively debate. But this works because we are already late, only if you really strictly adhere to the one minute. So after a minute, I'm really going to cut. Please adjust to this. Spontaneous speeches

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – Honourable Chair. The debate over a single charger is proof that we can listen to people in quite concrete matters. But things, of course, drag on too long. If we have been discussing the charger for 10 years, people rightly accuse us of being ineffective and that we are under the influence of multinationals, who are, of course, not in their interest to see these changes. Introducing a single charger would make life easier for people and, of course, businesses. However, since as many as 51 000 tonnes of chargers are dumped, the introduction of a single model would also have a very positive impact on our environment. Standardisation of chargers, however, could bring significant financial savings for both ordinary consumers and businesses. I hope, of course, that this idea, this initiative, will get an epilogue as soon as possible and that we will prove to all the people of the EU that we can be effective and independent.

name: Adriana Maldonado López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, it is often blamed on the European Union that we do not usually provide solutions to citizens immediately, that we usually act late. And it's true. This Directive, adopted in 2014, is a clear example that will is sometimes not the best way to achieve the objective we want to achieve. It is not normal that, in 2020 and digital sovereignty is one of the great challenges that this next and already current European Commission has, is one of the issues that we have to deal with in this new legislature. Because it is true that in our homes – and many of my colleagues said it – we have a large number of chargers that we no longer use. But also on an important issue, and young people have set a good example for us with climate change measures. We can't afford to keep buying a charger for each electronic device, and we're not just talking about mobiles. We're talking about watches, we're talking about cameras. We're talking about many types of electronic devices that we need you to renew. We need a universal single charger and we also need the cables to stop being effective. (The president withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Vlad-Marius Botoş (Renew).
text: – Madam President, a few years ago, we took a step forward with this project to standardise mobile phone chargers - a project that has proved beneficial to consumers. Commissioner, standardisation of chargers for all mobile electronic equipment will be a new step in favour of the European consumer. We must, however, ensure that the next steps, pending implementation, are taken as quickly as possible, so that Europeans benefit from these regulations as soon as possible. We must not lose sight of the objectives taken by the European Union through the Green Deal and we must ensure that, in addition to standardisation, we also require compliance with environmentally oriented production technologies, an extended warranty period and clear recycling arrangements, so that the carbon footprint of the final product is as small as possible. These provisions must be complied with both by chargers produced here in the European Union and by products imported into the Territory of the Union.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the problem is not just about mobile phone chargers. In several commonly used products, characteristics which cause, on the one hand, their incompatibility with products of other brands and, on the other hand, their obsolescence on a date prior to that which the technology and materials available would achieve are introduced by the manufacturer. The costs of this incompatibility, and especially the costs of this programmed obsolescence, are enormous for consumers and for nature. Any strategy to combat climate change, and any strategy to reduce the impact of human activities on nature, must respond consistently to this problem. Product design and disassembly rules are required that, in addition to ensuring compatibility where justified, allow the purchase and replacement of components and parts in addition to software and hardware updates.  A extended mandatory minimum guarantee is also required.  Is the European Commission available for these measures?

name: Maria Manuel Leitão Marques (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I think you may have heard here that we have a consensus in this Parliament on this measure. We're uneasy about the delay she's had. It is an important measure for consumers, as roaming has been in the past, and we need measures in the European Union that touch people's lives. At a time when the two biggest challenges we face are the digital and environmental transition, and we have talked about it today, we cannot wait any longer for this Commission initiative that so clearly serves consumers and environments. So whether it is a measure implemented by regulation or standardisation, or even both to give the necessary flexibility for innovation, which cannot happen, Commissioner, as you have heard here today, is to wait another ten years for a universal shipper, blocked by one company with the possible complicity of the others.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I will go back to what the speaker said here, and I will turn to the Vice-President of the Commission again, because he hears the appeal from left to right that we really do not want to wait another ten years and in ten years we will talk again about a common charger. I think that what may have been a problem in 2014 is no longer just a question of consumer comfort, but it is really the unnecessary waste, the thousands of tonnes of electrical waste that is multiplying.  And if we are serious about the European Green Deal, then when other than now to say that this is the right innovation, the green innovation. If anyone is afraid that a common charger could reduce the chances of new innovations, that is nonsense. A common charger should be the best innovation.

name: Leszek Miller (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. We look forward to working vigorously towards the introduction of a universal charger. Unfortunately, this necessary idea has a very long, ten-year history. We expect it to be implemented not only for ecological reasons, but also because it will allow real savings in the pocket of every user. In so far, the Commission should not succumb to the arguments of large corporations that the unification of chargers will hamper technological developments in this area or other excuses. I believe that the very high prices that come to us to pay for more and more newer models of mobile equipment are enough to tell manufacturers: enough dodging in this regard. And the Commission has our strong support.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to say that I heard everyone loud and clear. Very rarely do you have an almost unanimous opinion in the debate as you (the Members) demonstrated this afternoon, and I share your view that despite the efforts of the Commission to foster greater harmonisation and to push for sustainable products, in this case, it didn’t work as we expected. I would really like to underline the fact that the lack of progress was not because of any fear of any company in the world, but we’ll be looking for the best way in which to proceed further.  After listening to your debate, I would like to assure you that for the Commission, consumer convenience, reduction of electronic waste, safety and interoperability will very clearly be our guiding principles. At the same time, I would join your call to industry for it to do its utmost to accelerate innovation, bringing new, more performing products to the market for the benefit of consumers and for the benefit of our environment. We also have to acknowledge the fact that the voluntary approach in this case did not meet your expectations and it did not meet consumer or our own Commissions expectations. I agree with all those Members of the European Parliament who have been very clear on this, starting with Ms Thun und Hohenstein and Ms Schaldemose, but I would say almost every Member of the European Parliament who intervened in this debate. I would like to repeat the message to the industry that its’s never too late to come up with suitable proposals, but in this case, after so many years, we have to consider the legislative approach. The Radio Equipment Directive is one option to take a certain type of regulatory measures, but we also intend to analyse other options, including through the ordinary legislative procedure, to ascertain whether a superior cost/benefit outcome could be achieved by pursuing them.  I agree with all the Members of the European Parliament who highlighted the crucial importance of digital sovereignty of Europe. I think we see every single day how important this issue is becoming. I also have to add one important element – and the lesson from this approach would be crucial for my work which I pursue on the European Battery Alliance – because I think that after today’s debate, we can clearly conclude that the sooner we have higher European standards, not only for chargers but also for batteries, the better it would be.  This is how we can push our approach to the modernisation of the industry. This is how we can demonstrate our commitment to the sustainability of our products, and this is what we are going to do. Thank you very much for your very clear message, with which we will be working very actively in the Commission, and of course I hope that we can count on your support for this way forward and the proposals we will put on the table before this House.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
