text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at a later part-session. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Andrus Ansip (Renew)
text: Writing. – I support a single charger system for portable devices. However, I would also like to draw attention to car chargers. The shortcut between Brussels and Strasbourg lacks high-speed electric car chargers, and the European Parliament's 11 electric cars must therefore travel through Germany. In doing so, they must draw up an exit plan so that not everyone reaches the loading point at the same time. In the context of the European Green Agreement, it is certainly neither smart nor sensible.

name: Ivars Ijabs (Renew)
text: Writing. – Ten years ago, the European Commission began work on rules for the development of a single charger for all portable devices. Unfortunately, the original Commission proposal for electric equipment manufacturers to agree on a common standard themselves did not achieve their objective, forcing EU legislators to look for other solutions to protect citizens' interests. The European Parliament has re-debated this issue in its interest in mitigating the economic and climate consequences and standing up for consumers' interests. I ask the European Commission to come up with a common framework for a single device charger.

name: Pierre Karleskind (Renew)
text: In writing. The European Commission has been working on the issue of the universal charger for mobile devices for more than ten years now. It is certainly to be welcomed that the Commission's approach of passing through voluntary industry agreements has reduced the number of charger models from thirty to three since 2009. But don't stop halfway. Every year, 51,000 tons of chargers end up in the trash... or in the wild. Moreover, do we not all have a drawer at home filled with different chargers that are neither used nor recycled? The Commission must now act to extend the principle to all small and medium-sized electronic devices (tablets, readers, cameras, cameras, etc.), without restricting the innovation and emergence of tomorrow's chargers. In addition, the Commission will have a real impact on e-waste by ensuring that chargers are sold separately from their devices, to allow consumers to continue to use their old chargers. We call on the European Commission to take concrete steps in this direction in the coming months.

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D)
text: in writing. – We have been talking in the EU about one common standard for chargers for all mobile devices for over a decade now. The voluntary agreement adopted by producers of electronic equipment back in 2009 has proven insufficient, with tech giants like Apple applying their own standards in this area. What is more, Europeans have been facing a situation in which they are forced to acquire different chargers for the different electronic devices they use. What is more, they are forced to buy a charger with every new item of equipment, even if they already have one which is compatible with that equipment. And that means higher prices. Additionally, different standards for chargers result in the pile of electronic waste growing – currently it is 16 kilograms per year for each European. For the sake of consumer rights as well as out of ecological concerns we cannot tolerate this situation any longer. It is time the European Commission proposed a standard for a common charger, which would be obligatory for all producers of electronic devices. Consumers must also be given the right to purchase new electronic devices without chargers if they wish so.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on income disparities between women and men (2019/2870 (RSP)).

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank honourable Members for including the gender pay gap on today’s agenda. I am aware that this is an important matter for the European Parliament, as reflected in its resolutions calling for legal actions that tackle gender-based pay discrimination. We are on exactly the same page on this. Pay discrimination has gone on for too long. The principle of equal pay has been in the Treaty since 1957, but women are still being paid an average of 16% less than men in Europe. It is high time for further action. President von der Leyen has entrusted me with the task to develop a new European gender equality strategy to address areas in which women still face additional barriers. I will give equality in the world of work its due attention by putting forward proposals for pay transparency. The Commission envisages presenting a new gender equality strategy in the first week of March. The aim is to have a strong ambitious and overarching approach, with specific measures to close the gender pay gap. Equal pay will be a key principle of the new strategy, and the Commission will act as regards measures on pay transparency. We have had a non-binding recommendation for five years now, which gave Member States a toolbox of measures to enforce the equal-pay principle. Some Member States have introduced the measures, but many have not. Because there is a lack of transparency, many women do not even know that they are being underpaid. Work typically done by women is systematically and structurally underpaid compared to work typically done by men, even when it is work of equal value. This is why transparency is such an important issue. I will be looking at a broad range of options when working on the scope of the pay transparency proposals, from giving employees information on pay levels to requiring companies to report on pay levels and analyse such data in audits. I am aware that introducing binding pay transparency measures is challenging. While we want to strengthen the rights of employees to get more information about pay levels, we also need to recognise that some of the possible measures may add administrative burdens for employers. It is therefore imperative to consult employers, employees and national administrations to find the right balance for such EU intervention. Let’s also not forget that increasing pay transparency is only one of the steps towards addressing the gender pay gap. Closing this gap requires a comprehensive approach addressing all its root causes: a lower participation of women in the labour market; a higher use of part-time and career breaks by women when compared to men; vertical and horizontal segregation on the labour market; and gender stereotypes and discrimination. Another thing. Women are over-represented in work of precarious nature. They are the vast majority of part-time workers and often opt for variable hours and temporary contracts. This is another factor which significantly reinforces gender gaps. In in this regard, the Commission will work closely with Member States to ensure that binding legal acts are properly implemented, and to assist Member States in taking utmost advantage of other legal provisions. This includes the recommendation on access to social protection, the Directive on Part-Time Work, the Directive on Transparent and Predictable Working Conditions, and, of course, the Work-Life Balance Directive. I intend to work closely with the European Parliament throughout this process and I look forward to listening to your views today.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I would also like to point out here that the clock has been running backwards since today. But one thing remains the same: when it turns red, time is up.

name: Frances Fitzgerald
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I want to welcome what the Commissioner had to say here this evening. I’m glad we’re all on the same page – because we need to be if we are to get action in relation to this issue. If we are serious about gender equality here in the European Union, if we are serious, for example, about the sustainable development goals (SDGs), if we are serious about the European social pillar, then it is essential that we tackle the gender pay gap. Equality matters, and this is a very serious inequality that has lasted for far too long. Economic equality is critically important because without equality in earnings, in what people live on throughout their lives, social equality cannot be guaranteed. You have described the pay gap that exists: the 16%, and more in some places. Of course, we also have the pension pay gap, which is very, very serious. The current gender pension gap in Europe stands at over double the gender pay gap – at 35.7%. Just think of the implications of that for individual women, for children and for their families as they grow older. They just do not have access to the same money to live their lives. The consequences of both the gender pay gap and the pension pay gap are very serious. They cost our society. They cost because they perpetuate child poverty, they perpetuate skills shortages, and of course, there is an enormous cost to the economies of all our countries because they are underusing women’s skills, and there is a serious barrier here to women’s full participation. We know all this. The question is: what we are going to do about it? What we see already is quite a number of countries taking action. I welcome what you say about the variety of issues that can be dealt with if we take this seriously. Pay transparency is critical. We’ve seen already the impact of greater transparency, for example, when it has been seen in media jobs recently. We’ve got to have very strong implementation measures to make sure that this issue is dealt with.

name: Evelyn Regner
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. There is this sad anniversary, which highlights the glaring pay gap between women and men in the European Union: Equal Pay Day, which we all know. There is nothing to celebrate. This day marks the large pay gap between women and their male counterparts. Although the principle of equal pay for equal work or equal work of equal value has always been enshrined in the EU Treaties, although article 4 explicitly prohibits direct and indirect discrimination in pay, women still earn 16% less per hour than their male counterparts in 2019. The situation is even worse in old age, as women receive on average 40% less pension, less pension than men. Mothers with children under the age of seven have the worst at all: two-thirds of the pay gap is classic discrimination. Woman gets paid less just because she is a woman. The pay gap is based, among other things, on persistent stereotypes about the role of women, who still do most of the housework and child-rearing. What is needed is a rethink, a break-up of the existing power and thought structures if we want real equality and fair pay. That is why I am addressing the Commission: we need more than we have had up to now: real legislative measures on wage transparency, sanctions for discrimination and proper compensation for those affected. That is what we expect from the Commission, as a lawyer for men and women.

name: Sylvie Brunet
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, my fight is for equality. Eliminating the wage gap also means combating women's poverty and social exclusion. The gender pay gap is socially and economically intolerable. Socially, because it contravenes the principle of equality - as you have pointed out, of non-discrimination - enshrined in the European treaties. Economically, because it is part of growth and innovation that suffers from these gaps. It is estimated that by reducing the gender pay gap by an additional two percentage points, we could increase the EU's GDP by more than 40 billion a year. Equality is also at the heart of the inspiration for the European social rights base, which we are committed to putting fully into practice. The time has come to update the European Union's action plan on this issue by working around three axes. First, the transparency of remuneration information, which needs to be improved. Second, obligations of results, remedial measures and, third, support measures for the organization. Through the obligation to pay transparency and the implementation of audit measures, we will have accurate, objective and large-scale data that will enable us to better define the contours of these possible discriminations and also to measure progress. I am pleased that the Commission has resolutely embarked on this transparency, which is part of the obligations resulting from the 2014 directive on extra-financial information. On the second axis, the Commission, Member States and social partners - social dialogue is important - will need to have more relevant measures, as a prevention of binding remedial measures. Finally, let us not forget to act on the broader context of the organization of our labour markets in terms of stereotypes, orientation, training, education. Commissioner, we look forward to the new gender equality strategy and see a new modality of the principle of 'equal work, equal pay' applied.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: A particularly warm welcome to the six men who will be speaking in this debate.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, it is not very normal for us to be so few. I want to start by saying this. In any case, thank you, Commissioner, for what you presented here today. We are really hopeful that we will be able to work the fight against the pay gap in an important way. This is affecting a lot of women, given the 16% gap we have. We must not forget that this then has other consequences: the pension gap, which is at 35%, which is a direct consequence of the wage gap we have. And, therefore, I think there are two things about what he has said that are very important to me. First, we have had a specific own strategy, a specific action plan to combat the wage gap, which has done little work. I believe that, in the context of the review of the strategy, it must be updated, with clear indicators, in order to be able to deal with the phenomenon. And then, of course, we are very anxiously awaiting the new Directive on wage transparency, which you have already presented. I liked the content of what you mentioned: the fact that audits are mandatory, that employees can know and employees can know the gender pay scales. I think it is also very important that we have a regime of sanctions and the protection of victims of the significant pay gap in that legislative piece. With all this, I am convinced that you will be able to count on this Parliament. I believe that we can also learn a lot from the Icelandic experience, which has managed to reduce the pay gap by virtually zero with these measures. And finally, what I would recommend to you, or I think we have to do together, is to start working on an alliance in the Council. I do not want this legislative text to end as in the past other proposals, for example blocked. And for this we need to build alliances in the Council, and I take this opportunity to tell you that there is an excellent new Minister of Equality in the Government of Spain, Irene Montero, who I am sure will help you a lot to get all this forward.

name: Maximilian Krah
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for The gender pay gap is also one of the modern legends, and the less you ask specifically about it, the easier it is to get upset about it. There is an unadjusted and an adjusted pay gap. If we take the adjusted, the difference is between 2 and 7%, for the younger, the 20-30 year olds, even the other way round at the expense of men. If we look at the unadjusted gender pay gap, we have to say that the cause lies in the policy of the political left, which to this day does not manage to give attractive economic recognition to child-rearing times and motherhood and to start with the calculation of pensions, for example. We are seeing how conservatively governed countries such as Hungary, but also Poland, whose Minister for Family Affairs will shortly be speaking here, are going down the road where they take into account the very benefits that mothers provide when they take care of children, so that the unadjusted gender pay gap is falling, while precisely where women are seen only as economic farm animals and do not want to reward family benefits, it is just increasing, as in many Western European countries. In this respect, a new ideological attack by the Commission. It would be necessary to protect family work and motherhood in order to enhance women, and not to have such phantom debates.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Indeed, there is still a wage gap in the European Union between ladies and gentlemen, averaging around 16%. I am fortunate to come from a Polish where this wage gap is currently at 7% and is decreasing. As regards unemployment among ladies, they have been reduced from 18% to 5% in Poland. However, when we look globally at the issue of the gender pay gap, there is indeed much to be done. There are many reasons for the gender pay gap, but I am convinced that one of the main reasons is women's responsibility to look after their families. They raise children, take care of often old, sick parents. Ladies are therefore more likely to work part-time and in less profitable sectors. We should therefore consider how to compensate the ladies who act as mothers and carers of their ailing parents, precisely those differences in pay. I would like to emphasise one more thing, namely that, unfortunately, poverty is being feminisation. Ladies earn less and have pensions much lower than gentlemen.

name: Sandra Pereira
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, the gender pay gap is a reality at the age of work that worsens at retirement age. It will only be possible to put an end to inequalities by attacking their underlying causes with concrete measures such as the general increase in workers' incomes and the guarantee of equal pay between men and women, the enhancement of collective bargaining, the firm fight against precariousness and the regulation of working hours. In addition, it is necessary to provide protection in maternity, create public care networks for children and the elderly and demand concrete measures that provide public services with the necessary financial, technical and human resources to effectively intervene in preventing and combating discrimination and non-compliance with legislation. Finally, it is necessary to defend the existence of a public, universal and solidarity social security as the only guarantee of the right to a decent pension and a less unequal future.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Madam President, indeed, the principle of equal pay for men and women is a principle enshrined in the Treaties, in all the laws of the European Union. It is also part of the objectives of social development and is also part of the social pillar that we ourselves approve. The Commission's own president has set it a priority in this new equality strategy , even the Commissioner said , with binding measures so that we can actually eliminate this human rights attack which involves charging differently for work of equal value. It has been said here, it has lifelong consequences: fewer Social Security contributions, pension gap, risk of poverty, risk of violence, multiple causes, stereotypes. Women enter and leave the labour market, because there is the issue of motherhood, she works more part-time, she also has more temporary jobs. We must fight against the glass ceiling and that is why we propose , in line with what the Commissioner has said – greater wage transparency, combat professional segregation, have an agile and flexible labour market. And finally, to say that it will benefit everyone, because we will have more European values and more democracy.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: Mr President, when I started my first real job in 1987, I was overjoyed. We started with a group of men and women all at the same job. We did the same job for the same money. At least, That's what I thought, until we found out the men deserved more than me and my other female colleagues. We went to a lawyer who typed a neat letter to management, and fortunately there was no need for court intervention, but taking action against pay disparities works.  The wage differentials exist. They're not fairy tales, they're not a myth. Men still earn more than women, on average 5 000 euros per year in the Netherlands. This is possible and this has to be done differently. That is why I welcome the Commissioner's plan to introduce legislation on wage transparency within the first 100 days, so that we do not work until the year 2100 to eliminate the gender pay gap.

name: Radka Maxová (Renew).
text: – Madam President, the Czech Republic has the second largest average wage gap between working women and men. It's a staggering 21.1%. Although women are more educated in the Czech Republic, they prevalent in lower-wage workplaces. More often, they work in very important but lower-paid positions – education, health care, and social care. And they are underrepresented in management positions – 15% of women in the Czech Republic are on supervisory boards and 5% on boards. It is also very important to see the impact of the gender pay gap on the feminisation of poverty, where, in particular, pensioners or single mothers fall into poverty. The EU should promote equality between men and women, for example, by establishing a binding definition of 'equal pay for equal work' under the Equal Opportunities Directive 2006 or under the Directive on wage transparency and the enforcement of transparency in the disclosure of remuneration in European companies. Equality is not yet a matter of course.

name: Kira Marie Peter-Hansen (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President! Commissioner, thank you for the presentation. Last year we european women had our last working day on 4 November. European women should therefore, on average, have taken time off on 4 November and the rest of the year if we were to close the pay gap in 2019. This is equivalent to two months in which Women in Europe work for free. I hope that together we can turn this decade, which we have just entered, into the decade in which we put equality at the heart of it. That is why it is positive that we have had a Commissioner for Gender Equality. But great titles don't solve anything in themselves. I therefore hope that the Commission will help to create transparency about wages in the workplace. Female workers should have the right to know whether they should be paid less than their male colleagues doing the same job. I also hope that the Commission will keep an eye on the implementation of the Work/Life Balance Directive in the Member States. Indeed, there is no doubt that an unequal distribution of maternity leave contributes to the large pay gap that we are unfortunately seeing today.  I look forward to working together – and let us together ensure the same pay for the same work.

name: Isabella Tovaglieri (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the greatest theft in history, as it has been called by the United Nations, continues unpunished before our eyes: even today, women in the world earn on average 23 % less than men.  Europe is not doing enough. It is, in fact, an illiberal solution: Europe, instead of having to reduce freedom of enterprise, should instead support the Member States in removing the economic and cultural barriers that really prevent women from having access to the highest levels of work and pay. Passing the wrong and dangerous message that women are a category 'protected' by pink quotas really risks weakening, rather than strengthening, the bargaining power of women. On the contrary, the proper recognition of competences and merit will be the only possible solution for combining equal opportunities with equal dignity.

name: Elżbieta Rafalska (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab According to recent reports, the situation in Poland as regards the gender pay gap is good compared to other highly developed countries. It's getting better, changing and improving. Between 2000 and 2017 Poland made very good progress in improving the situation of women on the labour market. Polish position improved as it jumped from 19th to eighth place. So that according to Eurostat calculations this difference is small and in 2017 it was 7.2. At the same time, the European Union average was 16%. The lower level of this indicator was observed only in Romania, Italy, Luxembourg and Belgium. Let us remember, however, that the wage gap is a complex phenomenon and is due to the coexisting of many factors affecting the situation of women and men in the labour market. These include objective factors such as different education, professional experience and occupation. Let us also remember that women have the right to choose their way of life, family and career. But there is still a lot of work to be done in this area.

name: Eugenia Rodríguez Palop (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, in the European Union women work two months free a year compared to men, discounting the many who work without charging and in slavery conditions. We know very well why. Because it's the women we keep taking care of in an unpaid way at home and underpaid outside. Because social services have been cut. Because the care chain is neither the males nor the institutions. We know the measures we should take, but we don't take them. We didn't want to force large companies to undergo wage audits and pay penalties when they don't. We did not want to opt for parental leave that would prevent these companies from discriminating against women of childbearing age and forcing males to take care of their own children. Child education remains privatized in many states and is very expensive, expelling women from the market. We do not have a system of dependency care that is public, universal and free, so that informal care does not fall on them. We are killing women with doubles and triple days, while many of the lords grow like mushrooms in their cubicles, washes, hairstyles, ironings and reproduced. In Europe, many women work hard to remain poor, have less health coverage and age with minimum pensions. We still don't do enough.

name: Daniela Rondinelli (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, wage discrimination is one of the most widespread and abhorrent forms of social inequality, preventing women from participating fully in their country's economic and social growth. This discrimination has a lot to do with the cultures and stereotypes that characterise social models and labour market dynamics at national levels today. Commissioner Dalli, your proposal for transparency of salaries is acceptable but, as a 5-Star Movement, we ask you that the new proposal for a directive should not represent yet another list of statements of principle and good intentions, but should indicate solutions to the Member States in order to solve once and for all the problem of gender segregation in the various professions and sectors of activity. , segregation which is the main cause of the pay gap between men and women. We also need to start discussing a harmonised system of sanctions, which would punish those who blatantly violate the right to equal pay and those who deliberately exploit women's work to the detriment of justice and social cohesion.

name: Cindy Franssen (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the gender pay gap remains a persistent challenge. By 2020, women will still earn less than men, and inequality will become even more pronounced in retirement. This needs to be addressed urgently and a great deal has already been said, but I still want to focus on two things.  Women are more likely to have part-time jobs, which is automatically accompanied by lower wages. In this way, they find themselves in a vulnerable position and have a greater risk of poverty. Reducing the gender pay gap therefore presupposes the equal distribution of caring responsibilities and also presupposes equal participation in the labour market: equal pay for equal work. The full implementation of marianne Thyssen's work-life balance directive will therefore be crucial.  Secondly, segregation in the labour market must be eliminated, both vertically and horizontally. Breaking gender stereotypes and supporting women towards STEM sectors and the digital sector is the message.  Reducing the pay gap will make women stronger and more resilient.

name: Heléne Fritzon (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Thank you for a very good introduction, Commissioner Dalli. The principle of equal pay for equal work between men and women has been enshrined in the EU Treaties since 1957. But now we are here 63 years later, and women still earn less than men for the same work.  I think it is shameful that we have not gone any further. That we have not taken greater effort to make the same way, whether we are women or men. And it is, of course, shameful that we do not live up to europe's fundamental values of equality, and that we do not comply with the Treaty.  We have a task to fill. We know the explanations. But it is political will that allows us to change.  I wonder what you think I should tell my daughters? Is it reasonable for me to tell them that when you go out well educated in working life, you should earn and work for free two months compared to men? We need to change that.

name: Susana Solís Pérez (Renew).
text: – Madam President, today we are discussing an issue which should be settled: the gender pay gap. Because women charge 16% less than men, which is why we are asking the Commission for more ambition in equality. We need the Remuneration Equality Directive to be revised as soon as possible and to be taken to take action at European level to improve labour and family reconciliation. But one thing I'm particularly concerned about as an engineer is the impact of digitization on the pay gap. Many well-paid scientific and technological jobs will be demanded, and the percentage of women studying these areas is much lower than that of men by 17%, which will mean that this pay gap will widen further. We have to work so that girls and women are decanted by these kinds of studies and occupations. So we asked for ambition. There are many necessary measures; consider this a priority and introduce us as soon as possible to this strategy for gender equality

name: Alexandra Louise Rosenfield Phillips (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the economy is run by pickpockets. Every day, across the EU, women open their pay cheques to find that nearly a fifth of what they should be earning has been stolen from them – day after day, year after year, until they retire on a pension that is, on average, 35% less than their male counterparts. For women whose gender intersects with their race, migration status, religion, sexual orientation and/or disability, this wage disparity is even higher. ‘Equal pay for equal work’ is a slogan from the UK, where the Equal Pay Act became law in 1970. Yet here we are, 50 years later, and it is shameful that we are still having to stand up in Parliament Chambers and repeat it. If any of us saw someone lean over on a bus and take a banknote out of the pocket of the woman standing opposite, we’d shout out, we’d call the police, we’d be outraged. I call upon each and every Member of this House to shout out. Find your outrage. Women must not wait another 50 years.

name: Annika Bruna (ID).
text: Madam President, a man and a woman performing the same tasks and having the same skills must have the same salary. Equal pay for equal work: this simple principle must prevail and it is up to sovereign states to enforce it. The problem is that today Parliament is debating the concept of gender pay gap, that is, differences in pay between men and women explained by the hours worked, the experience or the position occupied. In many cases, however, these differences are a matter of women's choice and priorities. We must defend equal pay for equal work and allow women who wish to be able to access the same positions and salaries as men. However, some of the concepts defended here stem from an ideology denying the differences between men and women and an exclusively mercantile vision, the ultimate example of this drift being the freezing of eggs so that women shift their family life in favor of their professional constraints. Women also have the right not to want to be men like any other.

name: Jessica Stegrud (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his Thank you very much for the floor. According to the Commission's report, the difference in average income of 16% between women and men in the EU is mainly due to gender discrimination. In Sweden, which is one of the world's most equal countries, the responsible authority has stated that there is no indication in Sweden that the gender gap is due to discrimination, but mainly to factors such as career choice, position, personal characteristics and the number of hours worked.  The goal of an equal and free society can never be exactly the same outcome, for it would require totalitarian methods and disregard the individual's right to choose. Instead, it should be characterised by equal rights, obligations and the opportunity to make their own life choices.  Of course, I condemn the pay gap as a result of discrimination. But the work for equality must be based on facts and cleared of ideologically exaggerated myths.

name: Λευτέρης Νικολάου-Αλαβάνος (NI).
text: Madam President, the so-called policy of reconciling family and working life, 'equal opportunities', has led to the full flexibility of working time and the workplace for the female worker, resulting in one third of women in the European Union working part-time. Flexible working relationships are one of the factors responsible, for example, for the fact that the wage of a working woman in Greece is 17.5% lower than the salary of men, while in the European Union the average pay gap is up to 40%.  Modern women's rights at work are not guaranteed by equalising earnings for men and women downwards, as the European Union does; The determined struggle of workers against the aggression of the European Union, of urban governments, can breathe new life and strength into the working-class struggle for modern needs at work, in the social protection of motherhood and in leisure time.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Madam President, when Europe needs to renew its unity and look beyond the horizon, maintaining the gender pay gap is not only unjust to women, but also anachronistic. It insults women as full—fledged members of society. When the brightest women earn less than their male colleagues, it also reduces Europe’s chances in global competition. To make our labour market fit for the 21st century, we must get rid of the famous 16% differential. Also, the fact that today women are better educated does not mean that in the future the labour market will be more woman friendly. Girls are not encouraged by families, schools, universities or businesses to learn skills in new technologies. The pay gap can grow in the future. As a gender stereotype, the pay gap is a cost to the entire society. That is why I am convinced that this House will spare no effort to support the Commission action to ensure that the gender pay gap will be abolished entirely.

name: Elisabetta Gualmini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that to close the gender pay gap is not a symbol, but a way to restore social justice in our democracies. Not only is there the pay gap, but women are also victims of glass ceilings since they are not often promoted at the top level of their career. Women are victims of family duties and tasks since they are often the only caregiver in the house. Women are victims of gender bias and often not considered adequate enough. Women are also victims of violence, and more than 30% have experienced one form of violence in their lives. So this is the real fight, a fight for decency, for justice and for change. We have to fight for a day on which women will be fully equal to men, on which they will be fully aware of their value and their potential, and on which no more women will have to choose between a child and a job. So please let us close the pay gap as soon as possible within the next three months. You have to promise us: ‘you’re not alone, we are with you and we will never give up’.

name: Samira Rafaela (Renew).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that achieving financial equality between women and men is imperative. Being financially independent will make a person free, and too many women today are less free because of the gender pay gap, which stands at 16% in the EU and has barely changed over the last decade. At the current snail’s pace, we risk moving backwards and this will continue to harm women and it will cost the EU over EUR 200 billion in the next decade according to Parliament’s own research. If we are to be serious about our European values, the Commission must make freedom and independence for women its priority – from equal pay to active participation in an inclusive labour market. We need to go from minding the gap to understanding the gap to closing the gap, so large listed companies and governments must be transparent on how they pay their employees and we must know what is causing the gap.

name: Beata Szydło (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The topic we are debating today is one of the most important topics. This is a subject that, we can say, falls within what should be the foundation of the European Union: respect for equality of rights, equal rights, respect for everyone no matter where they live, what they do and in what part of our continent, in what part of the European Union. In Poland, we have been able to successfully put in place solutions that eliminate poverty and, on the other hand, as my colleagues from Polish have already said, also to tackle wage inequalities between men and women. Women want to work, they want to be active, but they also want to fulfil their role as mothers and want to have a chance to raise their children. That is why we have appreciated mothers who have raised at least four children and introduced special pensions for them.  On the other hand, finally, ladies and gentlemen, it is symptomatic that ladies are speaking above all in this debate today. I hope that we will effectively solve this problem for everyone here in Parliament.

name: Maria da Graça Carvalho (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I am pleased to see the European Commission presenting measures on pay transparency between men and women in the first 100 days of office. Although the principle of equal pay for equal work is enshrined in the Treaties, the reality is still quite different, with huge disparities between Member States. There remains a factor of discrimination between men and women, and even a throwback to the role of women in sectors of increasing importance in society, such as computer science and digital technologies. If nothing is done, we risk further restricting women's access to well-paid jobs. I ask the Commission to come forward with concrete and binding measures to tackle these problems and also to unblock the Women's Directive on the boards of listed companies.

name: Jackie Jones (S&D).
text: – Mr President, when I was a child in the 1970s, there was a raft of gender equality legislation that was passed at different levels. Over 40 years ago, we had the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW) passed. Fifty years ago in the UK, we had the equal pay legislation passed and, in the EU, after the Defrenne legislation and cases, we had lots of different directives that were passed. That was 50 years ago. Yet, still, there’s not a single country in the world that has equal pay for equal value. What’s going on? It’s pretty simple really: it’s discrimination. There’s not a single country in the EU that has equal pay. We’ve got to close this gap.  I’m getting old, and we’re leaving the EU. I had hoped that during my lifetime, we would see substantive equality and the advancement of women. CEDAW and its principles, as well as a revised Equal Pay Directive, should be part of the equal pay strategy. It should be part of a gender equality strategy in the EU.  I want to turn for one second, please, to the UK. As we leave the EU, I throw this gauntlet down to the Johnson Government: take back control. Well, let’s pass domestic legislation about equal pay right now. Let’s close the gender pay gap, let’s close the pension gap and let’s give the 50s women their pension back.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (Renew).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the Treaty of Rome denounced and began to combat the pay gap in order to settle another of the great bills of war. Women who joined the industry to replace dead men on the front line charged less, and that difference created problems in the market that wanted to be created. Today, in the knowledge economy, equality is also a matter of justice, but also of competitiveness. Equal pay is one more argument for attracting, stimulating and retaining talent we need; talent prisoner of prejudice, roles and inequality. That's why the pay gap is baited in women, but it impoverishes us all. Ursula von der Leyen has broken a glass roof. She is the first woman to chair the European Commission. I hope and trust that this momentum will allow the Union to be declared, at the end of its mandate, as a territory free of wage gap. It will be fair, but also a huge competitive advantage in the global world.

name: Andżelika Anna Możdżanowska (ECR).
text: – Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Today is an extremely important day, because regardless of gender, we are talking about tackling the wage gap that affects most countries, affecting women.  And this is the day when we speak with one voice, when all the arguments have sounded, when we can say that support instruments and systemic solutions are important, but it is also very important to work with entrepreneurs. I can also confirm this from my own experience as Deputy Minister of Investment and Development in the Polish Government, when we exchanged all the solutions with entrepreneurs on the creation of cooperation tools, when the government developed a free tool enabling employers Polish assess the scale of inequalities and allowing the application to estimate wages in a given industry, region and average wage in the European Union, when we laid the foundation for open solutions so that women could run their own business , we have been preparing systemic solutions so that they can reconcile family and working life. And I think that's the direction. But unfortunately we need to speed up in the European Parliament, because progress in the European Union is very slow. The gap has narrowed by just one percent in the past seven years.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, discrimination, or the gender pay gap, is simply prohibited, you have to be equally paid for equal work, and yet there is a difference of 16% on average. Even in some countries or more, in the Czech Republic almost 22%. The most common reason cited is the impact of motherhood and the caring role of women. I say that if we do not want motherhood and parenthood to be a path to poverty, then we must recognise the role of mothers and the role of parents, i.e. both the state and employers must take into account that these young parents are returning to work after their parental leave and must be given a new chance.  Here I would like to call on the Commissioner to really oversee the implementation of the work-life balance directive, because this is the start of this new approach, and I also share your call for better information and awareness-raising among women so that they can defend themselves and be able to assert themselves. The way is to appreciate motherhood, not discrimination.

name: Marc Angel (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, wage disparities, gender stereotypes, segregation in the labour market, all the inequalities that women experience on a daily basis. These inequalities are transgenerational and affect both girls and women in the labour market, they also affect retired women and contribute to female and child poverty. 16.3% wage gap and 39.6% overall income gap calculated on an annual basis: what contradiction with our treaties and what contradiction with the social Europe claimed in Gothenburg in 2017! Our policy responsibility is to react in this serious matter, and these inequalities are indeed the result of a societal structure based on the remnants of patriarchy still too often conveyed by populists and conservatives. We therefore need binding measures: the adoption of a directive guaranteeing transparency - I will support her as a socialist - the strengthening of the role of social partners and collective bargaining in the fight against social inequalities and finally the realisation of the European social rights base, including by introducing a European minimum wage.

name: Dace Melbārde (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it is deplorable not only that women in the EU earn nearly a fifth less than men, but also that the pay gap has increased by only one per cent over the last seven years. Whilst women in the EU are more highly educated than men, it is the latter that hold most of the senior positions in companies. Among other things, we need more gender balance in professions. Even in Western society, the share of women among STEM graduates is about twice as low as compared to countries such as Tunisia and the UAE. We need more women in IT, but we also need more men as teachers and culture workers, such as museum curators or librarians, which are mostly less well—paid occupations. Meanwhile, better general work-life balance can help in persuading more women to choose jobs that currently require long hours. When discussing the upcoming wave of automation, we as policymakers should keep in mind that female-dominated professions, such as secretaries, are as vulnerable to elimination as male—dominated industrial jobs. We must acknowledge that the gender pay gap is a multifaceted issue. And only by working together and approaching this issue holistically will we move towards solving this injustice.

name: Sunčana Glavak (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, Respected Commissioners, Colleagues and Colleagues, do you know that from 4 November 2019 women worked for free until the end of the year? It was on this November 4th that we marked the European Equal Pay Day, a date that symbolises the day when women across the European Union would stop earning the rest of the year compared to men.  At European Union level, we heard, 16%. The difference in my country, it's slightly lower, 13%. In other words, compared to men, women work about two months for free each year. In most countries, women are better educated than men, however, due to lower pay at the end of their working lives, there is a pension gap. As a result, women, after leaving the labour market, often face social exclusion, poverty and financial ally on their husband or partner. We also heard something about the glass ceiling. Women are not in positions where decisions are made or have so-called power.  Let me conclude with something that is likely to affect those who make important decisions as well. At issue are the results of a report by the McKinsey Global Institute that calculated that global GDP could increase by 1.2 trillion US dollars a year by 2025 if women were given equal opportunities.  And finally, I thank the male colleagues who discussed it. Five brave of the 32 applicants. Well, that's something!

name: Robert Biedroń (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The principle of equal pay between men and women has been in place since 1957. 63 years old women have to wait for this principle to work, and unfortunately they are still waiting. If we do not regulate accordingly, according to all studies, wage equality between men and women will be achieved in 257 years, in 2277. None of us will wait for this moment. Therefore, Commissioner, I would like to declare from here that many men in this assembly are as determined as you are here, who, together with you and with all the women who have spoken here today, want to knock down this one of the last glass ceilings that separate women from equality.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, women already have better education in Europe than men, yet women's wages are more than 16% lower than men's. What's that about? Women work more part-time, parental leave often accumulates for women, as do short-term jobs, career progression is weaker due to parental leave and simply women are often paid less for equal work.  It is very important that the European Commission is now increasingly tackling this problem and bringing legislation, then increasing wage transparency. But I think it is at least as important that we are able to distribute parental leave more evenly. The first quite good basis for directives has also been adopted. Similarly, it is also important to promote women's career development otherwise. Because the fact that women's pay is so much lower is reflected in women's whole lives. At present, pensions are also 36% lower for women than for men and such a difference is totally unacceptable.

name: Margarida Marques (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the Commissioner for her presentation here, and above all to say exactly what legislative initiatives the European Commission intends to take into practice. And we trust her mandate because it is not enough to have a Commissioner who is responsible for equal opportunities: it is essential that she has power within the Commission, on the one hand, and on the other hand has the ability to influence the other members of the College. But we expect a global strategy, and we especially hope that this global strategy will include several dimensions, including all dimensions. And I would like to remind you here that if it is a fact that there is a 16% gap in the gender pay gap, that gap, that gap, has a huge impact on women's future lives, because it has a huge impact on pensions.

name: Vlad-Marius Botoş (Renew).
text: – Mr President, equal pay for equal work: this is what we were thinking when we heard gender pay gap, but now it is more than that. The statistics are showing us that women are pushed towards the domains and towards the jobs that are paid less in the general economy. We encourage women to go to work, to have a career, but do we do enough to make sure that they have equality of choice? There are still educators in schools that are telling children that boys are more inclined for science and girls for literature and care. We still see the lack of equality in the educational process. We still see clothes that are telling girls they are delicate flowers and boys that they are heroes. We still see in our society, especially in the less developed ones, gender roles that are limiting both women and men. We have to take action. We have to do something to stop gender—based education and the way we are influencing children to choose a career. It is not enough to proclaim. It is time for real measures, real projects and real action.

name: Lina Gálvez Muñoz (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the pay gap is neither a legend nor an old nor modern, as has been said in this House a moment ago. It's a very serious problem. Not only a very serious problem of social justice, but also an economic problem because, above all, women are practically 60% of university graduates. It is true that action has been taken and that the gap has narrowed, albeit very slowly, especially over the past decade. And I also believe, Commissioner Dalli, that this directive, that this initiative on transparency is going to be very useful, but I do not think that is enough, especially in the middle of a digital revolution. Because right now the most demanded and highest paid jobs are precisely in the field of STEM, technological and, according to data from the European Institute for Gender Equality, since 2009 the presence of women in this area is shrinking and today it is 17%. We therefore need to take very concrete action in this area and tackle the problem in a very broad way. Therefore, my question goes in this line. What steps will be taken to narrow this gap?

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I consider the pay gap to be one of the biggest problems we have in the EU at the moment. I consider this to be a problem within individual countries, in the companies themselves and, last but not least, between the sexes. For example, being a single mother in the Czech Republic, where the gender pay gap is the second highest in the European Union, is extremely challenging and stressful. In particular, pay gaps can lead these women into poverty, either during working or, in particular, retirement age.  According to Eurostat statistics, women have to work more than two and a half months longer than men in order to achieve the same level of pay. There is no rational reason for the gender pay gap, but indeed no rational reason. If the European Parliament wants to fight for citizens' rights, it must clearly promote equal pay for equal work. I will always defend this principle.

name: Isabel Carvalhais (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, in the middle of the 19th century. XXI here we are discussing the persistence of gender pay inequalities. The causes are rooted in the way our societies operate, where conceptions persist about the division of family tasks, household chores, who are the main formal carers, and which lead to women ensuring a higher number of hours of unpaid work and conditioning their career choices. But upstream of all this is above all an ethical reading, or rather the lack of a true social awareness about the seriousness of this problem. There is a kind of collective complacency on this issue, as if there were always others in a list of priorities that are always outof moral relevance. And that's why, although 60% of the population with higher qualifications is female, women remain relegated from management and management positions. This is also the case in the agricultural world, where only 30% of farms in the European Union are run by women, often linked to low-paid tasks. Such disparities are aberrant and intolerable, which is why a comprehensive strategy, Commissioner, must have in the fight against gender stereotypes, developed from the outset within school citizenship education, one of the major long-term objectives against this form of structural violence.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am grateful for the dedication and support of the European Parliament for this discourse, so thank you all for your very valid interventions tonight.  This is a fact-based Commission. We act on facts. And the fact is that women are paid less than men, so may I add that it is also a fact that the Commission will act on this fact. I want to conclude by recalling that in addition to binding pay transparency measures and tackling the gender pay gap, as was mentioned here, there are other factors which contribute to women not being able to use their full potential and not being remunerated for what they are doing. So there is this new strategy on gender equality which will address other concomitant topics which were highlighted in the President’s political guidelines. We will work to combat and prevent violence against women, including online violence. We also know that there is a correlation between women’s financial independence and abuse and remaining in abusive relationships, so when we are talking about pay, as we did earlier, there are other consequences if this big issue is not addressed as it should be.  I also want to see gender balance on company boards and enhanced work-life balance for women and men. Again, this affects the quality of lives of women, of men, of our families. I want to see that we pay attention to the gender and broader equality perspective when addressing some of our society’s main challenges, such as climate change and digitalisation. The Commission will monitor the implementation of the work-life balance Directive in the Member States. We will promote take-up of the rights to family-related leave and flexible working arrangements, especially by men, and this will promote a more equal sharing of care responsibilities which is key to closing the gender pay gap. So, as you can see, it is all related and connected.  It is also about women achieving their full potential in the labour market, including their full economic potential. It will remove some of the incentives for women to self-select into lower-paying occupations and lower-paying roles within organisations. The strategy, in line with the commitments and the political guidelines of the new Commission, will also work on improving women’s positions in decision-making.  I will work hard with Member States to build a majority to unblock the Directive on women on boards. I count on the strong support of Parliament. Together we can make the gender pay gap history. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place at the january ii part-session.

name: Milan Brglez (S&D)
text: Writing. – Equal pay for equal work, including the prohibition of discrimination on grounds of sex, is a legally binding principle laid down in Article 157 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. At the same time, it is part of the European Pillar of Social Rights, on which all the key EU institutions agree.  Despite a number of commitments, the EU is not making progress in this area, as it has managed to reduce the gender pay gap by just 0.6% in recent years. On average, the differences are still 16% to the detriment of women, and in individual member states (both older western and newer eastern) even more than 20%.  The causes of the formation and persistence of these differences are multifaceted; from differences in sectors where women and men are typically employed, through related occupational and educational stereotypes, unequal work-life balance burdens, to direct discrimination on the part of employers.  We need a new EU gender equality strategy and a plan to implement it. At the same time, it is essential to look at this problem more broadly, because without structural changes in the European economy and the change in the attitude of countries and societies in the evaluation of individual forms of work and the importance of social inclusion, it is not possible to effectively eliminate pay inequalities. Gender equality and the principle of ensuring equal pay for equal work should also be included in the European Semester.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Dear Colleagues, Equal pay for the same work was a fundamental principle of the European Union in the 1957 Treaty of Rome. Article 157 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union ensures the application of the principle that men and women are paid equally for work of equal or equal value. In other words, in the case of performance wages, the remuneration for the same work is determined on the basis of the same unit of measurement or, in the case of a time wage, the same remuneration is paid in the same job. However, Member States are unable to fulfil their contractual obligations and we can therefore see a difference of up to 26% in some Member States in the pay gap between men and women for the same work. There is therefore a great need for the European Commission's efforts to place much greater emphasis on reducing wage dispar differences in the future by developing a new strategy. I hope that, in addition to the strategy, the Commission will make practical proposals so that the deterioration of the situation can be stopped throughout the European Union.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. – The EU must go beyond the declarations to implement the strategies that will lead to the full and practical implementation of equality between men and women because, as long as there is discrimination on grounds of sex, the Union cannot boast of the principles of equality and equality in its area. The fact that we are still discussing in the European Union the need to apply the equal pay of men and women is an insult both to the Union itself and to the European institutions, as well as to the Member States. The European Union must by definition be an area for safeguarding, promoting and promoting equal pay, equality, the abolition of all discrimination, equality and the defence of human rights. The European Parliament has pioneered and pioneered the full and unconditional implementation, at all levels, of equality between men and women. The issue of ensuring gender equality is a matter for all of us and a daily matter, and this fight must be held at every level until equality between men and women becomes an act and an experience for all.

name: Josianne Cutajar (S&D)
text: in writing. – When considering the positive leap made on issues of gender balance as a Union, significant legislation passed in the past that is currently in place is proving not to be effective enough today in ensuring that the pay discrepancy between genders decreases. Without effective pay transparency emanating from EU law, abusive employers will continue to act in defiance of the Equal Treatment in Employment Directive. The Gender Pay Gap however, is not only a legislative matter. The gap is real, and it means women do not only have lower hourly earnings, but they work fewer hours in paid jobs and have lower employment rates. This means that legislative change alone will do little without measures across the Union to ensure more flexible working arrangements so that they become worker-oriented; and family measures to balance out the disproportions in the hours men and women dedicate to care and household activities. I also urge the new Croatian Presidency of the Council to unblock the Women on Boards Directive as role models are essential to ensure that career progression and the attainment of decision-making jobs may legitimately fall within the realm of female aspirations.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – To kick-start the plenary debates in 2020 on the Gender Pay Gap augurs well for the EU’s commitment to deliver on this. Yet it is a stark reminder that in our societies women are still fighting for their right to earn what is deserved. We are making the case for why a person should be paid the same amount of money for the equal amount of work done by another, whatever their gender. On average, female workers are paid 16% less than men. Put simply, women work two months – out of 12 – for free. The situation is like this in most Member States, including Malta. I look forward to Commissioner Helena Dalli’s new gender strategy. We must tackle pay transparency – it will not be easy but we must keep pushing. Considering that most graduates are women, something is wrong. Women who deserve top managerial positions are side—lined. Not because of their competence, but due to chauvinism. Companies must be more progressive. Our laws need to be more progressive. If we treat women and men at par in family life and move away from stereotypes, companies will follow.

name: Laura Ferrara (NI)
text: in writing. Gender pay discrimination is a phenomenon in different sectors of the economy. In Europe, it is estimated that women are paid an average of 16% less than men, despite the fact that the TFEI enshrines the principle of equal pay. In this way, women pay the disadvantage of taking on important unpaid tasks, such as house work and the care of children or family members, in a greater proportion than men. The tendency to break careers and spend periods of time outside the labour market more often also has an impact on future earnings and pensions, which are about 40% lower than that of men. In the presentation of the new strategy for gender equality announced by the European Commission, I hope, in addition to declarations of principle, to provide for instruments that will have a significant impact on all the root causes of the pay gap.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Women in the European Union are still paid much less than men, even though they have the same competence and experience or hold the same position. I therefore believe that greater transparency in wages and wide-ranging Commission action is needed to equally equal pay between men and women as soon as possible.  The pay gap is one thing and the other is that women often have to reconcile family and professional life. There are therefore fewer than men in the labour market, but there is a lack of infrastructure to make it easier for women to return to work or start their careers again. We must also bear in mind maternity and parental leave, during which women sometimes receive lower wages and thus pay lower pension contributions, and also retire earlier than men. All this leads to a huge difference in the amount of benefits. It is currently as high as 38% in the EU. The average length of service of a man at the time of retirement is 37 years and women are only 33 years old. As a result, women of retirement age are much more likely to be exposed to extreme poverty and social exclusion. Therefore, when drawing up a strategy for gender equality and closing the pay gap, does the Commissioner also intend to draw attention to the problem of poverty and the exclusion of older women?

name: Presidente. –
text: The following is the debate on the Commission's declaration "Priority for housing" as an urgent action to address the situation of homeless people in Europe (2019/3013(RSP)).

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Parliament for organising this debate because it touches on one of the major problems that is at the heart of our concerns about social exclusion and misery. The number of homeless people in Europe continues to grow. In fact, you only have to walk around our cities to find out. Living in decent housing at a reasonable price and in a safe environment is a fundamental need that can be considered a human right. The situation of the homeless is a major challenge in a growing number of European countries. There are no official and comparable figures on the extent of this challenge. However, the few figures we are aware of indicate that the number of homeless people has increased in the majority of Member States over the past decade. It is estimated that there are some three million homeless people in Europe. Every night, more than 400,000 people sleep on our streets. This is a daily and tangible problem that we face in our cities and that challenges us. The causes of this problem are multiple and complex, but it is established that housing market parameters and housing policies have a direct and significant impact on homelessness, which is a form of extreme exclusion and particularly affects vulnerable groups, particularly people with disabilities and migrants. Recent analyses specifically identify rising housing prices and the shortage of social housing as a key factor. Indeed, the increase in rental and purchase prices makes housing less and less accessible. As such, social housing, market surveillance and housing benefit can potentially help households. However, many citizens, without becoming homeless, can suffer and often suffer from fluctuations in markets and housing policies, including prices that are literally exploding. The housing crisis is linked to a lack of investment. The High-Level Working Group on Investments in Social Infrastructure in Europe estimated in its 2018 report that investment deficits in affordable housing amount to almost EUR 57 billion in the European Union. Although the Union does not have the competence on housing - which is often a local competence in the Member States - social housing and homelessness play an important role within the EU's social policy agenda. The Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU stipulates that the Union recognises and respects the right to social and housing assistance so as to ensure a decent existence for all those who lack sufficient resources, in accordance with Community law and national laws and practices. The European Pillar of Social Rights includes a principle dedicated to housing and assistance for the homeless. It is a clear political signal on the importance that the European Union attaches to the fight against homelessness and housing exclusion. The European Pillar of Social Rights sets the bar high by promoting the reintegration of homeless people into society by means of enabling social services. The Commission will now launch a broad consultation on the implementation of the looter at a national, regional and local level. The EU's role will be to work alongside all levels of governance for the benefit of citizens, and housing should also be a focus of this process. Principle 19 of the looter is included among the areas of investment of the European Social Fund Plus (ESF) and the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) for the post—2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. Applying the integrated housing—led approach, housing action supported by the ERDF should be combined with thematic areas that can be supported through ESF. In addition, we foresee an increased guarantee for social infrastructure within the proposed InvestEU, the EU's future financial instrument for investments. The European Fund for Strategic Investments is already playing a key role by financing a wide range of social infrastructure investment projects, including affordable social housing projects. Through the European Semester, the Commission provides Member States with policy support, guidance and guidance on how to design efficient national policies aimed at ensuring citizens' access to affordable and accessible social housing by stressing housing supply shortage, dysfunctional housing markets, macroeconomic imbalances and insufficient stock of social housing. The issue of homelessness has to be fully taken into account at the level of our policies fighting poverty. The Commission has shown its readiness to support Member States when and where possible on tackling homelessness. A good example is the integrated housing-led approach, which follows the principles of Housing First, that is: combining the provision of immediate housing with enabling services to empower homeless people to sustain their tenancy, promote stable living conditions and prevent repeat homelessness. Through the tools at its disposal, the Commission enables the exchange of good practices and learning between Member States. The Commission also directly supports FEANTSA, a European—level network of national organisations focusing exclusively on the fight against homelessness and housing exclusion. It runs concrete projects at the local level and has benefited from close to EUR 5 million-worth of grants from the European Commission.

name: Dennis Radtke
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I can already hear the voices saying: why are you dealing with such a subject? You are not responsible at all. And here I can only say: yes, it may be that we do not have original competence for this issue, but I believe that an issue such as the truly exploding homelessness in the European Union and, overall, the extremely tense situation in the housing market here in the middle of this Parliament must be discussed, because if we were to turn a blind eye to such a development as parliamentarians. , then we would not be worthy to be Members of this House. If we look at the situation above all in the large conurbations, where we have exploding rents on the one hand, scarcer housing – the whole thing is combined in many places with rising energy costs – if one considers, in Germany alone 400 000 households without electricity, a total of 17 million households in the European Union, which cannot heat properly or cannot heat at all. , this is, so to speak, compounded by even more inexcising developments, and that is what we have to deal with. And I would also like to be clear: we also need to address business practices such as those of Airbnb, which, on the one hand, have unfair competitive advantages over hoteliers and pensions, and on the other hand, exacerbate these developments. We also have to deal with the fact that we do not even have a single instrument to measure the situation of homelessness in Europe. These are all things that we urgently need to tackle and, detached from this, a question must also be brought to the heart of the political debate: how can we promote property formation, especially for young families? This is at the very beginning of the chain, and the problems we are discussing here are, so to speak, at the end of the chain, but we must also do something at the beginning of the chain.

name: Agnes Jongerius
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Mr President, there is a shortage of 300 000 houses in the Netherlands. This is a city the size of my own Utrecht, the fourth city in our country. There is a shortage of affordable housing, both in the rental sector and in the owner-occupied housing sector. Only 10% of the houses for sale are affordable and accessible to first-time buyers. In the rental sector, it's just as difficult. Besides the fact that there are hardly any affordable houses, there are often also very strict requirements. For example, people must immediately earn three times as much as the bare rent per month. Social rent is already very difficult: there are long waiting lists in my city, of more than ten years. In addition, the number of homeless people has doubled in the netherlands, the wealthy Netherlands, in the last ten years.  I therefore make an appeal in the first place: sign the petition 'Housing for All'. In this way, we are all putting the European institutions and the European Commission to work to ensure that there is an affordable home for everyone. I call on the Commission to come up with a European plan, not only to combat homelessness, but to work towards an affordable roof for all European citizens.

name: Dragoş Pîslaru
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Mr President, there are 700 000 homeless people in the European Union in one night - a figure that has risen by 75% since 10 years ago. According to estimates provided by FEANTSA, the European Federation of Organisations Working with the Homeless, Eurostat data show that in 2017, one in four Europeans in poverty lived in an overcrowded dwelling. In first place is Romania, unfortunately, where 47% of the total population lives like this, and in 65.9% of cases we are talking about families with children. Romania is also in a dramatic situation in terms of housing conditions, with 17.2% of the population living in inadequate housing. Housing is the first element that leads to the fight against homelessness. The Housing First programme has had outstanding results in countries where it has become part of national strategies: Finland, the Netherlands, Portugal. Figures from Romania and elsewhere in the European Union reflect the low effectiveness of policies to combat homelessness. Cases from Romania such as Pata-Rât in Cluj or Pirita in Maramures are not acceptable. The argument that the Ministry of Development does not work with that of Labour, Health and Education must remain somewhere in the past.  There are two important premises for the enlargement and development of the programme in Europe: the identification of adequate and secure housing and the provision of stable and sufficient funding so that it can become a widespread response to the problem of homelessness.  I call on the European Commission, and I am ready to join in this endeavour, to set clear objectives for the promotion of social impact investments within investeu and to ensure that the Housing First programme is integrated into regional, national and local strategies. The Romanian Government calls for prioritising the resolution of homelessness and aligning with successful European policies and practices in the fields, with a view to developing a national strategic framework with an integrated cross-sectoral approach to social housing policy.

name: Katrin Langensiepen
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Everyone needs a home. Housing is a human right. Denying a person a home means depriving him of his dignity and human rights, his social participation and his future. So if the European Union wants to act on its own fundamental rights, it must finally intervene and set itself a clear goal of ending homelessness by 2030!  Ending homelessness is a matter of political will. This is what Finland shows us with its Housing First strategy – in my view, a paradigm shift in how to deal with people without shelter, how to see them. Homelessness is never just self-indebtedness. In Germany, hundreds of thousands of people are homeless. In Finland, this exclusion hardly exists any more. In order to live up to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and to put pressure on Member States, the Commission must call on all Member States to develop a national strategy to prevent and tackle homelessness. We need an EU framework that makes recommendations on preventive and reactive measures and monitoring the objectives through the European Semester.

name: France Jamet
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we must fight against the poverty and precariousness that affect the homeless and 12 million poorly housed, if only in France. Except that it is the European Union that has nevertheless contributed greatly to the aggravation of this problem in many Member States. Austerity policies that have been in place for more than a decade are you. Therefore, it totally disqualifies you for having the pretension to regulate the excesses of unbridled free trade and ultra-liberalism.
