And even if it is difficult to defer to Mr Macron, who is so zealously and zealously applying your injunctions, the fact remains that in our opinion, the legitimate step to get out of this infernal spiral can only be national. You are not competent, you said earlier, dear colleague. Sure, but you are responsible, and God laughs at men who weep over the consequences of which they cherish the causes.

name: Elżbieta Rafalska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Homelessness is an extremely complex problem, it is a wider social policy problem that cannot be reduced to social assistance only.  This is, firstly, prevention, which does not allow homelessness to arise, and supporting those who find themselves in homelessness and getting them out of homelessness. You spoke of the need to develop services for homeless people. I am signing up to this thesis, but it would also be necessary to look at the causes of homelessness. Among these causes is also the situation of life, family conflict, addiction, eviction and check-out. We have talked about homelessness in Europe increasing, and in Poland we are conducting a homelessness survey every two years and it has decreased by 9% in the last two years. So it is important to create support instruments and the situation on the labour market. Of course, the housing situation is crucial here. And I think that without external action, without government support, without the preparation of a proper policy, it will not be possible to create affordable and accessible housing.

name: Leila Chaibi
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 700,000 people sleep on the streets in Europe every night. On the other hand, there are more and more people who have a roof over their heads but are at risk of being on the streets. Faced with an increasingly expensive private rental stock, social housing is a solution, but then something asks me: how is it possible that, on the one hand, the right to housing is mentioned in the European social rights base and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights and that, on the other hand, The Member States that invest in social housing are sanctioned by the European Commission on the pretext that they would distort competition from the sacro-holy market? Commissioner, housing is not a commodity. If you agree with me, prove it and take public investment in social housing out of the 3% rule, because in order to live, to be able to dream, you have to know where to sleep.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Mr President, the American Housing First programmes that you are planning are neither new nor have ever solved any problems. They are aimed at just a few of the millions of homeless and impoverished people across Europe, for whom, because of unemployment and the broken wages of workers, decent housing is a luxury for airbnb co-workers and expensive homes that go beyond the labors of a lifetime. The European Union is defiantly shedding crocodile tears for the homeless at the same time that, in its fourth post-monumental assessment of Greece, it is exasuing the current and former government's declared target of 120 000 auctions of popular housing by 2021. With successive capitalisations and exemptions of red loans, banks and funds are rewarded, and the bill is paid by the people, with dismissals of bank employees and bans on mobilisations against auctions. We demand a legislative ban on auctions of popular homes and the seizure of payroll and pension bank accounts by the state, banks and funds. As has been shown, only with a centrally designed socialist economy can the roof cease to be a commodity and popular housing can be guaranteed. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Dennis Radtke (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague for his work I would be very interested, because I am not indifferent to what you have said here: if the situation on the housing market and also the homeless situation were as easy to explain as you have just done here, then I would ask you whether you can explain to me how it is in countries where the troika has not decided, so to speak, , where and how savings are made, this situation could occur in these places, if it is as simple as you have shown here.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: answer a question with a blue card. – All the more so in these countries, such as Greece, where the challenge is even greater, with all these so-called greetings and whining about the homeless that we hear here. All the more so with the attitude of the European Union, which, by promoting all these anti-labour measures, has 'crushed' a people and at the same time led them to auctions — which it even sets as numerical targets, referring to 120 000 by 2021 — and even provokes and promotes prosecutions and bans. So this is the policy of the European Union not only in them, but also in all the other countries.

name: Cindy Franssen (PPE).
text: Mr President, homelessness is unacceptable. Recent estimates even mention 700 000 people who are homeless. "Housing First" offers a unique opportunity to provide homeless people, often with complex needs, with a roof over their heads.  There are many projects in the field in several Member States and in practice this approach appears to be working. Already many homeless people were accompanied to a stable housing situation. It also creates opportunities to overcome health, mental and financial problems, to regain access to the labour market or to education. After all, a policy on homelessness goes beyond just housing. Health must also come first. Will the announced child guarantee also reach homeless children, Commissioner?  The recommendations of the Social Protection Committee on tackling homelessness are clear: a multidisciplinary approach across different policy areas. We urgently need to work with these recommendations. We are counting on an ambitious plan.

name: Manuel Pizarro (S&D).
text: – Mr President, on this cold night in which some 700,000 people in Europe are going to sleep on the streets or go to sleep in shelters. It's a drama that's been getting worse over the last decade. With the exception of Finland, in all Member States the problem has been getting worse. I know that this problem requires a multiple answer: housing is needed, of course, and first of all, but we also need a response in the social field, in the field of health, in the psychological aspect. All this has to be an integrated response, but the answer is urgent. It is urgent and needs to be articulated with other programmes that exist or are being promised by the current European Commission: the child guarantee, the youth guarantee, the disability strategy, the action plan against poverty. But it is time for us to move on, and Europe needs an action plan to tackle this problem, it needs an action plan that has clear and ambitious targets articulated with member states, regions and municipalities. We cannot accept the idea of a European Union where there are people who have no right to have a home and therefore live in the deepest social exclusion. Commissioner, we trust your action to reverse this.

name: Véronique Trillet-Lenoir (Renew).
text: Mr President, I will speak in French. Housing is also an urgent public health issue. In France, people on the street live on average 30 years less than the rest of the population. Being homeless means being more vulnerable to risky behaviours and related diseases. Too often, it is also to be excluded from health systems and official statistics, as shown by the recent report of the Observatory of Doctors of the World. How, therefore, does the Commission intend to better document the situations of the most vulnerable in its indicators and in particular in health situations. As you have pointed out, Commissioner, the European social rights base must be translated into concrete action. It is essential that no one is left out, let alone in terms of health, which is our most precious asset.

name: Kim Van Sparrentak (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, currently everywhere in Europe, the housing crisis is becoming more visible. The number of tenants’ movements is rising and local governments are starting to take more radical action to safeguard affordable rents, but the doubling of homelessness during the last decade in the European Union hasn’t gotten the same amount of attention. The increase in homelessness shows the dramatic human costs of failed policies of austerity, precariousness and financialisation. The most vulnerable people in society are the ones that are hit first and hardest, with increased rent, energy prices and scarcity of houses resulting in them losing their home. But tonight we are discussing solutions for homelessness, which I hope to see implemented quickly. First, let’s all agree that criminalising homelessness is definitely not a solution and this horrible practice has to stop. Second, let’s make sure that combating homelessness is part of the Child Guarantee to break the poverty cycle. And third, let’s make sure that more EU funds become available for Housing First programmes. Providing a roof over people’s heads gives them space to stop surviving and, with assistance, to be able to start living.

name: Guido Reil (ID).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I am incredibly grateful to you that, having announced that we are putting the issue of homelessness on the agenda, we are finally talking about this important issue. I've been on the road for the last three years. I have looked after the homeless in my home area of the Ruhr area, and since I have been a Member of this Parliament for six months, I have also taken care of the homeless in Brussels and Strasbourg. And I can tell you what I have experienced is appalling. I can invite each of you to take a tour with me under the bridges of Strasbourg. It is not romantic under the bridges of Strasbourg, I can assure you. There is hardship and misery. We are witnessing a humanitarian disaster in Europe, which is now affecting three million people. Homelessness is the plague of the 21st century, and it is not just that we have no remedy for it, we ignore this huge problem. I've seen people just go over the top of the homeless. They are no longer perceived at all. We have no solution, not even a beginning. We must finally address this important, real problem.

name: Beata Szydło (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. We are discussing an important, very important problem today, which is homelessness. I think that for us MEPs, the symbol of this problem, which is not solved and which should be a remorse for all of us and of the European Union as a whole, is the homeless, which we can see every day around the European Parliament also in Brussels or, as my colleague just said, here in Strasbourg. The migration crisis has exacerbated this problem, but we cannot sit with our hands folded, but we must take effective action. In this respect, I wanted to draw attention to another dimension of homelessness that awaits Europe: Europe is ageing. This is an increasingly serious problem of breaking family ties, lack of care for children and insemival parents. These older people often remain in a dramatic situation. They are removed from their apartments or have no opportunity to live anywhere at all. I ask that, also within the framework of those programmes that are being prepared at the moment, we pay attention to this aspect to old people who require our particular care.

name: José Gusmão (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, housing programmes have first produced results because they treat homelessness as citizens, responding to the problem of housing and leaving there to solve other problems of poverty and social exclusion. In Portugal, notably in Lisbon, a first housing programme is being implemented first without a single support from the European Union, and therefore, since the European Commission likes the idea of housing first, it was interesting to see if they intend to do something about it, whether they will have funding lines, or whether at least the European Commission, which has been hit so hard by liberalising the financial system and the rental markets , by the austerity policies that have restrained purchasing power for European citizens and the restriction of public investment policies a little across Europe, has something to do, something to present, to support these programmes, or at least to stop harming them.

name: Claire Fox (NI).
text: – Mr President, many years ago I worked at a homeless shelter in the Midlands in England, and it is an issue close to my heart. So this ‘Housing First’ initiative has much merit. But I have some concerns. I worry there’s a danger in a transnational centralised one-size-fits-all approach that can mean ignoring local and national circumstances and solutions. I’d like to stress that the causes of homelessness are not universal. I think that it can mean avoiding deeper long-term solutions. So, for example, the horror and degradation of homelessness has been in some countries directly the consequence of the impoverishing and brutal austerity policies imposed on nation-states in eurozone countries by this very European Union, that has led to unemployment, evictions and homelessness. But in turn, those stagnating economies in some countries force people to move around Europe looking for better lives, understandably, and they often, too, end up homeless. For those who glamorise freedom of movement, to remind you that according to the charity Crisis, the number of homeless people from continental Europe accounts for a third of all rough sleepers in London. Freedom of movement can mean people are far from home, exploited in low-paid jobs, with no support network. As one Polish man told the FT, homeless for five years: ‘Brexit or no Brexit, I’m staying, there’s nothing for me back there’. We have to make sure that we solve the problem at home before trying to impose from this central EU holier-than-thou body.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in September 2018 the ‘Housing First’ principle was introduced in Ireland, and it has been successful in reducing the number of rough sleepers – those we visibly see on the streets of Dublin, our capital city – not completely, but certainly it has had an impact. But it is a particular model, and it needs to be modified for every country. I’ve seen it work in the Midlands of Ireland where, for example, a derelict building was converted for 10 individuals who needed that extra support, and they have that and they are secure.  But of course this debate – and Commissioner, you’ve opened it out to be a much wider debate than just Housing First because in my own country after the housing crisis we have now a real crisis still for some families who are living in emergency accommodation, and while we have built social housing – 10 000 last year – we still have significant numbers who need housing. So I think it’s useful to hear there are problems across Europe, and it would be helpful to know that we would find common solutions.  We equally need affordability. We need people with skills to build housing, so Commissioner, if you can, with new energy I suppose, bring Europe together on this housing crisis, I think it would be very helpful. But I would say that outside the Parliament in Brussels it is quite awful to see the number of homeless people who sleep in all sorts of weather, as it is here in Strasbourg, as was referenced by a colleague.

name: Estrella Durá Ferrandis (S&D).
text: – Mr President, homelessness does not just mean not having access to decent housing, but involves serious problems of health, access to the labour market and social benefits and, above all, even personal security. Housing First is a model that is working successfully in some Member States, and is a strategy that combines accompaniment with access to social and health services. That is why we need a strong commitment on the part of the Commission to implement this model in all Member States, with sufficient budgetary allocation and the inclusion of homelessness as an ambitious objective in the table of social indicators of the sustainable semester. Commissioner, I am reminded of your commitment on this subject, and that is why I hope that the Commission will soon present a draft recommendation establishing an action plan to eradicate homelessness. Finally, I would like to point out that this problem significantly affects mobile citizens within the European Union. On this point, a new Commission communication would be desirable to ensure that the rights of these workers are respected and do not end up on the street.

name: Francisco Guerreiro (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it is estimated that there are around 700,000 homeless people and 11 million families living in vulnerable and serious housing conditions in Europe. And this number continues to increase, which shows that we live in a deeply unequal society. But for homeless people there are real solutions, and we can see it through the Finnish example, with the Housing First program. This programme guarantees primary access to decent housing, but does not focus solely on this point: it also expands into social policies, as well as ensures coordinated action in the field of health and access to employment opportunities. It is also of fundamental importance to note that the eradication of extreme poverty is one of the priorities of Agenda 20-30 and the sustainable development goals. We thus have 10 years to ensure that this goal is complied with. And in Portugal, also by the hand of the PAN Party, we began to move towards the national implementation of the Housing First program. These are small but important steps. But, Commissioner, the challenge is not only for the Member States, so the Commission must urgently move forward with a strategy to ensure that by 2030 no citizen is vulnerable to a fall in the poverty trap.

name: Silvia Sardone (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are, of course, all in favour of programmes that help the homeless, help them rehabilitate themselves, have a roof over their heads and reintegrate into society. However, since we are here, we should also think a little about the causes, and if we are to say the whole thing, in short, the European Union has responsibilities, because it has in fact multiplied the homeless and the misfits, increasing the number of people who bivouac on our streets and who are delinqueous. I say this because good will, fake integration, limitless reception, saying 'we all have doors open', praise for multiculturalism, what have they actually done? They have increased the number of immigrants, bringing immigrants to our territories. Unrestrained immigration leads to degradation, social hardship, increases crime (because they somehow have to live) and increases homelessness on our streets. So, since we're here, maybe let's do a little less rhetoric and a little more self-criticism.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Αρβανίτης (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, the loss of housing is the first consequence of the policy of poverty, Commissioner, Mr President. It is a political consequence; it is not natural, it is not a natural phenomenon. Especially in the countries of the South the roof was the last refuge in the slip towards absolute poverty. Under Alexis Tsipras' prime ministership, in Greece, the first residence was protected "with claws and teeth". Today the Minister for Development of the new right-wing government stated that, from 30 April, a framework of absolute non-protection of the first residence is being put in place; On the basis of the UN's objectives for sustainable development and Mrs von der Leyen's programme for the immediate implementation of the 19th principle of the European Pillar of Social Rights, I ask: How will all the weak be guaranteed access to housing programmes? Secondly, I call for a ban on first home auctions. I believe that strengthening existing housing must be a universal right, a right guaranteed — primarily by Europe — a right to reintegration into society. And we stress: Not funding housing in special areas, not in ghettos, but within the basic social fabric.

name: Daniela Rondinelli (NI).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against poverty in all its forms has become an emergency that can no longer be postponed, and the housing first proposal can be a credible response to the deplorable phenomenon of homelessness. However, as the 5-Star Movement, we reiterate that, without the break-up of social policies from the point of view of the Stability Pact, this initiative too risks remaining a dead letter. Mr Schmit, we are experiencing a huge contradiction: on the one hand, at European level, it is said that support for social policies, the fight against poverty and inequalities is important but, at the same time, the Member States are told to invest in social housing and social housing within budgetary constraints. As the European Commission, have the courage to propose the disuning of social investment from the Stability Pact, because only in this way will it be possible to give concrete and tangible answers to people in need and in poverty. The citizens of Europe are asking us strongly, Commissioner, that is our task, we must do it today and also restore their lost dignity to the homeless.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – Honourable President-in-Office. I dare say that Europe is the most socially orderly continent. We can set an example to the world. We know how to take care of various weaker groups, we are the largest donor of humanitarian aid in the world. In this sense, we are rich and therefore must also help those who cannot afford it to live a decent life. Of course, the homeless, too. A decent life for me means having a roof over my head. That's the basis, and some people can't afford that basic. That's why we have to help them. They were pushed to the edge of society by their lives. I support that individual countries, each with their best and every knowledge, are trying to help the homeless. And we can share good practices with each other. Of course, it is the Commission that, with some integrated approach, can encourage the Member States to take the best path. At the same time, I would also like those who receive and receive this social assistance to be treated responsibly.

name: Milan Brglez (S&D).
text: – Dear President-in-Office! In any case, homelessness is regarded as a more overlooked and growing form of human rights violation. Above all, it is about the right to a decent standard of living, which always includes the right to housing. Sometimes it even goes so far as to put the lives and personal safety of the individual at risk.  The Member States of the European Union and the European Union itself are, of course, obliged, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, to take measures to reduce and eliminate homelessness. They are also bound by other human rights instruments and by the European Pillar of Social Rights itself.  The fact that the number is increasing and that it is only Finland that has so far managed to avoid it really forces us to urgently help or help in this programme or to use this 'Dwelling First' programme, because it allows social inclusion and prevents other forms. In any case, there is an urgent need to stand up for a decent housing for all.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, nine years ago I was pushing the first strategy for the homeless. I was a social housing reporter. Every year, I sound the alarm, and governments sleep. Where are the emergency meetings? Where are the sums to be raised as soon as possible? The situation is terrible: the increase in homelessness, plus 70% in 10 years. In France, a homeless person dies every day, in England 59% of the homeless are children. You said that we do not have numbers. Eleven million people do not live in decent housing, which is a scandal. Eleven million people are men, women, children who suffer in their flesh. You are telling me that there should be more of a welcoming policy, but the policy of welcoming Member States is just expensive, inefficient but above all inhumane. The time is no longer in the sparadrap, Commissioner. Ladies and gentlemen, I call for a start, a wake-up call, a little humanity in this Parliament. It is time to join forces to help the weakest. It is time, Commissioner, to say that the Commission will take responsibility and call on the Member States, instead of always favouring the richest to tax exemptions, to impose real investments in social housing. Europe has been able to mobilise for the banks, so it is high time that it stretched out in the face of the plight of the most vulnerable. Commissioner, Europe is not governed by indifference.

name: Mathilde Androuët (ID).
text: Mr President, God laughs at men who deplore the effects of which they cherish the causes, and in my opinion God must laugh often by observing our institutions. If you want to improve the situation of the 700,000 homeless people on our continent, then the European Union must immediately change its software. First, stop encouraging over-concentration of services, places of life and jobs in areas where concrete is the norm and where house prices are exploding, forcing some poor workers to sleep in their cars. Secondly, stop encouraging the anti-social logics of a Europe geared solely towards financial gains instead of strengthening the natural family or institutional solidarity of our social retirement policies, disability aid or public health. And finally, stop growing the ranks of the homeless by importing millions of illegal immigrants: 95% of migrants are considered homeless in France. With a 70% increase in the number of homeless people in Europe in 10 years, it is clear that the two subjects are linked. For these three major reasons of which you are the political cause, the European Union is destined to remain a continent where the number of homeless people does not decrease. So, before launching a broad communication plan on the subject as a surety and a guarantee, change course right away for the good of everyone and especially the poorest.

name: Στέλιος Κυμπουρόπουλος (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, there are several reasons why one can find oneself on the road: failed Education, lack of domestic understanding, discrimination, domestic violence, addictions, sudden unemployment and a health issue. Long-term solutions are back in Education and the economy. However, since the need is immediate, I would also like to refer to the good practices of Finland and the Housing First programme. We need ambitious decade targets. A long-term residence offered, combined with social workers and job opportunities, is a good framework for reintegration. Opportunities for work people want so they can stand and see the sun. These fellow human beings were not fortunate enough to have people around them to support them in difficulty. Let's be their people! Let us build a network of solidarity and support, as first of all we are human beings. That's what we show in difficulties, and not just at Christmas!

name: Bernhard Zimniok (ID).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the From 2006 to 2015, the year Merkel opened the border illegally, about a quarter of a million people in Germany were consistently homeless. Since then, there has been a rapid increase. It is estimated that there will soon be more than one million homeless people in Germany. There are no official statistics on this. It is also tragic that many children, women, young people and even entire families have to live on the streets.  In my hometown of Munich, the same picture emerges: in 2015 about 5,000 people were homeless, today 10,000. The reasons: a lack of affordable housing, the shrinking of the stock of social housing, and – let us not turn a blind eye to this – the impact on the housing market of uncontrolled illegal immigration. Construction is currently underway in Munich as if there were no tomorrow. And for whom? For people who can afford to pay a price of €10,000 upwards, and for illegal migrants and their family reunification. The low-income person is left behind, lives on the street or has to dodge the surroundings. I therefore call on the Commission to do your job and close the external borders before social unrest or worse occurs!

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I must say that the housing affordability situation is indeed very difficult, even catastrophic, and is constantly deteriorating in many states. Housing costs are rising dramatically, and the availability of housing is indeed deteriorating significantly for entire sections of society. Social rights in the European Union have ceased to exist in this respect or are fundamentally undermined. We are witnessing major storms in Berlin, Munich, a number of other cities, such as Prague, where housing is growing very rapidly, which is particularly unaffordable for the young generation and the socially vulnerable. What to do about it? I think that support measures need to be implemented in the labour market, in the housing market, of course, and cooperation with municipalities needs to be achieved. This is a task for the government, for the European Union, but also for the municipalities. The situation in the area of homelessness is also a failure of the European Union, we should be aware of this.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Mr President, you will have to bear with me; I have a throat infection so I have to speak quietly and slowly. While there are issues at present between the cities of London and Brussels of which we shall not speak here, they are both among the richest regions of the European Union, yet in Westminster Underground and in Place du Luxembourg, parliamentarians step over homeless human beings. We should be ashamed of that – because this is a massive failure of public policy. It is not about migration; it is about a failure to invest in homes.  I represent one of the richest regions in the European Union – South-East England – and I would say to anyone in that region who thinks it could never happen to them: it can. If it happened to you, or your son, or your daughter, or your grandchild, or your parent, how would you wish them tret? As a criminal? As a vagrant? As an addict? In modern developed societies, the right to a roof above your head should be a right of every citizen, yet homelessness is everywhere. Putting it right starts with the right attitude, and here I want to praise Brighton and Hove Council and their adoption of a homelessness bill of rights, and it ends with the recognition that social cleansing of our cities is immoral and that when you don’t build homes, you get homelessness.

name: Ciarán Cuffe (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, in Ireland there are 4000 children without a home. Homelessness impacts greatly on women, on children, among young people and migrants. And sadly, I don’t believe that our Irish Minister for Housing, Eoghan Murphy TD, and his Fine Gael colleagues, understand the urgency of this and the depth of the crisis in Dublin, in Ireland, and in cities around Europe. Mairead McGuinness spoke earlier about a slight reduction in rough sleeping. What she failed to point out is that we have seen more than a doubling of homelessness in Ireland in five years, over a doubling amongst women and a quadrupling of the amount of homelessness amongst children. That needs action. And there are ways to solve this. It shouldn’t mean going from the streets into a hostel, into a hotel, into a homeless hub and, if you’re lucky – 10 years later – into a home. What it does need is Housing First! And the lesson from Finland and the lesson from Vienna, from Austria, of the Housing First model, of the cost-rental model, shows that if you build homes, if you provide a roof over people’s heads, it works. So I want to see the European Commission start a convention on homelessness to bring attention to the problem and then learn these lessons and work with the European Investment Bank and the European Central Bank to provide the funding to solve this crisis. We shouldn’t have homelessness in 2020.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, in recent years the number of homeless people has increased in the European Union. It is a complex issue, but not unrelated to social degradation in this territory, the deregulation of labour, the liberalisation of housing or energy markets or the privatisation of public services. The explosion in house prices in several Member States has not been accompanied by rising incomes, and there are cases where tenants spend 40% of household income, or more, on housing while many others live without decent housing. The right to housing must be guaranteed as enshrined in the Constitution of the Portuguese Republic. The discussion on housing and the inclusion of homeless people is not possible without a public housing policy regulating markets, promoting public services, ensuring urgent social responses. It is not possible without the creation of conditions that guarantee the right to work with decent rights and wages as the centre of a global policy of inclusion and development.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, honourable Members, this debate shows that this problem of homelessness exists in the south, north, east and west. It exists in virtually every major city. This shows that this is a local problem, but also a European problem, and we cannot avoid this problem by saying that, at the end of the day, Europe has no competences or the competences reside mainly with The Member States or local authorities. We are challenged and your debate shows that. We want to get involved and we want to find solutions. The challenge is considerable, the numbers have been mentioned and the resources we need are also considerable, but not impossible to mobilize. I agree that the first solution is actually supply because there is a huge supply gap in Europe. The housing market has become a speculative market, and we must be able to say that as well. We must therefore ensure that supply in our Member States and in our cities is once again keeping up with demand.  It is true that housing is at the heart of all social issues. First, work, employment. You don't have a place to live, you won't have a job. You don't have a place to live, your health is deteriorating. You have problems, your problems get bigger from the moment you are on the street. We therefore need a comprehensive approach that first addresses the problem of housing but accompanies those who are the victims of absolute exclusion, in the return not only to employment, but I would say towards dignity because the people who are on the streets are deprived of their essential and fundamental dignity. We have admirable texts: we have the declaration, we have the foundation, we have our values; it is now a question of action and it is a call that emanates from both sides of this Parliament. We are not going to sit idle. The housing problem must be at the centre of the fight against poverty. Moreover, when we talk about a guarantee for children, housing is an integral part of it and, without wanting to make too specific commitments now, I think it is important that we come together to work on a concept, to bring Member States, local entities together with the Committee of the Regions, among others, to actually develop a common approach. Of course, it will not be uniform because, despite everything, the situations are diverse, but we need a thread, a real thread that guides our policies, that also inspires the policies to be implemented. This is an offer I am making to you, I hope and I am convinced that your Parliament will join in. We will be working on a real housing policy that will be rolled out at all levels but of which Europe will be an inspiration.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Elisabetta Gualmini (S&D)
text: in writing. The number of homeless people in Europe and around the world is increasing significantly, with a few rare exceptions. The problem is urgent and alarming; It is above all the weakest groups that are affected, i.e. young people, women and foreigners. Social groups already at risk of poverty who, without an adequate place to live with dignity, will see their living conditions irretrievably deteriorate to the point of death. In many European regions there are already experiments and policies to welcome homeless people and to help restore an autonomous and self-sufficient life, for example the Housing First project in Italy and in particular in Emilia Romagna. But we obviously need robust public funding and inclusion policies shared at the various territorial levels. The house is everyone's right. The house allows you to develop your own life project and commit to the future. Without a home there is no dignity. I hope that the Commission will include a robust chapter on housing policies for the homeless in the implementation of the Social Pillar.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. – Hungary pays particular attention to the management of homelessness. It is important that all homeless people are given the opportunity to access services and that no one is forced to spend the night in a public place. We don't need alarm, we need action. The protection of human life is paramount! Nearly 10 000 accommodations (night shelters and temporary accommodation for homeless persons) are available nationally on an annual basis. More than 1 600 additional places can be used by persons in need during the winter season (intermittent capacity). In addition, more than 7,600 daytime heating capacities are available nationwide. In addition to the municipalities, a significant proportion of ecclesiastical and non-governmental organisations are involved in the operation of the institutions. On 8 January 2020, the use of night shelters was about 85.08% nationally and 83.66% in Budapest.  In total, there were around 666 available places for night shelters nationwide. The First Housing programme is also implemented in Hungary – building on the experience of previous hungarian (Back from the Street) and EU programmes. The aim is to get homeless people on the streets out of their crisis, to be placed in independent housing and to help them rehabilitate by a multidisciplinary team. A total of 14 applications were accepted, amounting to approximately HUF 1.85 billion, for which 11 applications came from the convergence regions and 3 from the Central Hungarian region. The project will provide housing for more than 300 homeless people with special needs.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. – Homelessness is contrary to a dignified life, which is why the European Union must be involved in this issue. Up to 20% of homeless people in the Czech Republic are people under the age of 30. A big problem is also the debts that their parents in their childhood will indust. There are more than 14,000 juveniles with debts in the Czech Republic. A very vulnerable group are mothers with children who are one foot on the street due to executions. These problems must be addressed. However, I believe that the issue of homelessness must be dealt with directly by the Member States at national or local level. It is the local authorities who know the situation in their area best. A good example of a local housing first project in the Czech Republic is the Rapid Re-housing project in Brno, where 50 city apartments were provided to homeless families. Within two years, 46 families were able to maintain their households. If people on the street or hostels can maintain stable housing, their health improves, the chances of finding a job increase, and poor parents are not in danger of ending up in institutional care. I believe that the European Union plays an important role in the financial support of similar projects. However, the very solution to this issue remains in the hands of the Member States from the point of view of subsidiarity.

name: Presidente. –
text: The following are one-minute speeches on important political issues (Rules of Procedure 172).

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we are currently in a situation where the new European Commission has been created, and I am pleased that the European Parliament has also made it clear that it will not tolerate any suspicion of a conflict of interest. I think that is also a very strong signal to citizens. Today, these are the programme and content priorities of the European Commission and the European Parliament, and I would like to highlight one that I consider to be the most important, namely the situation of small and medium-sized enterprises. I'm talking about small farmers, freelancers, technicians, many people in the IT field who need help. I am sure that we will best help them by enabling them to reduce administrative burdens, simplify life, complete the common market in services, build a common digital market and, above all, build a capital union so that they have better access to resources. Small and medium-sized enterprises should not be forgotten, because they form the skeleton of the economy and create values for the future of the European Union.

name: Иво Христов (S&D).
text: – Mr President, less than 800 tonnes of waste destined for incineration in Bulgarian thermal plants was seized by the Italian authorities less than a month ago. Investigations in the Italian media followed, linking this trafficking to the local mafia. International crime benefits from free movement within the European Union. The de facto route of the garbage trade in Europe can also be a channel for the trade of drugs and other illegal traffickers. At the same time, the health and environment of Bulgarians fall victim to the absence of European control mechanisms. Bulgarian citizens do not want our country to become a dump. I therefore appeal to the representatives of the European Commission for rapid intervention in the case and proposals for control of trade in waste in the European Union.

name: Judith Bunting (Renew).
text: – In 2018 Cyprus ratified the Istanbul Convention, which states that the rights of victims should be protected at all stages of an investigation and that judicial proceeding should enable victims to be heard, to supply evidence, and to have their views, needs and concerns presented. Last week, a British teenager was convicted of public mischief in Cyprus and handed a four-month suspended sentence after being found guilty of falsifying a rape claim. This young woman’s legal team has reported irregularities, which may have led to a questionable verdict in this case. How is it possible for a court to conclude this woman was lying when the judge has refused even to consider whether or not she had been assaulted? The woman in question has also reported that she was denied a lawyer, which is against the European Convention of Human Rights. We demand, we call on Member States to require that all Member States strive to uphold commitments made in the Istanbul Convention, that Cyprus addresses procedural issues that may have taken place in this case, and that the Cypriot legal system should ensure any appeal is heard by the Supreme Court.

name: Silvia Sardone (ID).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is Parma ham, it is an excellence made in Italy, but for the Nutri-Score system, what you want to introduce throughout Europe, is an unsealed food: you see, it has category D. so it's a must eat. This pre-cooked pasta, pretending to be Bolognese and fake Italian, also has the letter A and the green sticker, so for you it is a healthy product. Does that seem normal to you? In fact, healthy, natural products are rejected, also at the base of the Mediterranean diet, such as extra virgin olive oil, Parmigiano Reggiano – excellence also of my territory – and industrial, frozen or pre-cooked products are favoured in an absolutely discriminatory way. In short, I simply want to say, not only personally but on behalf of the entire ID group, that we will barricade and wage war, here in the Chamber, to protect healthy products and therefore also made in Italy.

name: Magid Magid (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the President of the United States of America publicly and repeatedly fantasised about carrying out war crimes in Iran. The truth is President Trump doesn’t really care about America – like the shifty, failed, plastic mafia boss of his simple imagination, he only cares about himself. So my dear fellow Europeans, on behalf of world peace, in the name of justice, I call upon the European Union to impose sanctions directly on this warmonger and associates. The only deterrents this limited individual understands is what personally and financially hurts him. So freeze his European assets, restrict his travel once he is a private citizen again, place sanctions on his beloved golf courses, and let the lessons of Europe be clear: war criminals do not win. But, friends, let us talk of hope. The hope of peace. The hope of an honest president. America needs that hero to throw off the terror of an endless war, and to secure a brilliant future for all. That hero, that great hope, just could be Bernie Sanders.

name: Charlie Weimers (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The conference of Ursula von der Leyen and the European Commission on the future of Europe lacks legitimacy. It is yet another flawed elite project, because the aim is clear: to transfer more power to europe. However, such a transfer of power lacks popular support. Britain's withdrawal should have been a wake-up call, as should the euro crisis and the migration crisis.  We want europe to be a flexible cooperation between sovereign states. An Intergovernmental Conference with the Member States in the driving seat is the way in which the Treaties are provided for in order to amend the EU Treaties. It is constitutionally and democratically legitimate, so let us go down that road. However, I am concerned that many will not respect the treaty-entrenched processes, but will push for this conference, but rest assured that you have an opposition in us.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, almost exactly a year ago today, a dam of toxic waste from a mining company, Vale, collapsed in Brumadinho, killing 272 citizens in Brazil. That area is still suffering. Today, as we meet here, protesters gather, and have been gathering since Christmas Day, to protest and demand protections from the likelihood of other dams bursting, causing other similar consequences. We in Europe are culpable for this. It was a German company that built the dam. It was a German company that falsified a certificate of stability, and it is German investments and European money which has backed it up. As we meet – and the European Investment Bank has promised another EUR 100 million of investment in Brazil – we have a responsibility to these people to ensure that the perpetrators are brought to justice, and that all of our investments are met with the binding legal business and human rights treaties in order to ensure that such catastrophes are not done and carried out in the name of profit and in our name.

name: June Alison Mummery (NI).
text: – Mr President, can somebody please tell me why the EU is allowing super trawlers to operate in the English Channel and the Irish Sea? Dutch-owned super trawlers, which are up to 14 times the size of an average fishing boat, have already caused controversy in South America, have been thrown out of Australian waters, and have contributed to massive overfishing in West Africa. The fact is, when it comes to managing our seas, it’s not just what you catch, but what you kill. In the English Channel alone, super trawler bycatch threatens John Dory and bluefin tuna stocks and poses a significant threat to dolphins, but incredibly these vessels have also been allowed to work within the English Channel sea bass hatcheries.  Sea bass is a species under so much pressure. British fishermen are banned from catching it. It is precisely this type of mismanagement that has made the EU’s common fisheries policy an economic and environmental disaster. It is time to learn the lessons of the past and ban the operation of super trawlers. The Africans don’t want them, the Australians don’t want them, and neither do we.

name: Traian Băsescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism was introduced for Romania in 2007. In the initial phase it had four objectives. The latest report, the one for last year, has no fewer than 18 recommendations, marking a jump of about 13 years. True, the report was drafted during the election campaign, when my friend Frans Timmermans exercised his critical qualities on justice in Romania. In order to have a fair report, I call on the Commission to redo the report for Romania, through independent experts, not subordinated to Commissioner Timmermans.

name: Carmen Avram (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the new green pact will probably bring about changes comparable to those produced by the great revolutions that humanity has gone through, but we have an obligation to ensure that there are no dramatic, social consequences, as have been seen recently in Europe.  For example, in Romania, before accession, the conditions imposed by the European Union were also that of the closure of mines declared non-performing. A tragedy of proportions followed. Hundreds of thousands of people went into unemployment, cities went bankrupt and turned into ruins. There have been social unrest all over the country for years. No government program could repair the disaster that was also humane and economic and ecological. Even today, 16 years away, in those areas, retraining is minimal and poverty is maximum.  I therefore call on the Commission to ensure that the future mechanism for a fair transition will supplement, will not replace, the Cohesion Programme, which must be continued because it has not ended, that this mechanism will be applied surgically exactly where it needs to be, that it will come with technical assistance and, above all, that it will not widen the gap that still exists between the countries of eastern and western Europe.

name: Antony Hook (Renew).
text: – Mr President, as Churchill envisaged in 1946, we have recreated the European fabric and produced the structure under which it can dwell in peace, safety and freedom. Decisions made here will still have an impact in my country for a long time to come, so the success of the European Union remains vital, and I believe the UK’s separation will be temporary. In our recent election, 53% of voters demanded another say on Brexit. Yet people in the UK live under a sham electoral system, which turns 42% of votes into 56% of seats. Almost all our press is owned by a few men living abroad. Britain’s party of government is funded by a tiny number of very rich men with no legal limit on donations. The Prime Minister suppresses a report on Russian interference in our elections. In time, we will again live up to Churchill’s vision, and democracy and Britain’s place in the European Union will be renewed.

name: Peter Kofod (ID).
text: Mr President! Child benefit, maternity rules, border controls, the right to Danish unemployment benefits and welfare benefits are all examples of the EU taking control away from us. The EUROPEAN Union will decide more and more and even more. Yes, i suppose there is nothing that the European Union does not think it should interfere in. But now not only will the EU elite take control away from us, it seems that the flags will also be taken away from us. It seems to have been decided that we should not have our national table tabs at our seats any more. For me, the flag on the table was meant as a deep respect and humility to the many, many Danes who have entrusted me and the Danish People's Party with their voice and trust. If the EU elite wants to lecture me on what to do with our flag, Then I can tell the EU elite what it can do about our flagpole. I'm not going to make a correction, because I know, and I remember, what I went to and what I promised the Danes, and that was the fight for the preservation of the nation state.

name: Francisco Guerreiro (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Australia is devastated by forest fires that have destroyed an area of more than 107,000 square kilometres, killed 28 people and incinerated more than 1 million animals.  But the growth of these extreme weather phenomena had already been predicted by the scientific community. Nothing that would demean the Australian government from acting. Worse, the current government publicly denies the impacts of climate change and actively promotes an economic and trade policy based on highly polluting sectors, such as the coal industry and the livestock sector. And it is against this backdrop that the European Union continues to negotiate a trade agreement with Australia to strengthen international trade and to reduce tax barriers between economic blocs. As if CETA were no longer enough, giving economic and political ballast to Canada, which exploits oil from tar sands, and the agreement with the Mercosur countries, which actively destroy the Amazon, Europe is now moving towards yet another disastrous transnational climate agreement. The European Commission and this Parliament must put a definitive end to this political and economic insanity of creating trade agreements at any price. It's time to stop. We're still in time.

name: Jorge Buxadé Villalba (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would now say, at 11 p.m., what President Sassoli, in breach of my rights as an MP, has prevented me from saying this afternoon, in accordance with Article 195 of the Rules of Procedure of this House.  Article 3 of the Rules of Procedure of this House establishes a procedure for becoming a Member, which is that the competent electoral management authority of each State forwards the corresponding credentials for one to be subsequently admitted. However, President Sassoli's attitude, accepting that Mr Puigdemont and Mr Comín, who have not come before the competent Spanish electoral authority, have not upded the Constitution, and are escaped from Spanish justice, may be in this Parliament, constitutes an attack on the European Electoral Act, an attack on the Rules of Procedure of this House, and seriously jeopardizes the legality and validity of all agreements adopted in this House. from now on.  I don't know where Mr. Sassoli wants to go. You have already had to give in to Mr Junqueras, since the Supreme Court of the Kingdom of Spain has shown you that we are right, and we also have the law on our part. He'll end up doing it with Mr. Comín and Mr. Puigdemont. I just want to say that Mr Sassoli is causing an unprecedented institutional conflict, he is putting this Parliament out of the law, and reminding him that, without law, there is no democracy.

name: Presidente. –
text: Although you are entitled to your opinion, I just want to inform you that President David Sassoli has not taken any decision. It was only aware of the decision of the Spanish judicial bodies.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, in Portugal, in the last decade, we have felt particularly vividly the antisocial and anti-national nature of the European Union's determinations. It was the successive stability programmes and the Troika programme that destroyed rights, cut workers' incomes, destituated and privatised public property and degraded public services. It was blackmail and threats of sanctions when the country began a path of replacement, defense and conquest of rights and income. It is now the determinations which want to impose no longer a limit on the budget deficit but even a budget surplus, in place to feed those who profit from our indebtedness, which itself are inseparable from the consequences of the European Union's policies at national level. Well, this surplus they want to impose on workers and the people Portuguese is the denial of the response that is lacking in improving their living conditions and in the development of the country, an answer that will not be given fully until the interests of the people and the country prevail over the impositions of the European Union and of those who command it.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, at this point, I would like to wish the re-elected President of Taiwan, Cai Ying-wen, who clearly won last Saturday's elections. Four years ago, I had the opportunity to meet her at her presidential inauguration, and I understood that she was a strong woman who had really led this country to prosperity. From the point of view of its relationship with China, it has acted prudently in the interests of the taiwanese people's ownness, so as not to provoke China unnecessarily.  The elections in Taiwan are, from some point of view, a feast of democracy. The only free choices in the context of Chinese civilization. They take place in a fair manner, all within range of Chinese missiles aimed at the island. China has stepped up political and international pressure on Taiwan in recent months, signaling that it does not rule out a military solution. President Tsai has kept a cool head and has taken some measures as well. A law against foreign infiltration of elections in Taiwan has been passed, just as we in Europe have experience of Russian interference in elections by disinformation, so they also have a wealth of experience with Chinese disinformation in Taiwan. I think that the European Union and Taiwan can join forces in this, and I congratulate it.

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent In two weeks we will commemorate the victims of the Upper Silesian Tragedy. We refer to this as repression against the Silesian population, which began in Silesia in January 1945 and lasted for three years. Arrests, rapes, detentions in concentration camps and forced expulsions for catory work in the Soviet Union. This tragedy cost the lives of more than 90,000 people simply because they were Slezakami. Camps in Świętochłówce-Zgodzi, Myslowice, Łambinowice are sad symbols of this tragedy. The Tragedy of Upper Silesia has not yet become part of the universal collective memory, and it should. We should teach about it in schools: Polish, German, Czech, European. We should also provide all children in Europe with regional education lessons, because regionalism and the love of their own Heimat are the best response to blind nationalism.

name: Jane Brophy (Renew).
text: – Mr President, this is one of the last plenary sessions before Britain leaves the EU. We may be going, but leaving will impact far into our future.  Today, Parliament discussed the tragic bushfires that have decimated Australia’s homes and wildlife. In Yorkshire, in northern England, people’s homes have been devastated by floods. The EU offered millions of pounds of funding in flood relief, but the UK rejected it. In 1980, our British beaches were badly polluted and they were unsightly too. Just 40 years later, 99% have been designated safe for swimming, mostly because of GBP 3 billion of EU funding.  Can we trust Boris Johnson’s Government to keep our beaches clean? Can we trust that our native species of birds will be saved again from extinction? Who will be there, when the floods come to the UK again, to support us? The EU has worked tirelessly to invest in a shared future for our children. Weird weather events must be a warning to everybody that climate change does not respect international boundaries. It is up to the elected representatives of every nation to protect our planet from environmental destruction, and Britain is so much worse off without the European Union.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the obligatory rule is that it is darkest under the candlelight. The European Union regulates a wide range of policies, enters a number of areas of our lives, sometimes happily, sometimes less appropriately, but what we incomprehensibly miss is the regulation of the activities and financing of political parties, and now I mean the national ones. There is a lack of any transparency in this regard, many states do not have at all regulated the reporting of the activities of national political parties and the availability of this data for national authorities, but also for citizens in general.  And it must be said that we have a number of cases where national political parties act as trojan horses of third powers, sometimes Russia, sometimes others. I can talk about the Freedom Party from Austria, the AfD, the Brexit Party, The Hungarian Jobbik and a whole range of other parties. And I think it is important for the European Union to start addressing this issue as well, because it is usually the darkest under the candlelight, but also the greatest risk.

name: Vlad-Marius Botoş (Renew).
text: – Mr President, Romania has one of the greatest incidences of cancer. Unfortunately, the treatment and care of cancer patients is not to acceptable standards. Their fight and their families is incredible.  I know what it means to see family members sickened by this disease. I know what it means to fight with them in a system that doesn't seem to be trying to help you, quite the contrary. That is why I think it is important that from here, at the level of the European Parliament, dear colleagues, we make as many projects as possible in which the main objective is prevention.  This chapter of health falls within our remit. We owe it to all those who voted for us to think of clear ways to prevent disease. It is no longer news to anyone that excessive pollution and nutrition are among the main causes of illness.  Let us give due importance to this chapter! Let us recognise that the health of European citizens is or should be our greatest concern and act accordingly!

name: Eugen Tomac (PPE).
text: – Mr President, my intervention today concerns a subject of our enlargement policy. Lately, the European Union has focused its attention on the Western Balkans, but I recently visited one of these countries – it is Serbia – and I note that, although Romania made it conditional, when negotiations began seven years ago with this country, that the rights of minorities be respected, I noticed something that I find extremely serious , namely, that the rights of the Romanian minority in this country – there are more than 300 000 Romanian speakers – are still disrespected. There is no access to education in the Romanian language, there is no freedom for the citizens of this Romanian-speaking country to have their own media institutions, and it is all the more serious since the ban on the construction of a Romanian church in Malainitsa, in Eastern Serbia – a church, which has been threatened with demolition for several years by the Serbian authorities – has not been withdrawn. So I am sounding the alarm to the Commission and i am calling for the rights of national minorities in this country to be strictly monitored, because, although a bilateral agreement has been signed between Romania and Serbia – an agreement that has been negotiated by the current Foreign Minister, Bogdan Aurescu – for 7 years, it is not respected and I think it is inadmissible as a country with European aspirations , who wants to become a member of the European Union, not to comply with these commitments.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Mr President, thank you for bearing with me again. Following representations by an elected representative in my constituency, I’m raising this issue as a matter of public record before this House. In recent days, following various media reports, the case of a young British female tourist who made a complaint to police of a multiple rape while on holiday in Cyprus has come to light. She later withdrew the complaint following 10 hours – 10 hours – of police questioning without legal representation. As a result, she was charged and found guilty of the crime ‘fomenting public mischief’ and assigned a four—month prison sentence, suspended for three years. Justice in this Union should work without fear or favour. We are all equal EU citizens. Having looked at reports of this case, I believe there’s a serious miscarriage of justice, or there’s evidence of that, which will do damage to the ongoing reputation of Cyprus. While I welcome the reality of a suspended sentence and the safe return of the young woman in question, I will be raising this issue with my Cypriot colleagues. It is my hope that her name will be cleared on appeal. This Union cannot be considered complete until justice and women’s rights are guaranteed throughout its territory.

name: Cristina Maestre Martín De Almagro (S&D).
text: – Mr President, depopulation is one of the challenges we have to face in this new legislature. The ageing population, the exodus of young people and the low birthplace of rural areas are common characteristics of this phenomenon, but not the only ones. The point is that there is a growing imbalance between depopulated areas and urban areas. That is why I would like to recall here the responsibility of the European institutions to prevent these inequalities and to ensure that all citizens have access to basic services and opportunities, regardless of where they live. To date, CAP funds, ERDF funds and the European Social Fund have financed certain specific activities aimed at curbing depopulation, but we now need to prioritize strategies, measures fully studied and financed and in line with the new needs and realities of 21st century society. For example, the promotion of new technologies and digitization in the rural environment through high-capacity networks, or also to bet on sustainable growth and development models and the stimulus and incentives to fix population. In short, what I want to ask is agility, commitment and that, once and for all, we are already working to implement all these measures by virtue of the commitments we have all made to the demographic phenomenon and challenge.

name: Sunčana Glavak (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, perhaps to what my colleague said before me, only a strong Europe can adequately respond to the challenges of the modern world, and that is why the four priorities of the Croatian Presidency, which we will hear more about tomorrow morning, and we have almost stepped into tomorrow, can be summed up in a strong Europe in a world of challenges.  I am sure that we all want a Europe that is evolving, with a clear emphasis that smaller and larger, both rich and poor have equal opportunities, a Europe that connects with the full potential of all its capacities. Bringing Europe closer to the citizens and informing them as best as possible about all that Europe brings because, let's not forget, it is their home.  At the initiative of Croatia, demography is included in the strategic program of the European Union, and Dubravka Šuica is the vice president entrusted with this very task, the Conference on the Future of Europe. We want a secure Europe that protects, we want an influential Europe. We want to strive to strengthen Europe's position in the world, our old continent which has an indispensable role to play a corrective and a force for new challenges in the world.  Are we ready for them? I'm sure Croatia will show that we are. We will hear more about all this tomorrow, and all of you who will come to Croatia, I want you to feel that Croatia is breathing strongly for the European Union.
